  • Identify directories focused on creative works, poetry, short stories, or artist portfolios.
  • Submit your website or project with appropriate descriptions using your target keywords naturally.
  • Maintain accurate, updated profiles to leverage ongoing link benefits.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Low-quality directories or spammy link sources can harm SEO rather than help.
  • Over-reliance on directories without diverse link-building can limit overall authority growth.

Example

Submitting poetry site URLs to creative work directories to reinforce the niche relevance related to poetry or short stories.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leverage Podcast Appearances for SEO Backlinks and Brand Exposure

What It Is

Use guest appearances on podcasts within your niche to gain backlinks in episode show notes and increase brand visibility.

Why It Works

Podcast show notes often include backlinks; linking your site from trusted podcasts boosts authority and referral traffic. Plus, podcasts expose your brand to targeted audiences.

When To Use

Content creators, authors, bloggers, and small businesses wanting to build topical authority and backlinks through outreach.

Execution Steps

  • Use tools like podcastmatcher.com to find relevant podcasts seeking guests.
  • Pitch yourself as a guest, emphasizing your expertise in your creative niche.
  • Provide your website URL and a clear keyword-focused description to the host for inclusion in show notes.
  • Follow up on published episodes to promote and build further reach.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Requires outreach effort and preparation.
  • Not all podcasts provide backlinks or detailed show notes.

Example

Using podcastmatcher.com to connect with podcast hosts and gain backlinks with blurbs mentioning your poetry or short stories service.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Target Bottom-of-Funnel Keywords with High Conversion Intent ("Compact Keywords")

What It Is

Focus on keywords where searchers have strong intent to consume or purchase (e.g., exact content seekers), aiming to convert searchers into consumers quickly.

Why It Works

Bottom-of-funnel keywords attract motivated searchers ready to engage or buy, leading to more immediate traffic and potentially higher conversion rates.

When To Use

Especially relevant for ecommerce, service providers, or content creators selling or promoting creative works or products online.

Execution Steps

  • Identify keywords that directly relate to product or service intent (e.g., “poetry about sadness” rather than just “poetry”).
  • Create well-optimized pages that meet this search intent with clear pathways to conversion (links to buy books, read poems, etc.).
  • Use keyword-focused titles, meta descriptions, and user-friendly content that leads to action.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Ignoring early funnel keywords might reduce brand awareness growth.
  • Excessive focus on conversion without quality content may hurt user trust over time.

Example

Targeting the keyword “poetry about sadness” with a page that lists poems and offers access or purchase options, capturing motivated searchers.

These strategies extracted from the transcript provide a comprehensive, niche-focused SEO playbook suitable for creative bloggers, writers, and small site owners pursuing rankings with targeted, low-competition keywords and user-focused content optimization.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

LLM.txt File Usage

What It Is

A plain text file (LLM.txt) intended to assist large language model (LLM) AI chatbots by highlighting the most useful content, brand information, and important site links for AI to crawl and use.

Why It Works

The idea is that LLM bots would directly access and utilize this file to better understand and rank your site's content by guiding AI on what content and brand info to prioritize.

When To Use

Proposed for sites wanting to optimize specifically for AI-based content use and generative search engines.

Execution Steps

  1. Create a plain text LLM.txt file at your site root.
  2. Include clear statements about your brand, most valuable content, and key links.
  3. Submit or make accessible to bots.

Pitfalls & Limits

According to recent empirical data from Adobe’s audit of 1,000 domains, major AI bots (Google, GPT, OpenAI bots) practically don’t request or use LLM.txt files. The file is currently not adopted by AI platforms and is ineffective. Investing effort here is largely wasted.

Example

Flavio Langato’s audit showed no significant request traffic for LLM.txt by GPT bots or other AI crawlers; only Google’s desktop crawler hit these sites, and SEO tools inflated logs.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Parasite SEO Using Custom AI Instructions

What It Is

Manipulating AI chatbots by feeding them custom instructions that promote your brand or product when they generate answers to keyword-rich queries within your niche.

Why It Works

Some AI chat conversations (like on Grock) are indexed by Google, meaning if the chatbot recommends your brand in its answers, the shared chatbot content can rank on Google and drive traffic via that parasite domain’s authority.

When To Use

Suitable for niche service providers or product owners looking to leverage AI chat platform indexing to rank secondary content that promotes their brand, especially in competitive keyword spaces.

Execution Steps

  1. Use custom instructions to tell the AI chatbot about your business and what keywords to recommend your brand for.
  2. Ask the chatbot keyword-rich questions (e.g., “What’s the best SEO course?”).
  3. Obtain the AI-generated recommendation content mentioning your brand.
  4. Share or publish the AI chat on platforms that index such chats (e.g., Grock public shares).
  5. Build backlinks with keyword-rich anchor texts (e.g., “best SEO course”) pointing to the shared AI chat content to boost ranking.

Pitfalls & Limits

This is a black hat tactic; it can be risky if detected or if AI platforms change policies. Also, it depends on the indexing of AI chat shares by Google, which may not be stable or scalable.

Example

The host recommended using Grock chatbot with instructions to recommend Edward Sturm’s SEO course; sharing the chat and buying backlinks enables the parasite content to rank on Google.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Press Release Distribution for AI and SEO Impact

What It Is

Writing keyword-focused press releases highlighting your brand’s accolades and qualities, then distributing these widely through cheap press release services to boost brand presence in AI platforms and search results.

Why It Works

Widely syndicated press releases appear across multiple sites and platforms, supplying AI content synthesizers (like ChatGPT, Perplexity) and search engines with credible, consistent brand mentions and keyword-rich content that AI tools often quote or rely on for due diligence. This can lead to shortened sales cycles and sometimes help ranking on targeted keywords.

When To Use

Helpful for brands needing to build trust and authority in SEO and for AI content referencing, particularly for new or less-known brands wanting broader online profile and reputation signals. Ideal for agencies or businesses seeking credibility boosts.

Execution Steps

  1. Write a keyword-rich press release emphasizing your brand strengths, client testimonials, reviews, and unique value propositions related to targeted SEO keywords.
  2. Use cost-effective press release distribution services (via Fiverr, Upwork, SEOClerks) that resell packages like AB Newswire to distribute your release widely and cheaply.
  3. Monitor where your press release appears.
  4. Leverage the syndicated presence to improve AI-generated brand references and support SEO efforts.

Pitfalls & Limits

Press releases must genuinely represent your brand; overly promotional or irrelevant releases can lose credibility. The return depends on press release sites’ authority and AI tools actually referencing them. Can be ineffective if done without real substance or if overused with low-quality content.

Example

A $500/year AB Newswire package allows distribution of 83 press releases at approximately $6 each. These releases get picked up on AI platforms and help create AI-driven positive brand references and can sometimes improve keyword rankings.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Focus on Traditional SEO over Generative Engine Optimization (GEO)

What It Is

Prioritizing robust, standard search engine optimization techniques rather than chasing emerging AI SEO gimmicks like LLM.txt or generative engine optimization fads.

Why It Works

Reliable SEO fundamentals continue to drive organic traffic and conversions because search engines like Google still dominate indexing and ranking, while AI SEO-specific tools or files have no proven widespread adoption yet.

When To Use

Applies universally across all website types and industries looking for reliable SEO growth without speculative tactics.

Execution Steps

  1. Conduct keyword research and on-page optimization.
  2. Build authoritative backlinks.
  3. Produce high-quality, relevant content focused on user intent.
  4. Monitor analytics and adjust based on data.
  5. Ignore unproven AI-specific SEO hacks like LLM.txt at this time.

Pitfalls & Limits

Avoid chasing AI SEO trends prematurely; investing time in unproven speculative files or tactics wastes resources. However, ignoring AI entirely could miss future opportunities—balance is key.

Example

The transcript repeatedly highlights that LLM.txt is unused, and AI platforms still rely on classic SEO signals, reinforcing that good SEO is the best “geo” strategy.

These four strategies are the only unique, specific, and actionable SEO tactics described in the transcript.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Write SEO Copy for Searchers, Not Search Engines

What It Is

Focus on creating content that directly addresses the needs and intent of the actual searcher, rather than producing keyword-stuffed or overly mechanical copy designed only to appease search engine algorithms.

Why It Works

Google’s algorithms increasingly prioritize user experience signals, including relevance to user intent and satisfaction measured through engagement metrics like bounce rate and time on page. Writing for users ensures lower bounce rates and higher engagement, which positively influence rankings.

When To Use

Crucial for all SEO content, especially for ecommerce sites, service providers, and bottom-of-funnel keywords where users have clear action intent. Also essential for updating existing content that underperforms.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify the search intent behind your target keywords (informational, navigational, transactional).
  2. Understand the knowledge level and expectations of your searcher for each keyword.
  3. Craft copy that quickly delivers the specific information or reassurance the user needs to take action, avoiding fluff or redundant explanations.
  4. Use natural, clear language that feels human and directly answers the searcher’s query.
  5. Avoid keyword stuffing or forced placements; prioritize readability and flow.

Pitfalls & Limits

Writing only for search engines leads to poor user experience and higher bounce rates. Overthinking or overoptimizing keywords without addressing user needs wastes effort. This strategy may require more upfront research and iteration but yields better long-term results.

Example

Targeting “maca powder for energy” with copy that explains why your brand (e.g., Maca Deluxe) specifically delivers sustained energy, rather than generic info about maca powder benefits, which aligns with purchase intent.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Align Copy with Search Intent (Top, Middle, Bottom of Funnel)

What It Is

Tailor your content tone and detail level depending on where the keyword sits in the buyer’s journey—informational (top), consideration (middle), or transactional (bottom).

Why It Works

Searchers have different expectations depending on their funnel stage; mismatch in content depth or style decreases relevance and reduces conversions or rankings. Google’s algorithm rewards content that best fits user intent per query.

When To Use

Useful for all types of sites, especially those targeting diverse keywords across funnel stages — ecommerce, B2B services, SaaS, and content marketing sites.

Execution Steps

  1. Categorize your target keywords by intent and funnel stage.
  2. For bottom-of-funnel keywords, focus on brand/product specifics and calls to action.
  3. For top-of-funnel keywords, educate and inform without pushing sales.
  4. Align headlines, first sentences, and content tone consistently with the funnel stage.
  5. Review competitor content and user queries to confirm intent interpretation.

Pitfalls & Limits

Misclassifying intent can confuse users, increase bounce rates, and lower rankings. Over-explaining obvious information to bottom-funnel searchers reduces trust and conversions.

Example

Writing bottom-funnel copy for “maca powder for energy” as a purchase page highlighting the brand’s unique energy benefits instead of a generic informational blog explaining why maca powder gives energy.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Put Keyword in Critical Page Elements Only

What It Is

Use your primary keyword strategically in the page title, URL slug, meta description, H1 heading, and the beginning of the first sentence, but avoid excessive keyword repetition.

Why It Works

These elements signal page relevance to search engines efficiently while maintaining natural content flow. Keyword stuffing beyond these areas triggers algorithmic penalties and creates poor user experience.

When To Use

Applicable for all SEO content creation and updates, particularly helpful in ecommerce product pages, landing pages, and blog posts targeting competitive keywords.

Execution Steps

  1. Incorporate the primary keyword exactly once in the URL slug.
  2. Use the keyword naturally in the page title.
  3. Write a compelling meta description containing the keyword.
  4. Include the keyword in the H1 header.
  5. Start the first paragraph with the keyword or a natural variation.
  6. Focus remaining content on user value without forcing keyword inclusion.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overusing keywords after these key placements leads to clunky writing and possible ranking penalties. Underusing keyword placements can reduce relevance signals if missed entirely.

Example

No specific case example beyond general best practice references given.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Deliver Answers “Above the Fold”

What It Is

Provide key answers or content value immediately visible on the screen without requiring users to scroll.

Why It Works

Users seek quick information; immediate answers reduce bounce rates and improve engagement signals. Google favors content that satisfies user intent fast.

When To Use

Effective in all content types, especially for mobile users, ecommerce product pages, FAQ pages, and quick-answer informational content.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify the main user question or intent.
  2. Place succinct answers or key points at the top of the page layout.
  3. Use clear headings and formatting to highlight this information.
  4. Avoid fluff or lengthy introductions before getting to the point.
  5. Test on multiple devices to ensure critical info is visible without scrolling.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overloading the above-the-fold area with too much content can overwhelm users. Not applicable for purely narrative or storytelling content where context buildup is necessary.

Example

The transcript notes traditional SEO copy often buries key info forcing users to scroll excessively, resulting in poor performance.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Explicitly Show Why Your Brand Fits the Keyword Intent

What It Is

Instead of generic product or topic information, highlight how your specific brand or product matches the exact benefits or use cases implied by the keyword.

Why It Works

Searchers with transactional intent want reassurance that your brand meets their needs; delivering this builds trust and increases conversion likelihood, which positively impacts SEO performance indirectly.

When To Use

Best for ecommerce and service sites targeting bottom-of-funnel or branded keywords with purchase or usage intent.

Execution Steps

  1. Analyze the keyword to understand the specific user expectation (e.g., energy from maca powder).
  2. Frame your brand/product messaging around these specific benefits or features.
  3. Avoid generic statements about the category; emphasize unique brand strengths or differentiators.
  4. Integrate product-specific proof points, testimonials, or technical benefits to reinforce claims.
  5. Place this messaging prominently near the start of the page.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overpromising or making unfounded claims can damage credibility. Not relevant for purely informational or top-funnel content.

Example

“Maca Deluxe is maca powder for energy, giving you lasting stamina, sharper focus, and a natural lift without the crash” instead of just generic maca powder benefits.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Avoid Keyword Stuffing and Forced Keyword Insertion

What It Is

Do not excessively repeat keywords or awkwardly shoehorn them into unnatural parts of the text just to increase keyword density.

Why It Works

Keyword stuffing reduces readability and user experience, leading to higher bounce rates and algorithmic downgrades by Google’s sophisticated spam detection systems.

When To Use

Vital across all content creation scenarios. Essential when optimizing competitive keywords or updating legacy content.

Execution Steps

  1. Incorporate the keyword in important elements (title, URL, meta, H1, first sentence) naturally.
  2. Write the body copy for users without repeating the keyword artificially.
  3. Use synonyms or related terms naturally as they fit.
  4. Proofread content to ensure smooth and natural flow.
  5. Employ SEO tools to detect keyword stuffing and adjust accordingly.

Pitfalls & Limits

Underusing keywords in important on-page signals can limit relevance. Overcorrecting by removing all keyword mentions can weaken SEO signals.

Example

The transcript highlights common mistakes of keyword stuffing leading to clunky, awkward writing that no longer performs well.

These six distinct, actionable strategies summarize all the key SEO tactics articulated in the podcast transcript, framed for clarity and practical implementation.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Expert Sourced Content via Help a Reporter Out

What It Is

Use the platform Help a Reporter Out (HARO) to source expert answers for content creation by responding to journalists’ queries and then expanding those brief answers into full-length articles by soliciting additional input from all contributors.

Why It Works

This taps into user-generated content from real industry experts, boosting topical authority, E-A-T (Experience, Expertise, Authority, Trustworthiness), social sharing, and backlinks as experts promote their contributions. Also, expert-byline content enhances brand clout and search visibility for both the publication and the experts.

When To Use

Effective for niche sites, industry blogs, brands targeting thought leadership, and publications wanting to scale expert-driven content quickly. Also useful for increasing branded search volume and topical authority.

Execution Steps

  1. Sign up for Help a Reporter Out as an expert or monitor journalist queries in your niche.
  2. Respond to relevant queries with short answers.
  3. Request expanded responses (5-6 paragraphs) from all contributors to build comprehensive articles.
  4. Edit or use AI tools (e.g., Claude) to proofread for grammar and title generation without rewriting content fully.
  5. Publish full articles featuring multiple expert contributors.
  6. Repeat regularly to build volume and network of authors.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Fully relying on AI for rewriting can create inauthentic content and harm credibility.
  • Quality varies widely; some submissions will be mediocre.
  • Requires editorial effort to polish content and manage contributors.
  • Journalists might not pick your initial answers easily; persistence needed.

Example

The speaker has successfully repeated this multiple times, generating increased branded searches, backlinks, social shares, and raising topical authority in their niche.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Personalized OG Images Featuring Contributor Faces

What It Is

Create custom heading images (Open Graph images) that include the contributor’s headshot and branding, used as social media preview images when the article URL is shared.

Why It Works

Social posts with personal faces attract more clicks due to social validation and connection recognition, increasing engagement and social sharing, which can indirectly support SEO through increased traffic signals and backlinks.

When To Use

Ideal for sites with multiple contributors or guest authors looking to increase social engagement and shareability, especially in content marketing or thought leadership contexts.

Execution Steps

  1. Obtain or request headshots from each contributor.
  2. Use a design tool or AI-powered graphic generator to create a professional header image including the expert’s face and your site branding.
  3. Implement this image as the OG image meta tag for the article page.
  4. Ensure images are sized correctly for all major social platforms.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Requires permissions for using contributor images.
  • Poorly designed images can harm brand perception.
  • May require design skills or investment in graphic tools.

Example

The speaker uses such images on LinkedIn shares, noting these generate more clicks due to recognition of the connection’s face.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Shareable Quote Images With Contributor Faces and Branding

What It Is

Design graphical quote images embedded within articles that contain quotes from contributors, their headshots, and your website branding/URL, optimized to encourage contributors to share these on social platforms.

Why It Works

Visual quote cards featuring contributors increase social sharing due to personal branding incentives, drive referral traffic, boost brand awareness, and generate indirect SEO benefits. The inclusion of the site URL encourages links and brand recall.

When To Use

Works well for sites with guest authors, thought leadership articles, or any content where expert opinions are highlighted. Particularly useful for industries active on social media like LinkedIn or Instagram.

Execution Steps

  1. Select compelling quotes from contributor responses.
  2. Use design templates or AI tools to create quote images incorporating the quote text, contributor’s photo, and your branding.
  3. Embed these quote images at relevant points in your articles.
  4. Provide these images to contributors for sharing on their networks.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overuse may clutter articles and distract readers.
  • Low-quality images can reduce credibility.
  • Contributors may be reluctant to share unless incentivized or encouraged.

Example

The speaker transitioned from manual creation (Figma, Sketch) to AI-generated images to scale this tactic efficiently.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Alt Text for Contributor Images to Rank for Author Names

What It Is

Add descriptive alt text tags to contributor headshots and other images to help these images rank in Google Image Search, especially for contributors’ personal name queries.

Why It Works

Alt text helps Google understand image content and associate it with contributors’ names, increasing chances your site appears when users search those authors, driving branded search traffic and expanding topical relevance.

When To Use

Highly effective for sites with many guest authors or contributors whose personal brands overlap with your niche.

Execution Steps

  1. For every contributor image, add alt text that includes the contributor’s full name and relevant niche keywords.
  2. Ensure alt text is natural and accurately describes the image.
  3. Regularly audit image alt texts for completeness.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Stuffing alt text with keywords can be penalized.
  • Images without proper attribution diminish value.
  • Only useful if contributors have name search volume or niche relevance.

Example

The strategy was used to boost discoverability when searching for contributors' names within the niche for added topical authority.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Templatized Author Profile Pages for SEO and Engagement

What It Is

Create clean, SEO-optimized author pages containing bios, social media links, and lists of authored articles to improve discoverability of contributors and increase site authority.

Why It Works

Author pages enhance E-A-T signals, enable ranking for author name searches, and provide a central hub linking to multiple pieces of content, improving internal linking and user navigation.

When To Use

Sites with multiple contributors, guest authors, or journalistic content where author credibility impacts trust and search ranking. Essential for building author brand associations within niche content.

Execution Steps

  1. Design a reusable author page template with sections for bio, social profiles, and articles.
  2. Automatically generate an author page for each contributor based on their submissions.
  3. Link author names throughout content to their profile pages.
  4. Optimize meta titles, descriptions, and URLs targeting author names and related keywords.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Requires consistent data collection from contributors.
  • Can create thin or low-quality author pages if contributors have minimal contributions.
  • May require additional moderation to maintain quality.

Example

The speaker emphasizes using this to capitalize on searches for author names and build topical authority within the niche.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Content Prioritization Through Click-Depth Segmentation

What It Is

Segment mediocre or low-value guest content into a subfolder placed at least three clicks away from the homepage, while keeping high-quality content within two clicks, signaling relative page importance to search engines.

Why It Works

Search algorithms interpret shallow click-depth (closer to homepage) as higher importance, so pushing weaker content deeper minimizes its SEO value dilution and preserves site authority for premium content.

When To Use

Useful for large blogs or sites accepting many guest submissions of variable quality to maintain overall site quality signals and user experience.

Execution Steps

  1. Evaluate guest content quality and categorize into standard and “mediocre.”
  2. Publish exceptional content in the main blog directory (2 clicks from homepage).
  3. Place mediocre content in a separate subfolder that requires three clicks to access.
  4. Adjust site navigation accordingly (e.g., exclude mediocre content from main blog links).

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Over-classifying content as mediocre might waste potential.
  • Too deep click hierarchy can hurt crawl budget or indexation.
  • Must balance user experience with SEO signals.

Example

The speaker places lower-quality guest articles in a separate folder three clicks away to preserve SEO value for top posts.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

No-Follow Links on Contributor Social and Author Links

What It Is

Apply nofollow attributes to all outbound links pointing to contributors’ social profiles or websites to avoid passing link equity back to them while still receiving backlinks from contributors to your site.

Why It Works

Prevents reciprocal link dilution or risk of passing page rank to unrelated or competitor sites, allowing the host site to retain SEO benefit while contributors gain credibility from backlinks pointing to the host.

When To Use

Best for sites with many guest contributors where reciprocal linking occurs, and you want to maximize inbound link juice without supporting contributors’ SEO.

Execution Steps

  1. Audit all links to contributor profiles and social accounts.
  2. Add rel="nofollow" attribute to these outbound links.
  3. Regularly check for new links and apply nofollow as needed.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Contributors may feel slighted if unaware of nofollow usage.
  • Not necessary if contributors’ sites are trusted/partnerships rather than unknown entities.
  • Overuse of nofollow could raise transparency or trust issues.

Example

The speaker uses this “salty” approach to retain link equity, as most contributors don’t understand the difference between follow and nofollow links.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Target Keyword-Rich Industry Article Submission Pages

What It Is

Create specific pages targeting long-tail keywords like "[industry] article submission" (e.g., human resources article submission) to attract guest authors searching for publications to contribute to.

Why It Works

Captures search intent from experts looking to write guest content, increasing incoming content submissions, backlinks, and topical relevance, which fuels organic growth of your site’s authority in the niche.

When To Use

Especially effective for industry blogs, publications, SaaS, or service providers looking to grow guest contributions in specific verticals.

Execution Steps

  1. Research relevant long-tail, purchase/pitch-intent keywords in your niche.
  2. Create separate landing pages optimized with target keywords in title, meta description, URL, H1, and first sentence.
  3. Clearly communicate how authors can submit guest articles.
  4. Promote these pages internally and through outreach.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Needs ongoing maintenance to handle requests and maintain quality.
  • Risk attracting low-quality or spammy submissions if not moderated.
  • Requires keyword research to find valuable, intent-rich phrases.

Example

The speaker mentions targeting various "[industry] article submission" keywords to draw in guest authors actively seeking opportunities.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Standard Keyword Targeting on Guest Submission and Author Pages

What It Is

Apply standard on-page SEO keyword targeting best practices—putting keywords in page title, meta description, URL slug, H1, and beginning of content—to all guest submission pages, author pages, and other targeted content.

Why It Works

Proper keyword placement signals to search engines about page relevance and increases probability of ranking for those terms. Helps capture organic traffic looking for guest posting opportunities or author information.

When To Use

Universal tactic for all pages targeting keywords, especially those designed to attract guest contributors or promote authorship.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify target keyword(s) for each page.
  2. Include keywords naturally in the page title tag.
  3. Add keywords in meta description for click-through appeal.
  4. Use keyword in URL slug.
  5. Place keyword prominently in H1 header.
  6. Incorporate keyword early in the first sentence of body content.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Over-optimization or keyword stuffing can harm ranking.
  • Must prioritize natural flow for user experience.
  • Keyword selection must align with actual search intent.

Example

The speaker applies this to industry article submission pages and author pages to improve organic ranking and visibility.

These nine strategies synthesize the full actionable tactics outlined in the transcript for creating expert-driven content leveraging Help a Reporter Out, maximizing social and SEO impact through images, content structure, link management, and keyword targeting.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Press Release Injection for AI Overview Manipulation

What It Is

Distributing low-cost press releases with targeted keywords that get picked up by AI-driven search answer boxes (Google AI overviews, ChatGPT, Perplexity), effectively influencing what these AI systems cite as authoritative sources.

Why It Works

AI models like ChatGPT frequently source their answers from recent, indexed web content, including press releases. By becoming a cited source in AI overviews, brands gain prominent visibility even if traditional organic rankings are not at the top.

When To Use

Best for low-competition, low or no-search-volume keyword phrases; brand mentions during events or promotions (e.g., Black Friday); rapid reputation shaping or visibility augmentation through AI-powered search interfaces.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify niche or low-competition keyword phrases relevant to your brand or product.
  2. Write a well-crafted, keyword-optimized press release that highlights your brand/product strengths and targets these keywords.
  3. Use a press release distribution service (e.g., AB Newswire) that indexes releases quickly for web and AI crawlers.
  4. If cost is a concern, leverage bulk or shared press release memberships (e.g., $500 annual with multiple releases) to keep expenses around $6 per release.
  5. Publish and promote the press release, then monitor citations in AI overview boxes and ChatGPT answers.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Press release tactic is less effective for high-competition keywords or phrases with significant search volume.
  • May not improve traditional organic rankings significantly—mostly influences AI summary features.
  • Overuse or poor-quality press releases can reduce credibility and may be discounted by AI or Google.
  • Relies on press release services being indexed timely by Google and AI crawlers.

Example

Harpit’s press release promoting the “best AI SEO newsletter” targeted very low-volume keywords; the PR showed up as a cited source in ChatGPT and Google AI overview boxes, promoting his SEO Espresso newsletter even though organic ranking was only 4th for the base keyword.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Creating Bottom-of-Funnel SEO Landing Pages for Real Keywords

What It Is

Building dedicated, keyword-optimized landing pages targeting high-intent, bottom-of-funnel search queries that have real search volume and customer intent.

Why It Works

These pages capture qualified traffic from users actively searching for solutions or products, improving conversion rates by matching explicit user intent and supporting better organic rankings through focused content and site structure.

When To Use

Ideal for ecommerce, service businesses, SaaS, and any site aiming to convert visitors actively searching for specific solutions or buying terms. Also useful for new or existing sites wanting sustainable, long-term traffic and leads.

Execution Steps

  1. Conduct keyword research to find compact, high-intent keywords with sufficient search volume.
  2. Develop landing pages tailored around these keywords with compelling sales copy, clear calls-to-action, and trust signals.
  3. Structure the site to house these pages logically (e.g., silo or cluster model) supporting keyword relevance and crawl efficiency.
  4. Build white-hat backlinks to these pages to improve authority and ranking potential.
  5. Monitor rankings and conversion metrics, and optimize content periodically.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Requires initial keyword research effort and quality content creation.
  • Not suitable for zero or no-volume keywords where no organic demand exists.
  • Poorly structured or thin content will hinder rankings and conversions.
  • Link building must be white-hat; manipulative tactics can cause penalties.

Example

Although not detailed with metrics in the transcript, the host emphasizes that creating bottom-of-funnel pages outperforms press releases for ranking real keywords that get actual searches and drive leads.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leveraging AI and Search Behavior Trends in SEO

What It Is

Tailoring SEO efforts to account for the growing role of AI in search results and changing user search habits, including personalization and AI-powered answer boxes.

Why It Works

As Google and AI tools increasingly feature direct answers and personalized content, understanding and aligning with these trends allows brands to capture traffic both from traditional organic results and AI-powered features.

When To Use

Across all SEO projects but especially in markets where AI integration in search (e.g., Google’s AI overviews, ChatGPT citations) is prominent, and for brands targeting personalized or voice search.

Execution Steps

  1. Monitor AI features in search results relevant to your industry.
  2. Identify low-competition, personalized queries that AI frequently answers.
  3. Create content that can act as an authoritative source cited by AI algorithms (could include press releases, blog posts, FAQs).
  4. Combine this with strong traditional SEO — optimized pages, structured data, backlinks.
  5. Track AI mentions and adjust content strategies accordingly.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Rapid changes in AI algorithms may reduce effectiveness unpredictably.
  • Relying solely on AI citations without improving organic rankings is risky long-term.
  • Some AI-sourced content visibility may not directly generate traffic if users rely only on AI snippets.

Example

The $6 press release tactic exploits AI tendencies to cite fresh, online PR content; but broader SEO still requires optimized landing pages and white-hat links, per the host’s recommendations.

These are the three main actionable SEO strategies explicitly described or strongly implied in the transcript.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Parasite SEO on User-Generated Content (UGC) Platforms

What It Is

Utilizing authoritative third-party platforms like Reddit, Medium, LinkedIn Pulse, and former popular sites (e.g., Quora) to publish content or posts that rank quickly for targeted keywords, leveraging the platform’s existing domain authority.

Why It Works

Google favors high-authority domains and prioritizes user-generated content platforms. Leveraging these platforms transfers their authority to your content, allowing faster and higher rankings than building authority from scratch on a new or low-authority site.

When To Use

Effective for quick ranking on competitive or moderately competitive keywords; suitable for affiliate marketers, entrepreneurs promoting their services, and brands targeting local or niche keywords. Best used when your own site has low authority or slow growth potential.

Execution Steps

  • Identify authoritative UGC platforms relevant to your niche (e.g., Reddit, Medium).
  • Create posts/pages targeting specific keywords, placing those keywords prominently in titles and post content.
  • Mimic genuine user behavior (e.g., pose as someone seeking recommendations).
  • Engage with the post to boost visibility (comments, upvotes).
  • Use aged accounts if possible to avoid platform restrictions.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Platforms may have strict anti-spam and self-promotion rules.
  • Using large or heavily moderated sub-communities is difficult due to active moderators and strict rules.
  • Risk of account bans or content removal if overused or flagged.
  • Performance declines on very competitive keywords without additional tactics.

Example

For the keyword "best interior designer Atlanta," posting in smaller, local subreddits with the keyword in the post title and content, followed by upvoted comments recommending a service, resulted in high Google rankings.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Engagement Manipulation on UGC Platforms

What It Is

Boosting the visibility and ranking potential of parasite SEO posts by artificially increasing engagement metrics such as upvotes, comments, and other interaction signals on platforms like Reddit.

Why It Works

Engagement metrics signal to both the platform and Google that a post is valuable and relevant, pushing it higher both within the platform’s search and in Google’s rankings for the targeted keyword.

When To Use

Critical when posting on platforms where user interaction influences ranking; especially useful on Reddit and similar forums where posts with higher engagement rank better in platform search and external search engines.

Execution Steps

  • Post your target keyword in the title and body of the post.
  • Use separate accounts or collaborators to comment endorsing the service or product.
  • Purchase or otherwise secure upvotes on the post and the top comment to increase visibility.
  • Edit the original post later to include references to the top comment as “resolved” or “final decision” to create authenticity.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Manipulation is against platform guidelines, risking bans.
  • Overuse can trigger algorithmic penalties or moderator intervention.
  • Requires multiple accounts and IP diversification to avoid detection.
  • Engagement without genuine value can lead to negative user feedback if discovered.

Example

Posting “Best interior designer Atlanta” in a local subreddit, then commenting with a friend or alternate account linking to the business, purchasing upvotes to boost both post and comment engagement, led to high Google rankings.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Juicing Parasite SEO With Purchased Backlinks

What It Is

Amplifying the authority and ranking ability of parasite SEO posts by acquiring backlinks pointing to these posts on authoritative UGC platforms.

Why It Works

Backlinks remain a core Google ranking factor; adding backlinks to parasite SEO content signals Google to trust and prioritize that content more highly, increasing the chances of ranking in the top 1–3 positions for valuable keywords.

When To Use

Best when targeting high-value, competitive keywords where basic parasite SEO alone doesn’t guarantee top rankings; useful for affiliate marketers and businesses with high commission or search volume keywords.

Execution Steps

  • Create parasite SEO content on high-authority UGC platforms targeting important keywords.
  • Purchase a small number (often just one or two) of quality backlinks to that specific post or page.
  • Ensure the backlinks are from relevant or authoritative domains to maximize effect.
  • Monitor rankings to measure impact and avoid overbuying backlinks that may raise flags.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Buying backlinks violates Google’s guidelines, risking penalties if detected on your own site (though risk is lower when backing parasite UGC pages).
  • Backlinks of poor quality or irrelevant links may not improve rankings.
  • Limited effectiveness if overused or if parasite content is on low-authority or banned platforms.

Example

Affiliates targeting highly competitive keywords combine parasite SEO posts on Reddit or Medium with purchased backlinks, pushing their parasite content into the #1 spot on Google for their target terms.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Using Aged Accounts for Parasite SEO

What It Is

Establishing and utilizing older, trusted accounts on UGC platforms to post parasite SEO content, which benefits from higher trust and less scrutiny by platform moderators and algorithms.

Why It Works

Older accounts tend to have more platform trust and less likelihood of being flagged as spam, increasing the chances that the post will be visible longer and gain organic engagement, which supports ranking.

When To Use

When using parasite SEO on platforms with active moderation and account-based trust systems such as Reddit, LinkedIn Pulse, and Medium. Particularly necessary for ongoing or repeated parasite SEO efforts.

Execution Steps

  • Create or obtain UGC platform accounts and maintain regular legitimate activity before attempting parasite SEO posts.
  • Focus on slowly building account age and credibility (posting non-promotional content, engaging with other users).
  • Use these aged accounts to post parasite SEO content with targeted keywords.
  • Avoid suspicious patterns like spamming multiple posts or frequent edits on new accounts.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Building aged accounts requires time and effort that immediate parasite SEO does not.
  • If the platform changes its rules or reduces the influence of account age, the benefit may diminish.
  • Doesn’t guarantee success without engagement and quality post content.

Example

Not explicitly mentioned but emphasized as a requirement for successful parasite SEO tactics on Reddit and similar platforms to avoid bans and maximize post visibility.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Keyword Integration in Post Titles and Content for Parasite SEO

What It Is

Placing exact target keywords prominently at the beginning of the post titles and repeatedly within the post body to maximize relevance signals to Google and platform search algorithms.

Why It Works

Google and platform internal search systems rank content higher when the keyword appears in key places like the title and early content, matching user intent signals precisely.

When To Use

Always use this strategy when creating parasite SEO content, especially in forums, subreddits, and UGC blog platforms. Particularly impactful for location-based and “best X” style queries.

Execution Steps

  • Choose a clear keyword phrase to target (e.g., “best interior designer Atlanta”).
  • Use the exact keyword phrase at the start of your post title.
  • Include the keyword naturally several times in the post content, especially near the beginning and end.
  • Avoid keyword stuffing; keep the content looking authentic and user-generated.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Over-optimization can trigger spam flags or make the post look artificial.
  • Using the same keyword excessively without engagement or support lowers effectiveness.
  • If the keyword is very competitive, may need additional tactics like backlinks or engagement manipulation.

Example

The Reddit post titled “Best interior designer Atlanta” with the same phrase in post content achieved rankings on Google and was further boosted by engagement tactics.

Note: The transcript primarily focused on parasite SEO tactics combining keyword targeting, engagement manipulation, aged accounts, and backlink purchasing for improved rankings on big UGC platforms. It also included warnings regarding risks and platform moderation. No other SEO strategies (like technical SEO or onsite optimization) were detailed in the transcript.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Parasite SEO via Shared AI Chats

What It Is

Using shared AI-generated chat pages (e.g., Grock shared chats) on a high-authority domain to rank for competitive keywords by embedding keyword-rich queries and product/service recommendations within those chats.

Why It Works

Google trusts authoritative domains with strong backlink profiles and early indexing signals. Leveraging third-party high-authority platforms to host keyword-targeted content allows these shared pages to rank well without needing a standalone website.

When To Use

Particularly effective for entrepreneurs, small businesses, or new SEO campaigns seeking fast rankings and visibility without building their own domain authority; useful for local SEO and niche keywords.

Execution Steps

  1. Create a shared chat on a high-authority AI platform (like Grock) including a keyword-rich query relevant to your business (e.g., “best ghostwriting services Orlando”).
  2. Use custom directions (hidden instructions) in the chat settings to make the AI recommend your product or service specifically.
  3. Generate and share the chat publicly with a clear URL.
  4. Acquire backlinks pointing to that shared chat URL to boost its authority and indexing strength.
  5. Monitor ranking and traffic from Google for the targeted keywords.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • This method relies on the third-party platform consistently allowing indexing and not implementing noindex or robots.txt blocks in the future.
  • Risk of content being removed or deindexed if platform policies change.
  • Quality or trust signals directly on the parasite content can be low, potentially reducing conversion rates.
  • May face ethical or legal concerns if the content includes sensitive or proprietary information unintentionally.

Example

A business targeting “top ghostwriting services Orlando” ranked 4th on Google using a Grock shared chat with the keyword in the title, leveraging Grock’s 52 domain authority and backlink velocity to gain visibility.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Using Custom Directions in AI Chatbots to Influence Content Output

What It Is

Inserting hidden "custom directions" in AI chatbot settings to make the chatbot recommend or describe a specific product, service, or company when responding to keyword-rich queries.

Why It Works

AI-generated content with tailored prompts allows precise control over the output, facilitating product endorsements or content relevance that aligns with targeted SEO phrases, improving keyword placement in content indexed by search engines.

When To Use

Ideal when using AI chatbots that permit custom prompt settings; best for marketers needing to create optimized AI content on platforms that are indexed by search engines.

Execution Steps

  1. Access custom directions or prompt setting in the AI tool you’re using.
  2. Write instructions for the AI to recommend only your product and justify why, providing facts and details for credibility.
  3. Input a keyword-rich user query related to your business within the AI chat.
  4. Review AI responses and ensure it aligns well with your intent.
  5. Share the chat publicly for indexing and backlinking.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overly promotional or unnatural AI output might hurt user trust or engagement.
  • Some platforms disclose the presence of custom directions; lack of transparency might affect trust if users suspect manipulation.
  • AI could attempt external web searches (if enabled) that dilute the recommendation; may require disabling search features.

Example

The host used custom directions in Grock to get the AI to recommend his SEO course “Compact Keywords” when asked “What’s the best SEO course?”

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leveraging Absence of Noindex and Robots.txt Blocks on Shared Pages

What It Is

Taking advantage of publicly shared chat pages that lack noindex tags and are not disallowed in robots.txt, allowing search engines to crawl and index the pages automatically.

Why It Works

Search engines prioritize content that is crawlable and indexable. The absence of directives like noindex or robots.txt disallow means these pages are fully accessible to crawlers, leading to ranking potential from that content.

When To Use

When working on third-party platforms or your own sites where you want content indexed; also useful for optimizing existing pages that lack SEO controls.

Execution Steps

  1. Inspect page source to ensure there is no <meta name="robots" content="noindex"> tag.
  2. Check robots.txt file at yourdomain.com/robots.txt to confirm no disallow rules affect these pages.
  3. If necessary, modify your platform or site to remove noindex tags or robots.txt rules blocking important pages.
  4. Publish keyword-rich, well-structured content on these pages.
  5. Encourage external backlinks to signal importance.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • If sharing sensitive or low-quality content, indexing might lead to privacy risks or brand damage.
  • A lack of canonical URLs or duplicate content issues may still hurt SEO effectiveness.
  • Indexing does not guarantee ranking; backlink and on-page relevance still matter.

Example

Grock’s shared chats have no noindex tags and no robots.txt blocks, which allowed Google to index over 15,000 keywords with 1.2 million clicks per month.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Building Backlinks to Shared AI Chat URLs

What It Is

Generating backlinks pointing directly to publicly shared AI chat pages to increase their authority and improve their likelihood of ranking well in search engine results.

Why It Works

Backlinks are a key ranking factor; they pass authority and trust signals to the indexed page. Linking to parasite pages hosted on high-authority domains increases their prominence in the eyes of search engines.

When To Use

When promoting shared AI chat pages or other “parasite” content hosted on third-party domains to boost organic search visibility quickly.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify the publicly shareable URL of the AI chat or parasite content.
  2. Create or acquire backlinks from relevant and authoritative sites pointing directly to that URL.
  3. Use diversified backlink sources (e.g., guest posts, PR, social sharing) to build link velocity.
  4. Monitor rankings and traffic for the shared chat URL.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Buying or building low-quality backlinks may lead to penalties or reduced effectiveness.
  • Backlink efforts can be nullified if the host platform disallows crawling or removes content.
  • May not work well for very competitive keywords without additional on-page relevance or signals.

Example

The host recommends buying backlinks to Grock shared chat URLs to improve positioning for target keywords.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Disabling Web Search in AI Chatbot to Control Content Output

What It Is

Turning off the AI chatbot’s connected web search feature to prevent it from pulling in external search results and ensure it responds solely based on custom directions or internal knowledge, thus providing controlled content output.

Why It Works

Web search integration can cause the AI to fetch generic or unintended information, diluting targeted promotional content. Disabling it forces the AI to generate content strictly within the scripted instructions, allowing better SEO-focused content creation.

When To Use

When creating SEO-optimized AI content needing consistent product or service recommendations without interference from live web data.

Execution Steps

  1. Access the AI chatbot settings.
  2. Turn off or disable the web search or browsing feature.
  3. Input your custom directions and queries.
  4. Review the response to confirm it aligns with your desired recommendation.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Disabling web search may reduce the AI’s ability to update responses with the latest data, potentially leading to outdated content.
  • Not all AI platforms offer this toggle, limiting applicability.

Example

The host had to disable Grock’s web search to prevent the AI from doing unrelated searches and to get a clean recommendation of his SEO course.

No unrelated points or generic commentary were included; all strategies derived directly from actionable tactics discussed in the transcript.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Cross-Page Reciprocal Backlinking

What It Is

A link exchange tactic where two different pages from two separate websites link to each other’s related but distinct content pages, passing link equity without reciprocal linking on the exact same page or to root domains.

Why It Works

It allows modest flow of PageRank and link authority between pages, reinforcing topical relevance through contextual anchor text and semantic signals, while also driving referral traffic and building genuine relationships. Search engines interpret these editorial links as votes of confidence, helping improve query relevance.

When To Use

Effective for blogs or websites in niche industries with complementary expertise, when authoritative backlinks are scarce, or as a last-resort link-building method alongside a diverse backlink profile.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify partner websites with related but non-identical topic pages.
  2. Draft content that references the partner’s article as supporting or extended reading.
  3. Insert a natural, contextually relevant link inside the content body with descriptive anchor text matching the target page’s focus.
  4. Provide the full HTML code for the backlink to your partner to minimize their effort.
  5. Ensure the partner reciprocates with a similar contextual link to a different page on your site, not the exact same page or root domain.
  6. Keep reciprocal link exchanges under a small percentage of your total outbound links.
  7. Use “rel=noopener” and “rel=noreferrer” for external links but avoid “rel=sponsored” or “rel=ugc” to maintain editorial link status.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Avoid automated or bulk reciprocal link exchanges and link rings to prevent Google penalties.
  • Do not place reciprocal links in sitewide footers or sidebars, as these appear manipulative.
  • Avoid paying for reciprocal links or making links a publication condition.
  • Do not forcibly insert unrelated keywords as anchor text, which can appear spammy.
  • Risky if overused—Google flags excessive reciprocal link patterns; always maintain majority one-way, editorial backlinks.
  • Uplift from reciprocal backlinks tends to be modest and depends on the authority of linking pages.

Example

Analysis of 100,000+ high-ranking pages by Ahrefs found nearly 50% involved at least one reciprocal domain-level backlink. Smaller tests showed a slight visibility improvement within weeks after adding a contextual reciprocal backlink.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Contextually Relevant, Natural Anchor Text Based on Search Console Data

What It Is

Crafting anchor text for backlinks that is contextually relevant and aligned with actual user queries, using real-world data from Google Search Console or Bing Webmaster Tools to guide keyword choices without forced or unnatural insertion.

Why It Works

Anchor text provides semantic signals that help search engines understand the topical relevance of the linked page and improve rankings for related queries. Using actual query data ensures the keywords chosen match what users search for and fit naturally within content.

When To Use

Useful in all SEO contexts where backlinks are being built, especially when aiming to boost rankings for targeted keywords in blog posts, articles, or ecommerce product pages.

Execution Steps

  1. Check your site’s query and keyword data in Google Search Console or Bing Webmaster Tools.
  2. Identify keywords or partial matches that your pages rank for or can realistically target.
  3. Write anchor text that naturally fits the sentence and aligns with these keywords without stuffing or forced insertion.
  4. Ensure surrounding content contextually supports the anchor text and target page’s topic.
  5. Avoid unrelated or generic phrases that don’t inform either users or search engines about the linked content.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Avoid inserting keywords randomly or without context, which can look manipulative and harm user experience.
  • Using only exact-match anchor text can lead to unnatural backlink profiles and potential algorithmic penalties.
  • Over-optimization of anchor text should be avoided; maintain diversity in anchor variations.

Example

The transcript notes that many backlinks use anchor texts unrelated to the linked page’s actual keywords, missing an opportunity for SEO benefit. Using search console data helps avoid this mistake.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Maintain Low Ratio of Reciprocal Links in Your Link Profile

What It Is

Limiting the percentage of reciprocal backlinks to a small minority of your total outbound links to avoid Google penalties and maintain a natural and authoritative backlink profile dominated by one-way editorial links.

Why It Works

Google’s algorithms detect manipulative link patterns, including excessive reciprocal link exchanges, often penalizing sites that rely heavily on them. Maintaining a natural ratio preserves link trustworthiness and ranking potential.

When To Use

Always applicable whenever reciprocal link building is practiced, especially for sites aiming to avoid link-related penalties and sustain long-term SEO health.

Execution Steps

  1. Track and audit your backlink profile regularly to identify reciprocal domains.
  2. Ensure reciprocal links represent only a few percent of outbound links (keeping forced exchanges well under ~5%).
  3. Focus on acquiring high-quality one-way editorial backlinks from trusted sources.
  4. If reciprocal links are identified, diversify link sources and reduce forced reciprocal link exchanges.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Relying heavily on reciprocal backlinks can prompt Google manual or algorithmic penalties.
  • Ignoring this practice can lead to ‘excessive reciprocal link’ patterns harming your site’s trust and rankings.
  • Difficult to recover from penalties caused by manipulative link schemes.

Example

The article references Google’s stance on excessive reciprocal patterns and advises keeping forced exchanges minimal.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Reciprocal Link Placement Within Content Body (Avoid Sitewide or Footer Links)

What It Is

Placing reciprocal backlinks only within the main content (editorial body) of a page or post, rather than in footers, sidebars, or sitewide link placements.

Why It Works

Google values editorial context and perceives links embedded in content as natural endorsements of relevance and quality, while sitewide or footer links are often flagged as manipulative or paid links.

When To Use

Especially relevant in bloggers’ outreach, content marketing, and editorial collaborations seeking SEO-friendly link placements.

Execution Steps

  1. Ensure reciprocal links are embedded directly into relevant paragraphs or sections discussing related topics.
  2. Provide descriptive, natural anchor text connected to the topic discussed in that section.
  3. Avoid placing reciprocal links in footers, sidebars, pop-ups, or any sitewide repeated areas.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Placing reciprocal links in footers or sidebars can trigger link schemes penalties.
  • Overusing sitewide reciprocal links can look manipulative and harm your link profile quality.
  • Guest posts or paid content with forced reciprocal links can violate Google guidelines.

Example

The transcript warns clearly to avoid sidebar or footer sitewide reciprocal links, recommending only editorial contextual links.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Provide Full HTML Link Code to Reciprocal Partners to Simplify Implementation

What It Is

Creating and sharing the complete backlink HTML code (anchor text + URL + attributes) with partners to streamline reciprocal backlink placement and reduce the chance of errors or effort avoidance.

Why It Works

Making it easy for link partners removes friction, increases the chance of them correctly placing the backlink, and ensures full control over anchor text and link attributes that affect page rank and semantic relevance.

When To Use

When collaborating on reciprocal link exchanges with partner sites, particularly if partners have limited time or technical know-how.

Execution Steps

  1. Write the desired anchor text and select the exact URL of the page to link to.
  2. Create the HTML link snippet, including “rel” attributes if needed (e.g., noopener, noreferrer).
  3. Send the full HTML snippet to your partner with clear instructions on placement.
  4. Follow up to confirm correct implementation on their site.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Partners may still ignore instructions or modify anchor text, lessening SEO value.
  • Over-standardizing links can look unnatural if overused or identical across many partners.
  • HTML link code won’t help if the partner refuses or the site is technically limited.

Example

The transcript highlights that providing partner sites the entire justified HTML code reduces their workload and improves uptake.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use rel=noopener and rel=noreferrer Attributes on Reciprocal Links

What It Is

Adding “rel=noopener” and “rel=noreferrer” attributes to hyperlink HTML when reciprocal links open in a new tab, helping secure the relationship without flagging the link as paid or user-generated content.

Why It Works

These attributes protect user security and privacy and signal to search engines that the link is editorial and not sponsored or user-generated, preserving SEO value while safely opening links in new tabs.

When To Use

When you want to open reciprocal backlinks in a new browser tab without risking Google penalties for paid or user-generated link schemes.

Execution Steps

  1. In your backlink HTML, add target="_blank" to open the link in a new tab.
  2. Append rel="noopener noreferrer" to the link tag.
  3. Avoid using rel="sponsored" or rel="ugc" as these imply non-editorial or paid links.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Omitting these attributes can cause security vulnerabilities (e.g., tabnabbing).
  • Using “sponsored” or “ugc” attributes for editorial reciprocal links reduces their PageRank flow and editorial value.

Example

The transcript advises using noopener and noreferrer but avoiding sponsored and ugc for reciprocal editorial links.

These six strategies encapsulate actionable SEO tactics extracted from the transcript regarding reciprocal backlinks and associated best practices.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Longer Title Tags

What It Is

Instead of limiting title tags to the traditional 60-character best practice, create significantly longer title tags (sometimes exceeding 200 characters) that include multiple relevant keywords and descriptive phrases.

Why It Works

Longer title tags provide Google with more context and keyword variations, helping the algorithm better understand your page content and matching it to a wider range of search intents. Google often rewrites title tags anyway, so giving it rich, relevant content increases the chance of improved rankings and visibility.

When To Use

Particularly effective for competitive queries, pages needing broad keyword coverage, and industries where additional context can differentiate pages; suited for ecommerce, service providers, enterprise sites, and any site testing SERP performance improvements.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify your target keyword(s) and related keyword variations.
  2. Write a descriptive title tag incorporating the target keyword, related keywords, benefits, and brand name, using vertical dividing lines “|” to separate ideas.
  3. Extend the title tag length well beyond 60 characters, aiming for 150-230+ characters if relevant and natural.
  4. Prioritize important keywords at the start of the title since Google truncates longer titles.
  5. Avoid unnatural keyword stuffing or repetitive phrasing.
  6. Implement the longer title tag on your page.
  7. Monitor rankings and click-through rates over time to evaluate the impact.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Avoid overstuffing keywords, which can appear unnatural and reduce click-through rate.
  • Not all industries or pages may benefit equally; benefits can vary.
  • Google may still truncate titles visibly, so placing the most important content first is vital.
  • Overly long and confusing titles can hurt user experience if they look spammy or unclear.

Example

A page with a 229-character title saw clicks steadily increase after implementation. A personal injury lawyer moved from position 6 to 4 for a target keyword using a 232-character title including an additional target keyword.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Start Title Tags With Target Keyword and Use Vertical Dividers

What It Is

Begin title tags with the primary target keyword followed by vertical divider bars (“|”) to separate the keyword from unique benefits and brand name to create clear, scannable, and informative title tags.

Why It Works

Starting with the target keyword ensures it’s visible despite truncation, aiding Google’s understanding and user recognition. Vertical dividers improve readability and allow users and Google to parse the title easily, increasing click-through rates.

When To Use

Effective for virtually all SEO scenarios, especially pages competing in crowded SERPs, service pages, product pages, and brand-driven content.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify your main target keyword.
  2. Construct the title starting with the keyword.
  3. Add a vertical divider bar “|” immediately after the keyword.
  4. Insert a unique benefit or differentiator offering a compelling reason to click.
  5. Add another vertical divider and conclude with your brand name.
  6. Review title length and ensure it reads naturally.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • If the brand name or benefit is too long, it may get truncated; this is acceptable as long as the main keyword and benefit appear upfront.
  • Avoid forcing unrelated benefits or overly salesy language that lowers trust.

Example

For the keyword “cloud-based sales recording software,” a title might be “Cloud-Based Sales Recording Software | Save Time & Boost Accuracy | Acme Corp.”

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Add Differentiating Benefits to Title Tags

What It Is

Include clear, unique selling points or benefits in title tags alongside keywords to give users a reason to choose your page over others in search results.

Why It Works

Highlighting unique benefits increases the perceived value and relevance of your listing, improving click-through rates and engagement signals that Google may reward.

When To Use

Particularly important in competitive niches where many pages target the same keyword; useful for service providers, ecommerce, SaaS products, and educational content.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify what sets your page or offering apart (speed, quality, free resources, guides, etc.).
  2. Summarize these benefits succinctly in 3–8 words.
  3. Insert benefits after your target keyword separated by vertical dividers in the title tag.
  4. Make sure benefits sound natural and avoid keyword stuffing.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overloading titles with benefits can make them unwieldy or spammy.
  • Benefits should be truthful and relevant; exaggerations harm credibility.

Example

Instead of “Free SKU Generator | Acme Corp,” better is “Free SKU Generator | Create SKUs On Demand | Easy Inventory Management | Acme Corp.”

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Avoid Keyword Stuffing in Long Title Tags

What It Is

While elongating title tags with more keywords, ensure the wording reads naturally without repeating the same or similar keywords excessively.

Why It Works

Google penalizes keyword stuffing as spammy behavior, and unnatural titles reduce user trust and click-through rates. Well-written, natural titles are preferred by users and the algorithm.

When To Use

Always, but especially when creating extended title tags with varied keyword coverage.

Execution Steps

  1. Review your proposed title tag for repeated keywords or unnatural phrasing.
  2. Replace repeated keywords with related terms or descriptive phrases.
  3. Use action-oriented language (e.g., “Learn how to...,” “Avoid these mistakes,” “Free guide”) instead of stuffing keywords.
  4. Read title out loud to check for natural flow and clarity.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Confusing Google’s contextual understanding by overusing variations can reduce effectiveness.
  • Keyword stuffing can trigger manual or algorithmic penalties.

Example

A skew generator page improved by changing from repeated “skew generator” mentions to “Create SKUs on demand” and “Effortlessly build SKUs” for more natural phrasing.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Test and Monitor Impact of Extended Title Tags

What It Is

Implement longer, keyword-rich title tags in controlled experiments and track their effects on rankings, impressions, clicks, and overall performance metrics.

Why It Works

SEO outcomes can vary by industry, page type, and keyword intent; testing ensures data-driven decisions avoiding wasted effort on ineffective tactics.

When To Use

Relevant for all sites looking to optimize titles beyond traditional best practices, especially for established sites with traffic data.

Execution Steps

  1. Benchmark current ranking, clicks, impressions, and CTR for the page.
  2. Create a longer title tag guided by previous strategies.
  3. Implement the new title.
  4. Monitor changes over at least several weeks.
  5. Compare pre- and post-implementation data to infer effects.
  6. Adjust accordingly or revert if negative impacts are observed.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Changes may take time to reflect; impatience can lead to misjudgment.
  • Multiple simultaneous SEO changes can confound attribution.

Example

After increasing a title tag from 57 to 197 characters, clicks showed a noticeable positive trend over several weeks.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Action-Oriented Language in Titles

What It Is

Incorporate verbs, calls-to-action, or educational language (“Learn how to,” “Avoid mistakes,” “Free guide”) in titles to engage users and clarify the value of the page.

Why It Works

Action-oriented titles promise immediate value and guide user expectations, improving click-through rates and user satisfaction signals to Google.

When To Use

Best for tutorials, guides, how-tos, educational content, and service pages where user intent includes learning or problem-solving.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify the main action or benefit you want users to take or learn about.
  2. Write portions of the title tag that explicitly state the action or offer guidance.
  3. Combine with your target keyword and separator bars for clarity.
  4. Ensure the title remains concise and natural sounding despite added language.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overly lengthy titles can dilute the action-oriented message.
  • Avoid vagueness or generic calls-to-action that don’t add specific value.

Example

For a page on AI agent building: “Learn How to Build AI Agents | Free Guide from Start to Finish | Avoid These 5 Mistakes | Acme Corp.”

These six strategies encapsulate every specific, actionable SEO tactic discussed in the podcast transcript related to title tag optimization and provide detailed usage guidance.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Niche Photo Link Building via Free Stock Photo Platforms

What It Is

Upload high-quality, unique photos related to your niche on free stock photo websites like Unsplash or Pixels, then request users who utilize your images to credit your website with backlinks.

Why It Works

Websites using your niche-relevant photos are likely in the same industry or topic area, increasing chances of natural, relevant backlinks; this also leverages user-generated content sharing behavior and the popularity of free stock images, enhancing backlink volume and authority.

When To Use

Effective for websites with visually-driven niches (e.g., travel, fashion, food, outdoor activities) seeking scalable link-building; applicable for small to medium businesses and content creators looking for organic backlinks.

Execution Steps

  1. Create or source high-quality, unique photos within your niche.
  2. Upload these images to free stock photo platforms (Unsplash, Pixels).
  3. Monitor usage of your photos via platform notifications (Unsplash alerts for Medium, Canva, etc.) and reverse image search tools (e.g., Google Reverse Image Search, TinEye).
  4. Compile a list of sites using your photos.
  5. Contact site owners with a polite, genuine message requesting a backlink to your site instead of the stock photo platform’s link.
  6. Optionally automate monitoring and outreach using AI or scripts for scale.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Conversion rates for backlink requests average around 5–7%, so patience and volume are needed.
  • Poor photo quality yields minimal backlinks.
  • Irrelevant or spammy sites may use photos, but you should only request backlinks from reputable, niche-related websites.
  • Overuse or black-hat tactics may trigger spam filters or damage reputation.

Example

Some photos reportedly generated 100 to 200 backlinks, helping sites rank on the first page for competitive keywords. More aggressive implementations have produced 1,000 to 2,000 backlinks.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Reverse Image Search Outreach for Backlink Acquisition

What It Is

Use reverse image search tools to identify websites using your images without proper credit or links, then reach out to request backlink attribution.

Why It Works

Many websites use images without backlinks; directly identifying and contacting them leverages relationship-building and compliance to earn backlinks, enhancing domain authority and search rankings.

When To Use

Useful for websites with proprietary visual assets, photographers, designers, and brands looking for incremental backlinks; suited for ongoing link-building campaigns.

Execution Steps

  1. Upload your images to stock platforms or use owned images on your site.
  2. Use Google Reverse Image Search or TinEye to find all occurrences of your images online.
  3. Filter results to identify those that do not link back to your site.
  4. Collect contact information for site owners or admins.
  5. Send polite, personalized outreach messages requesting backlink credit.
  6. Track responses and update your backlink profile accordingly.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Time-consuming without automation; low reply rates are common.
  • Some websites may intentionally avoid backlinks or ignore requests.
  • Outreach must be respectful to avoid being flagged as spam.

Example

Achieves about a 5–7% backlink conversion rate from outreach efforts.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Selective Link Request to High-Quality, Niche-Relevant Sites Only

What It Is

Focus backlink requests only on reputable sites relevant to your niche while ignoring unrelated or low-quality sites even if they use your content (e.g., photos).

Why It Works

Backlinks from authoritative, relevant sources have higher SEO value and avoid diluting domain authority or risking penalties related to spammy links.

When To Use

Best applied when dealing with wide content exposure where image or content use spans diverse sites; critical for maintaining link profile health in competitive industries.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify all sites using your content via notifications and reverse image searches.
  2. Assess site quality and topical relevance (domain authority, niche overlap).
  3. Send backlink requests only to those deemed high-quality and related.
  4. Avoid requesting links from spammy or irrelevant sites, leaving their credits pointing to original platforms (e.g., Unsplash).

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Ignoring links from small but potentially growing sites might miss opportunities.
  • Misjudging a site’s relevance or quality can waste outreach resources.

Example

Unsplash automatically links back to their site by default on low-quality users, protecting the photography site's reputation from bad backlinks.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Automating Link Building Outreach via AI Agents

What It Is

Employ AI-driven tools or scripts to monitor image usage and automate personalized outreach emails requesting backlinks.

Why It Works

Automation increases scale, efficiency, and consistency of backlink requests, which can significantly improve backlink acquisition rates without manual effort.

When To Use
