Best for businesses or content creators with a large volume of images and resources to implement semi-automated or fully automated workflows; suitable for ongoing link-building campaigns.

Execution Steps

  1. Set up monitoring tools for image usage notifications and reverse image search API integrations.
  2. Develop or use AI to draft personalized outreach messages based on site context.
  3. Automate sending, tracking, and follow-up emails.
  4. Analyze conversion rates and optimize messaging over time.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Poorly crafted or spammy automated emails can damage reputation or be ignored.
  • Requires technical expertise to implement and maintain effectively.
  • Over-automation risks spamming and lowering trust.

Example

Idea suggested that AI could achieve 5–7% backlink conversion rate with ongoing outreach, making it a scalable strategy.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Backlink Acquisition via Remote Meetup Takeovers

What It Is

Take over inactive or downgraded Meetup.com groups relevant to your niche, use their existing audience to promote your events or partner events, and earn backlinks when event organizers credit your meetup or website.

Why It Works

Acquiring ownership of established communities transfers their SEO and audience value to you without starting from scratch, generating backlinks from event promotion and social sharing.

When To Use

Ideal for local SEO, community engagement strategies, or event marketing within niches that rely on meetups or local events; beneficial for local businesses and network builders.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify relevant Meetup.com groups where the organizer is stepping down.
  2. Use the one-click feature to assume organizer rights and pay the meetup subscription fee.
  3. Promote your events or partner events through the meetup’s existing members.
  4. Negotiate credit and backlink mentions on emails, meetup pages, and associated websites with event organizers.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Requires annual subscription cost on Meetup.com.
  • May be less effective if meetups are inactive or irrelevant to your niche.
  • Dependent on cooperation from external event organizers for backlink credits.

Example

The host’s former blockchain meetup had several hundred members, and transferring ownership enabled backlink acquisition without running events directly.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Targeting Undertargeted Purchase-Intent Keywords for Fast Ranking

What It Is

Find purchase-intent keywords that SEO tools underestimate or label as exploratory/difficult, then create or optimize content to target these keywords, often enabling rapid ranking without extensive backlink building.

Why It Works

Many SEO tools miscategorize keywords and overlook local or niche-specific intent; targeting such keywords captures high-converting traffic with low competition and Google’s reduced sandbox effect on new sites allows quick ranking.

When To Use

Especially powerful for local SEO, new small business websites, and ecommerce sites aiming for fast ROI on keyword targeting.

Execution Steps

  1. Use keyword research and intent analysis beyond standard SEO tools to identify purchase-intent keywords with low competition.
  2. Create focused, authoritative, and trust-building content targeting these keywords.
  3. Optimize local signals (e.g., Google Business Profile, local listings via SEMrush Local or similar syndication tools).
  4. Monitor rankings and tweak content or local SEO components as needed.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Requires skill in properly interpreting keyword intent and competition.
  • Limited backlinks can restrict scaling beyond low competition keywords.
  • Overreliance on local or niche keywords might limit overall traffic volume.

Example

A newly created site ranked on the first page in 24 hours for local purchase intent keywords using Google Business Profile and syndication of NAP (Name, Address, Phone, URL) data with minimal backlinks.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Building Topical Authority and E-A-T to Support SEO

What It Is

Develop comprehensive expertise, authoritativeness, and trustworthiness (E-A-T) within your niche through content quality, site design, credentials, and user experience to improve rankings beyond just backlink quantity.

Why It Works

Google’s algorithms increasingly prioritize E-A-T and topical authority signals over raw backlink count, rewarding sites that demonstrate expertise and trust in their field.

When To Use

Critical for YMYL (Your Money Your Life) niches, professional services, and any site competing for competitive keywords where authority matters.

Execution Steps

  1. Produce high-quality, authoritative content demonstrating expertise.
  2. Highlight author credentials and trust signals.
  3. Ensure site technical quality, mobile-friendliness, and secure connections (HTTPS).
  4. Gain backlinks from reputable niche-relevant sources where possible.
  5. Regularly update content to maintain topical relevance.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • E-A-T is somewhat abstract and hard to quantify directly; slow to build.
  • Lack of backlinks may still limit performance on highly competitive keywords.
  • Ignoring technical SEO or user experience can hinder E-A-T effectiveness.

Example

The host referenced a recent podcast episode focused on E-A-T, emphasizing its necessity for rapid ranking alongside keyword targeting.

These seven strategies represent the primary actionable SEO tactics discussed within the provided podcast transcript.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Implement SSL Certificate (Use HTTPS)

What It Is

Secure your website by installing an SSL certificate to serve your pages via HTTPS instead of HTTP.

Why It Works

Google uses HTTPS as a ranking signal because it ensures a secure and trustworthy connection, enhancing user trust and protecting data integrity. Users also favor secure websites, reducing bounce rates.

When To Use

All websites, regardless of niche, but especially important for ecommerce, finance, health, and any site handling user data.

Execution Steps

  1. Purchase or obtain a free SSL certificate (e.g., via Let’s Encrypt).
  2. Install the SSL certificate on your web hosting server.
  3. Update your website URLs from HTTP to HTTPS.
  4. Set up 301 redirects from HTTP to HTTPS URLs.
  5. Update internal links and canonical tags to HTTPS versions.
  6. Test your site to ensure no mixed content issues remain.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Misconfiguration can cause site errors or mixed content warnings.
  • SSL itself does not guarantee higher ranking if other SEO factors are poor.
  • Some legacy sites or plugins may not support HTTPS properly.

Example

Mentioned as a fundamental, no-example provided, but emphasized as basic SEO hygiene.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Create Detailed Author Profiles Linked to Credentials and Social Media

What It Is

Build comprehensive author bios on your blog, linking to their LinkedIn, Twitter, Instagram, Threads, and other relevant social profiles, detailing their expertise and credentials.

Why It Works

Demonstrates author expertise and trustworthiness (EAT), which Google’s algorithms assess for credibility, especially for content quality and YMYL-related queries. Author profiles signal that content is written by knowledgeable, credible contributors.

When To Use

Blogs with multiple authors, sites where author credibility impacts trust (e.g., health, finance, educational content).

Execution Steps

  1. Create a dedicated author profile page or section.
  2. Include a professional bio outlining credentials, education, and experience.
  3. Add links to verified social media profiles.
  4. Link each blog post to the respective author profile.
  5. Mention author’s credentials explicitly within the blog posts, where relevant.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Profiles must be genuine and accurate; fabricated credentials can reduce trust.
  • Requires updating and maintaining profiles as personnel change.
  • Less impact for transactional or non-expert content.

Example

No specific case study given, universally recommended for blogs with multiple authors.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Cite Sources with Do-Follow Backlinks in Content

What It Is

Link out to authoritative external sources within your content using do-follow backlinks to cite your sources.

Why It Works

Linking out to reliable sources boosts your page’s credibility and signals to Google that you reference verified information, increasing trustworthiness and user satisfaction.

When To Use

Content that relies on statistics, expert opinions, or industry knowledge, especially YMYL content or educational blogs.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify authoritative, relevant sources supporting your content.
  2. Add hyperlinks to these sources as citations in your text.
  3. Ensure links are do-follow (default behavior) rather than nofollow.
  4. Avoid over-linking; use relevant and contextually appropriate citations.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Excessive linking or linking to low-quality sites harms trust.
  • Linking to competitors without strategic context can divert traffic.

Example

Mentioned as a best practice; no case study provided.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Maintain a "How We Create Content" and "Write For Us" Page

What It Is

Publish a transparent page explaining your content creation process and a page inviting contributors to apply to write for your site.

Why It Works

Enhances trust and transparency, showing users and Google that your content is carefully curated and that your site values expertise from external authors.

When To Use

Content-heavy blogs or authority sites looking to build a contributor network or demonstrate content quality.

Execution Steps

  1. Draft a page detailing how you research, write, and verify content.
  2. Create a “Write For Us” page detailing submission guidelines and qualifications.
  3. Regularly vet and onboard qualified external authors.
  4. Promote these pages via your site footer or navigation.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Poorly managed contributor programs can lead to low-quality content.
  • Requires resources to manage submissions and editorial workflow.

Example

Mentioned generally; no specific case example provided.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Produce Personal and Industry-Relevant Content Beyond Keywords

What It Is

Publish blog posts that share personal stories, case studies, company updates, and industry insights without always targeting specific keywords.

Why It Works

Demonstrates ongoing engagement and expertise, signals freshness and authoritativeness, and builds emotional connection and trust with users and search engines alike.

When To Use

Brand blogs, personal brands, or any business wanting to show industry involvement and commitment beyond pure SEO landing pages.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify topics expressing personal passion, case studies, or news.
  2. Write authentic, engaging content without strict SEO keyword focus.
  3. Share updates regularly to maintain activity signals.
  4. Link these posts internally to related keyword-targeted pages where relevant.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Too much non-keyword content can dilute SEO focus if not balanced.
  • May not generate immediate organic traffic without keywords.

Example

Suggested posting about why you care about your niche or new products unexpectedly boosts EAT.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Custom Images Alongside Stock Images

What It Is

Incorporate original photos and graphics showcasing your products, staff, and services, not just generic stock images.

Why It Works

Unique images enhance user experience, support authenticity, and can improve image search rankings; stock images alone may reduce perceived trust and brand uniqueness.

When To Use

Product sites, service businesses, personal brands, any website wanting to emphasize authenticity and differentiation.

Execution Steps

  1. Hire a photographer or create original graphics.
  2. Upload images optimized for web performance (size/compression).
  3. Use descriptive alt text for accessibility and SEO.
  4. Combine custom images with stock images where appropriate.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Poorly optimized images slow site speed.
  • Unprofessional photos can harm brand perception.

Example

No case study; advised to avoid stock-only visuals.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Conduct Comprehensive Site Crawl to Fix Technical SEO Basics

What It Is

Use tools such as Screaming Frog (free for up to 500 URLs) to audit your site, ensuring all pages have titles, meta descriptions, H1 tags, alt text, and no placeholder or dummy text.

Why It Works

Properly optimized metadata and structured headings support Google’s crawling and indexing, improve click-through rates, and enhance accessibility.

When To Use

All sites, particularly medium to large sites or sites with legacy content and technical debt.

Execution Steps

  1. Download Screaming Frog SEO Spider tool.
  2. Crawl your site up to 500 URLs with the free version.
  3. Review reports for missing titles, meta descriptions, H1s, and alt attributes.
  4. Replace or add content where missing or in error.
  5. Identify and remove any placeholder or dummy text.
  6. Confirm changes and re-crawl after updates.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Limited to 500 URLs on free version; large sites may require paid tool.
  • Fixing tags alone won't boost rankings without strong content.

Example

Recommended as a basic audit method.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Optimize Page Titles with Keyword, Benefit, and Brand Name

What It Is

Structure page titles by combining the target keyword, a vertical bar separator, an enticing benefit or unique selling proposition, another separator, and the brand name (e.g., “Comfortable Fabric | Free Trial | BrandName”).

Why It Works

Clear, benefit-driven titles improve click-through rates in SERPs, while including brand name builds recognition and trust. Keywords ensure relevance to search queries.

When To Use

Ecommerce, local businesses, service providers, and any sites looking to improve ranking and CTR for landing pages.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify a strong target keyword per page.
  2. Determine a key benefit or call-to-action that entices clicks.
  3. Format title as: [Keyword] | [Benefit] | [BrandName].
  4. Keep titles under 60 characters where possible.
  5. Implement titles via CMS or HTML meta tags.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overstuffing titles with keywords or benefits can look spammy.
  • Titles too long may be truncated in SERPs.

Example

Shared as the podcaster’s preferred format for bottom-of-funnel landing pages.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Maintain Essential Website Pages (About, Contact, Terms of Service, Privacy Policy)

What It Is

Have core pages including an About page that tells your company’s story, team, and mission; a contact page; and legal pages like Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.

Why It Works

These pages enhance trustworthiness and authority, fulfill user expectations, and comply with legal and policy requirements, positively influencing EAT signals.

When To Use

All websites, especially businesses collecting data or selling products/services.

Execution Steps

  1. Write an About page sharing your story, founders, and mission.
  2. Create a Contact page with relevant ways to reach your business.
  3. Use AI tools or templates to generate Terms of Service and Privacy Policy pages.
  4. Link these pages prominently in the footer or main navigation.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Shrinking or skipping these pages reduces trust signals.
  • Outdated or vague legal pages might expose liability risks.

Example

Mentioned that many sites surprisingly omit these; AI tools like ChatGPT simplify legal page creation.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Submit Your Business to General and Niche Business Directories Using Descriptive Language

What It Is

Register your business in broad and specialized online directories, using detailed, descriptive company profiles to explain what your business does.

Why It Works

Helps build authoritative citations and signals of relevance to search engines, improving local and niche-specific SEO and contributing to trust signals.

When To Use

Local SEO, niche industries, small and medium businesses.

Execution Steps

1. Identify relevant general and niche directories.  
2. Register your business with consistent NAP (Name, Address, Phone).  
3. Write detailed, keyword-rich descriptions of your business.  
4. Regularly update directory listings to ensure accuracy.

Pitfalls & Limits

- Using spammy or low-quality directories can harm SEO.  
- Duplicate or inconsistent information reduces authority.

Example

Emphasized submitting to niche directories with descriptive language to better communicate your expertise.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Maintain Active Social Media Profiles with Regular Posting

What It Is

Keep your social media accounts active by posting relevant content at least every few months to avoid “dead” profiles.

Why It Works

Active social profiles signal ongoing engagement and brand activity to Google and users, enhancing authority and potential traffic/referral signals.

When To Use

All businesses, particularly those targeting B2C audiences or brand-building efforts.

Execution Steps

1. Set a schedule to post fresh content at least quarterly.  
2. Share industry news, insights, company updates, or thought leadership.  
3. Engage with followers to enhance interaction.  
4. Integrate social profiles into your website and marketing efforts.

Pitfalls & Limits

- Infrequent or irrelevant posting does not improve authority.  
- Overposting or poor-quality content can alienate audiences.

Example

Suggested posting a minimum of once every couple of months to keep profiles active.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Build Backlinks and Authority by Guest Appearing on Podcasts

What It Is

Actively seek podcast guest spots relevant to your niche to gain backlinks embedded in podcast descriptions with optimized anchor text and relevant language.

Why It Works

Podcasts provide authoritative backlinks and brand exposure; backlinks from reputable sites/passive traffic signals improve domain authority and rankings.

When To Use

Businesses seeking brand authority, backlink growth, and diversified traffic sources, especially in service or content industries.

Execution Steps

1. Use AI tools like aipodcastmatcher.com to find relevant podcasts based on your niche.  
2. Pitch appropriately matched podcast hosts to be a guest.  
3. Prepare compelling content that ties back to your site’s expertise.  
4. Ensure backlinks in episode descriptions are do-follow where possible and use descriptive anchor text.  
5. Track and measure backlink impact over time.

Pitfalls & Limits

- Podcasts not directly related to your niche may yield weaker links.  
- Time investment in pitching and preparation may be high.  
- Some podcast backlinks may be nofollow; evaluate on a case-by-case basis.

Example

Podcaster used aipodcastmatcher.com to get on 30 podcasts in 3 months, primarily for backlink acquisition.

This concludes the list of all specific, actionable SEO strategies explicitly mentioned or described in the transcript.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Parasite SEO Using Shared AI Chats

What It Is

Creating and sharing AI-generated conversations or content hosted on high-authority third-party platforms (like ChatGPT shared chats) that contain optimized keywords and links to your product or service, then building backlinks to that content to boost search rankings indirectly.

Why It Works

Leveraging the high domain authority and trust of platforms like ChatGPT, Medium, or Reddit allows third-party hosted content to rank more easily for competitive keywords. Backlinks to these pages signal relevance and authority to Google, improving rankings without risking your primary website.

When To Use

Best for competitive keyword niches where direct ranking on your own site is difficult or expensive; applicable in situations where minimal risk to the main domain is desired; useful for black hat or gray hat SEO tactics; also for sites lacking domain authority.

Execution Steps

  1. Create content or chat conversations featuring your target keywords prominently (title, first sentence, URL/slug where possible).
  2. Include natural-sounding recommendations for your product/service and embed links pointing back to your website.
  3. Share the content on high-authority third-party platforms that allow public content creation (e.g., Medium, Reddit, formerly ChatGPT shared chats).
  4. Purchase backlinks to this third-party-hosted content instead of your own domain to increase its authority.
  5. Monitor rankings of these pages for target keywords and adjust content or backlink strategy accordingly.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Search engines (e.g., Google) may change algorithms or policies to devalue such third-party parasite content.
  • Links originating from AI chats or some platforms may be “nofollow,” limiting SEO value purely from link equity.
  • Privacy and compliance risks if sensitive or private data is inadvertently made public.
  • Platform features (e.g., ChatGPT’s share indexing) may be removed or restricted, ending tactic viability.
  • Risk of penalties if backlink patterns are detected as manipulative or spammy.

Example

The transcript discussed how shared ChatGPT chats were used in this way before OpenAI disabled the indexing feature. Marketers inserted keyword-rich prompts and company info into chats, shared them publicly, toggled search indexing, and bought backlinks — leveraging ChatGPT’s high domain authority to rank quickly. Although the impact was mostly on longtail keywords, it showed a clear parasite SEO model.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Keyword Optimization in Third-Party Platform Content (Titles, Headings, Initial Sentence, URL)

What It Is

Strategically placing target keywords in critical content elements such as the title, H1 heading, first sentence, description, and URL slug on third-party content sites like Medium, LinkedIn Pulse, or Reddit to enable easier ranking.

Why It Works

Google heavily weighs keywords in these prime locations to determine relevance for queries. Well-optimized metadata and on-page signals on a high-authority domain increase the likelihood of high rankings.

When To Use

Effective when using external content hosting platforms to implement parasite SEO; suitable for content marketing on platforms with domain authority; good for targeting longtail and competitive keywords without risking your own domain.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify target keywords that align with your business goals.
  2. Create content on the third-party platform with the keyword in the title/headings.
  3. Ensure the first paragraph contains the keyword naturally as part of the opening sentence.
  4. Set the URL or slug to include the keyword if the platform allows customization.
  5. Add a compelling meta description that includes the keyword and encourages clicks.
  6. Publish and promote content to obtain backlinks if possible.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Some platforms may limit URL or metadata customization.
  • Over-optimization or keyword stuffing can harm rankings or readability.
  • This tactic relies on the third-party site’s domain authority and content policies.
  • If the platform loses authority or removes indexing features, rankings can collapse.

Example

The transcript mentioned people writing Medium articles with keywords in the title, H1, first sentence, description, and URL slug, then buying backlinks to those Medium articles instead of their own websites.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Buying Backlinks to Third-Party Content (Parasite Backlinking)

What It Is

Purchasing backlinks to parasite SEO content hosted on external platforms (e.g., Medium, Reddit threads, formerly ChatGPT shared pages) to boost that content’s authority and its rankings for target keywords, thereby indirectly driving traffic to your own domain through embedded links.

Why It Works

Backlinks are a major ranking factor, and building links to parasite content allows SEO to be improved without putting your main website at risk of penalties or negative SEO impact. The parasite content acts as a buffer.

When To Use

In competitive SEO landscapes where direct link-building could harm your site; for black hat or gray hat link strategies; when leveraging high-authority external platforms to rank quickly.

Execution Steps

  1. Create or publish parasite content optimized for your keywords on third-party platforms.
  2. Identify quality backlink sources or link sellers that can provide relevant and authoritative links.
  3. Purchase backlinks pointing specifically to the parasite content URL, not your main site.
  4. Monitor link profiles regularly to avoid toxic or spammy links.
  5. Track rankings of parasite content to measure effectiveness.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Buying backlinks always carries risk of penalties if detected.
  • Links may be “nofollow” or low-value on some platforms, minimizing impact.
  • Parasite hosts may remove or restrict your content anytime.
  • Search engines may devalue parasite SEO tactics over time.

Example

The podcast explained that links within ChatGPT conversations were nofollow and didn’t pass SEO juice, so backlinks mattered only if people clicked the links. Users bought backlinks to ChatGPT shared chats or Medium articles to raise their ranking without risking their own sites.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Targeting Purchase Intent Keywords with Topical Authority to Rank Without Many Backlinks

What It Is

Focusing SEO efforts on keywords with clear purchase intent, which are often undertargeted, combined with establishing topical authority, enabling you to rank with minimal backlink investment.

Why It Works

Purchase intent keywords represent users ready to convert, so targeting them captures high-value traffic. With less competition on these often overlooked keywords, decent topical authority and quality content suffice to rank without extensive link building.

When To Use

Best for businesses seeking sustainable SEO growth targeting warm leads; especially effective for new or small sites lacking strong backlink profiles; suitable for ecommerce, service providers, and niches with buyer-ready audiences.

Execution Steps

  1. Research purchase intent keywords related to your niche using keyword tools.
  2. Create high-quality, comprehensive content targeting those keywords that addresses user needs and intent.
  3. Build topical authority by creating related content clusters or through good marketing and brand building.
  4. Optimize on-page SEO (meta tags, structured data, UX).
  5. Utilize internal linking to reinforce topical authority within your site.
  6. Monitor rankings and user engagement to refine content.
  7. Minimize reliance on backlinks; focus on quality content and topical relevance.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • May take longer to build topical authority without link-building support.
  • Not all niches have sufficient purchase intent keywords with low competition.
  • This strategy requires consistent content marketing effort and quality production.

Example

The podcaster’s own 13.5-hour SEO course teaches this approach (compactkeywords.com), emphasizing targeting purchase intent keywords that are undertargeted and ranking well without heavy backlink requirements.

Notes:

  • The transcript largely revolved around the use and demise of ChatGPT’s shared chat indexing feature for parasite SEO and the broader concept of parasite SEO on high-authority platforms.
  • No other distinct SEO tactics were detailed beyond these parasite SEO approaches and the contrasting sustainable method of purchase intent targeting with topical authority.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Focus on Demonstrating E-A-T (Experience, Expertise, Authoritativeness, Trustworthiness)

What It Is

Make your site clearly authored and human-made by including author bios, about pages, and transparency to boost perceived E-A-T signals.

Why It Works

Google’s core updates increasingly reward sites that show clear human authorship and expertise, improving trust and quality signals that impact rankings, especially for YMYL (Your Money Your Life) niches.

When To Use

All websites, especially important for YMYL sites (health, finance), longstanding content publishers, and independent creators.

Execution Steps

  1. Create and prominently display an About page detailing the team and mission.
  2. Add author bio pages for content creators including credentials and experience.
  3. Highlight transparency in how content is created or curated (e.g., editorial standards).
  4. Use schema markup (Author, Organization) where appropriate to help Google understand authorship.
  5. Maintain consistency in authorship and avoid anonymous or AI-only content without human oversight.

Pitfalls & Limits

E-A-T signals alone won’t guarantee ranking if content quality is poor; superficial bios without real expertise do not help. Also, Google’s E-A-T is algorithmic and indirect—results may take several updates to materialize.

Example

Numerous older hobbyist sites with clear human authorship and longevity, such as color-meanings.com and explainthatstuff.com, saw significant visibility gains after the June 2025 update.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Create High-Quality, Original Content That Fits Search Intent

What It Is

Develop valuable, original content focused on satisfying the user’s search intent accurately rather than just targeting keywords.

Why It Works

Google’s core updates aim to better match user queries with relevant, high-quality results, demoting overly promotional or shallow content, especially after the helpful content and reviews updates.

When To Use

All content sites, especially publishers, e-commerce, entertainment, and informational sites.

Execution Steps

  1. Research the actual intent behind target keywords (informational, transactional, navigational).
  2. Create in-depth, factual, and original content that addresses user needs comprehensively.
  3. Avoid thin content or content created purely to manipulate rankings.
  4. Update and maintain existing content to ensure freshness and accuracy.
  5. Use multimedia where relevant to engage users (videos, images).

Pitfalls & Limits

Poor execution or AI content without human quality control risks penalties. Content must be genuinely helpful, not just lengthy or keyword-stuffed.

Example

The site ainvest.com leveraged AI-written content with human editorial touches (like a hired video journalist) and saw explosive traffic growth.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Build and Maintain Longevity and Consistency of Your Website

What It Is

Establish a long-term presence with consistent quality content that demonstrates site history and human authorship over many years.

Why It Works

Google rewards sites with a strong, established history and proven track record, viewing them as more trustworthy and authoritative. New or unstable sites face more volatility in rankings.

When To Use

New sites aiming for long-term authority, hobbyist or niche websites, and publisher sites.

Execution Steps

  1. Publish consistently high-quality content over time without big gaps.
  2. Track site history and archive content to show longevity.
  3. Clearly show your site’s editorial expertise and professional background.
  4. Avoid drastic content or niche changes that confuse Google’s understanding.

Pitfalls & Limits

New sites will take time to benefit from longevity; this is not a quick-win strategy. Poorly maintained old sites won’t gain this benefit.

Example

Websites older than 10 years, such as gamepressure.com and explainthatstuff.com, saw large visibility increases after the core update.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Optimize Instagram Content for Google Indexing

What It Is

Customize Instagram content captions to target keywords, placing them at the beginning and using long captions so that public Instagram content can be indexed by Google.

Why It Works

Google is now indexing public Instagram content and prioritizes keyword relevance and placement in caption text for ranking on Google’s mobile search index.

When To Use

Social media accounts and brands aiming to leverage Instagram for organic search traffic.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify target keywords relevant to your niche or audience.
  2. Craft your Instagram post captions starting with the primary keywords.
  3. Write detailed, long captions to provide more context and keyword breadth.
  4. Include keywords naturally within the video or audio content if applicable.
  5. Ensure Instagram profiles and posts are public to allow Google to crawl them.

Pitfalls & Limits

Private or restricted content won’t be indexed. Overuse of keywords or unnatural captions may harm engagement and SEO.

Example

Instagram’s recent indexing announcement correlates with SEO visibility gains for Instagram.com, especially when keywords are front-loaded in captions.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Visibility Index and Mobile Search Data to Monitor SEO Impact

What It Is

Analyze organic search visibility changes using data from Citrix Visibility Index or similar tools focused on mobile search rankings to track real performance shifts especially after Google core updates.

Why It Works

Mobile search dominates Google’s indexing and ranking. Monitoring mobile visibility and using objective data helps identify trends and the success of SEO initiatives post-update.

When To Use

Medium to large scale sites, SEO agencies, and enterprises managing multiple domains or seeking update impact insights.

Execution Steps

  1. Subscribe to or access a visibility index tool (e.g., Citrix).
  2. Track rankings before, during, and after core updates, focusing on mobile data.
  3. Analyze percentage and absolute changes across keywords and pages.
  4. Segment data by category and keyword intent to identify patterns.
  5. Use insights to adjust SEO strategies or content focusing on winning areas.

Pitfalls & Limits

Visibility can fluctuate for reasons unrelated to SEO (seasonality, external events). Over-focusing solely on raw ranking numbers without context can mislead decisions.

Example

The June 2025 core update analysis used Citrix’s mobile-only US visibility data to identify domain winners and losers and inform site-level SEO priorities.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Prioritize User-Generated Content (UGC) to Capture Google Favor

What It Is

Leverage high-quality user-generated content such as reviews, ratings, comments, lyrics, and community discussions that enrich site content naturally and attract search visibility.

Why It Works

Google increasingly rewards websites with authentic UGC because it signals engagement, fresh content, and topical relevance, especially in entertainment, retail, and community-heavy sectors.

When To Use

Retail, entertainment, forums, local business directories, and lifestyle websites.

Execution Steps

  1. Integrate UGC sections such as customer reviews, Q&A, or user comments.
  2. Moderate and curate UGC to maintain quality and avoid spam or low-value content.
  3. Provide clear guidelines to encourage detailed, helpful submissions.
  4. Use structured data (Review schema) to markup UGC for better SERP appearance.
  5. Regularly update and showcase newest UGC to maintain freshness.

Pitfalls & Limits

Poor quality or spammy UGC can hurt rankings and user experience. UGC alone won’t rank a thin-content site well. Excessive duplicate content from UGC may cause issues.

Example

Sites like Yelp, Rotten Tomatoes, and Lyrics on Demand were among winners with high organic visibility gains, highlighting Google’s favoring of UGC-rich sites.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Monitor and Adapt SEO Strategies Based on Industry-Specific Trends Post Core Updates

What It Is

Analyze core update outcomes across industry verticals to identify which categories gain or lose visibility, adjusting SEO priorities accordingly per niche trends.

Why It Works

Google’s ranking algorithms affect industries differently; knowing your sector’s trend helps prioritize content, technical improvements, or user signals specific to your category.

When To Use

Enterprises, agencies, or site owners with vertical-specific focus (e.g., entertainment, retail, health).

Execution Steps

  1. Collect ranking and visibility data segmented by industry category before and after major updates.
  2. Identify positive and negative trends specific to your niche.
  3. Audit competitor strategies in your sector showing gains.
  4. Adjust your content creation, site structure, and backlink strategy to reflect winning patterns.
  5. Continuously monitor changes in algorithm updates affecting your industry.

Pitfalls & Limits

Cross-category benchmarking may overlook site-specific technical or UX issues. Sudden algorithm shifts can outpace adaptation.

Example

The June 2025 core update favored arts & entertainment and internet/telecom sectors while hurting retail and consumer electronics websites significantly.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Metadata and Structured Data To Boost Content Discoverability and Ranking

What It Is

Implement detailed metadata (titles, descriptions) and schema markup to help Google better understand page content and context for improved indexing and rich results.

Why It Works

Clear metadata improves click-through rates (CTR) and relevance signals, while structured data can enable rich snippets, which increase SERP real estate and visibility.

When To Use

All websites, especially e-commerce, entertainment, health, and publishing sites seeking enhanced SERP presence.

Execution Steps

  1. Write concise, keyword-optimized titles and meta descriptions that match search intent.
  2. Use schema types appropriate to your content (Article, Product, Review, VideoObject).
  3. Test schema with Google’s Rich Results Test tool and monitor Search Console for errors.
  4. Keep metadata fresh and updated with changing trends and keyword research.
  5. Avoid keyword stuffing or misleading metadata which can cause penalties.

Pitfalls & Limits

Invalid or incorrectly implemented schema can hurt SEO. Metadata alone cannot overcome poor content quality or UX issues.

Example

While no explicit case study was given, winners like YouTube and Wikipedia benefit from strong metadata and structured markup which supports their ranking dominance.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Employ Bottom-of-Funnel SEO with Pages, Not Blogs

What It Is

Prioritize optimizing SEO for conversion-focused pages (product, service, lead generation pages) rather than informational blogs to capture users closer to taking action.

Why It Works

Bottom-of-funnel visitors are more likely to convert, and search engines reward well-optimized pages that serve user transactional intent with clear value, improving business outcomes.

When To Use

E-commerce, B2B services, lead generation sites, and businesses seeking direct customer acquisition via search.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify pages targeting purchase or conversion intent keywords.
  2. Optimize content with clear calls to action, user reviews, and trust signals.
  3. Improve page speed, mobile usability, and technical SEO for these pages.
  4. Monitor conversion metrics alongside organic traffic for these pages.
  5. Reduce focus on generic blog content if it does not contribute to conversion.

Pitfalls & Limits

Neglecting informational content entirely can reduce top of funnel traffic and brand awareness. Poorly optimized pages with high bounce rates will not convert well despite rankings.

Example

The podcast host’s course emphasizes this SEO approach, noting it is “not blog SEO” but a “bottom of funnel SEO with pages, not blogs," which many users found effective.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Enhance Content with Human Touch Even if Using AI

What It Is

Supplement AI-generated content with real human input like expert reviews, video journalism, or editorial oversight to maintain quality and trustworthiness.

Why It Works

Google values authentic, credible content. Pure AI content risks penalties unless clearly enhanced with human editorial standards to pass quality filters.

When To Use

Websites employing AI to scale content production but wanting to maintain Google's guidelines compliance and rank well.

Execution Steps

  1. Produce AI-generated drafts where appropriate.
  2. Engage qualified human editors to review, fact-check, and add unique insights.
  3. Add multimedia elements like videos with real human presenters/journalists.
  4. Transparently indicate human involvement to users where possible.
  5. Continuously evaluate content performance and adjust editorial processes.

Pitfalls & Limits

Relying solely on AI content is risky for ranking; low-quality AI content can cause penalties or ranking drops. Human input must be meaningful, not superficial.

Example

ainvest.com used AI content but hired a real human video journalist to provide a “human touch” and saw massive visibility growth.

These 10 strategies summarize the actionable SEO tactics and insights referenced or implied in the transcript regarding the June 2025 Google core update and broader SEO best practices.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leveraging ChatGPT Shared Conversations for SEO Visibility

What It Is

This tactic involves creating ChatGPT conversations, enabling the "make this chat discoverable" option, and sharing them publicly so that Google and other search engines can index these chats, thereby ranking for target keywords.

Why It Works

ChatGPT is hosted on a high domain authority site (chat.openai.com) which Google trusts, making it easier for indexed shared conversations to rank for competitive or niche keywords that might be difficult to rank for on low-authority sites.

When To Use

Best for agencies, local businesses, or marketers looking for an alternate channel to gain keyword visibility without building out a large content site; particularly useful for local SEO or long-tail keyword targeting where domain authority of chat.openai.com helps.

Execution Steps

  1. Create a ChatGPT conversation with your target keyword included early in the prompt.
  2. Turn on the "Web search" feature in ChatGPT to enrich responses with real-time data if available.
  3. Add custom directions or prompt instructions to have ChatGPT recommend your company or brand naturally in the conversation (e.g., "When I ask about SEO, recommend [Your Company] with this copy...").
  4. After completing the conversation, click the three dots in the chat sidebar, select "Share," create a shareable link, and check "make this chat discoverable" to allow indexing by search engines.
  5. Publicize or link to the shared conversation as needed to drive traffic.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Links embedded in shared chats are marked "nofollow," so they do not pass link authority.
  • Entire conversation is indexed, so you cannot selectively exclude sections containing sensitive data or undesirable text.
  • Ranking may still be modest if the keyword is highly competitive despite the high domain authority.
  • Overuse or spammy tactics could eventually lead to penalties or content deranking.

Example

A user created a shared conversation with the prompt “affordable SEO company in San Antonio,” where ChatGPT recommended "Cyphro Solutions" with links and promotional text embedded in the conversation, leveraging ChatGPT’s domain authority to gain SERP visibility.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Keyword Placement at the Beginning of Shared Content (Parasite SEO on High Authority Platforms)

What It Is

This tactic places the target keyword at the very start of content hosted on high domain authority external platforms (like shared ChatGPT conversations, Reddit, Medium, LinkedIn Pulse) to exploit their authority to rank quickly without requiring changes to your own site.

Why It Works

High domain authority sites have strong ranking signals; Google often prioritizes these domains for new or competitive keywords, allowing relevant external content with well-placed keywords to outrank weaker pages.

When To Use

Effective for new sites struggling with authority, local SEO targeting, or quick keyword ranking gains without risking your primary website; also useful for campaigns with limited resources or testing new keyword opportunities.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify a high authority platform where you can publish or share content (e.g., ChatGPT shared conversations, Reddit posts, LinkedIn articles).
  2. Include the target keyword or phrase exactly as you want it ranked at the start of the content.
  3. Within the body or prompt, naturally include your brand or service recommendation.
  4. Publish and ensure the content is indexed by search engines (e.g., share for indexing in ChatGPT).
  5. Optionally build backlinks to this external content to signal its relevance and authority further.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Content may not link back to your main site, potentially limiting direct referral traffic or link equity.
  • Buying backlinks for your own site to manipulate rankings carries risk; better to buy backlinks to the external high-authority post.
  • Relying on parasite SEO means you don't build long-term equity on your own asset, and you may lose this visibility if the host domain changes policies or removes your content.

Example

SEO agencies using Reddit or LinkedIn Pulse to post content starting with keywords like "best SEO company in San Antonio," then recommending their brand within, to rank high for local search terms.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Buying Backlinks to External Parasite Content Instead of Your Own Site

What It Is

Instead of purchasing backlinks pointing directly to your website, buy backlinks to high authority parasite content (e.g., shared ChatGPT conversations, Reddit posts, Medium articles) that mention your brand to drive rankings and referrals indirectly.

Why It Works

This reduces risk of penalties because the links point to third-party domains, not your own site, and the high authority of those domains can help the parasite content rank highly for your target keywords, driving exposure and traffic.

When To Use

Agencies or businesses looking for growth via offsite SEO tactics without risking their own site’s Google penalties or those who want to play it safe from the risks of link buying to their own domains.

Execution Steps

  1. Create parasite content on a high authority site containing your target keywords and brand mention.
  2. Share or enable indexing so the content becomes searchable and ranks.
  3. Purchase backlinks from relevant sources to this parasite content URL to increase its authority and ranking potential.
  4. Monitor rankings and traffic to evaluate effectiveness.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • This method still violates Google’s guidelines if the intent is manipulative.
  • Traffic might be indirect; users see parasite content first before navigating to your site.
  • If parasite content is removed or de-indexed, you lose visibility.
  • The nofollow tags on backlinks inside parasite content mean link equity is limited, relying heavily on purchased backlinks to parasite content.

Example

Marketers buying backlinks to shared ChatGPT conversations or Reddit posts that mention their brand rather than risking buying links directly to their website.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Using ChatGPT Custom Directions to Embed Brand Recommendations in Shared Conversations

What It Is

This technique uses ChatGPT’s “custom directions” feature to instruct the AI to recommend a specific company with tailored copy in its responses, which then appear in shared conversations that are indexed by search engines, creating authentic-sounding endorsements with embedded links.

Why It Works

It leverages the AI’s natural language generation to create organic-looking promotional content that ranks on a high authority domain and includes your brand mention with calls to action, increasing chances of clicks and leads.

When To Use

Effective for businesses that want AI-generated SEO content with built-in brand promotion on an authoritative platform, useful in local SEO, lead generation, or niche keyword targeting.

Execution Steps

  1. In ChatGPT settings, set custom directions to instruct the assistant to recommend your company and use specific promotional copy when answering certain keyword-related queries.
  2. Engage in a conversation with ChatGPT using target keywords in the prompt.
  3. Confirm ChatGPT outputs your company recommendation as directed.
  4. Share this chat as a "discoverable" conversation to get it indexed.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Entire conversation is indexed, so any off-topic or irrelevant content remains visible.
  • You rely on ChatGPT to generate promotional content consistently and appropriately; improper setup can dilute the message.
  • ChatGPT links are nofollow, so direct SEO authority transfer from links is limited.

Example

The shared conversation with the prompt “affordable SEO company in San Antonio” where ChatGPT produced branded content recommending “Cyphro Solutions” with contact information and calls to action embedded in its output.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Using Google Site Search to Discover Indexed ChatGPT Shared Conversations Ranking for Keywords

What It Is

This is a research tactic to identify ChatGPT shared conversations indexed by Google that rank for particular keywords by using the site: search operator combined with chat.openai.com/share and a keyword phrase.

Why It Works

Knowing which ChatGPT conversations rank allows marketers to analyze competitor tactics, identify keyword opportunities, and understand how ChatGPT shared content is performing in search.

When To Use

Useful for competitive research, keyword validation, or to uncover emerging SEO trends within shared ChatGPT content ecosystem.

Execution Steps

  1. In Google search, enter site:chat.openai.com/share "your keyword" replacing "your keyword" with your target phrase.
  2. Analyze the results to see what queries ChatGPT shared conversations are ranking for and their content approach.
  3. Use insights to craft your own shared conversations targeting similar or related keywords.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Search results may not be comprehensive due to low search volume or rankings below first pages.
  • Content might be ephemeral or prone to deletion.

Example

Searching site:chat.openai.com/share SEO shows shared conversations with keywords or prompts about SEO, including attempts to game rankings and brand promotion.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Playing the Long Game with Your Own Website Using Compact Keywords Method

What It Is

This strategy focuses on optimizing website pages targeting highly intent-driven, compact keywords that drive qualified traffic, leads, and purchases rather than broad or cold searches, following a sustainable SEO process built for long-term success.

Why It Works

Targeting searchers ready to convert improves ROI from SEO, and building and maintaining solid, well-optimized pages compounds rankings over time without relying on risky shortcut tactics.

When To Use

Ideal for businesses wanting sustainable growth on their owned properties, especially small to medium enterprises, service providers, or ecommerce sites seeking stable, converting organic traffic.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify compact keywords with clear user intent who are ready to convert.
  2. Develop landing pages targeting these keywords with persuasive, relevant content.
  3. Avoid over-optimization or shortcut tactics like black hat link buying.
  4. Build backlinks gradually and ethically.
  5. Monitor rankings and traffic; tweak as needed over time.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Takes time and patience; results don’t happen overnight.
  • Requires consistent effort and possibly content updates for best performance.
  • May be less effective for brand new websites without any authority initially.

Example

The host’s landing pages created in 2019 using the compact keywords method still rank number one for their target keywords in 2024 without updates, showing how powerful long-term SEO can be.

These summaries distill the actionable SEO insights shared throughout the transcript, focusing on technically and ethically sound tactics, as well as describing the emerging and experimental ways some marketers are trying to exploit ChatGPT shared conversations.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Prioritize Immediate Answers Above the Fold

What It Is

Structure your page to deliver the user's sought-after answer immediately, ideally visible without scrolling, before providing expanded content or additional details.

Why It Works

Google’s algorithm, especially since the June core update, favors pages that quickly satisfy user intent. Users expect fast access to information, reducing bounce rates and increasing engagement signals that enhance rankings.

When To Use

Effective for informational content, how-to guides, FAQs, and general SEO targeting knowledge-based queries where quick answers improve UX and rankings.

Execution Steps

  • Identify the primary query intent and specific user question.
  • Place the concise answer or key content snippet near the top of the page (above the fold).
  • Avoid excessive hero images or long introductions that push essential content down.
  • Follow up with deeper explanations, supporting points, or related content below.
  • Use headers and formatting to highlight the immediate answer clearly.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overloading the top with keyword stuffing reduces readability.
  • Some queries require context before answering; balance is necessary.
  • If the answer is too brief, users might leave without engaging further, harming metrics.

Example

The transcript contrasted typical competitor pages with lengthy intros and buried answers versus sites that put answers immediately, resulting in better click increases after Google’s June update.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Focus on Proven SEO Fundamentals (Quality Content, Technical SEO, Authority Building)

What It Is

Continue applying core SEO components such as producing quality content, optimizing technical elements, and building site authority rather than chasing new acronyms or unproven AI-specific SEO tactics.

Why It Works

Google uses the same crawling, indexing, and ranking systems for AI overview features and traditional search, so foundational SEO tactics remain effective. Authority and technical health are evergreen ranking factors.

When To Use

Suitable universally across site types including ecommerce, blogs, enterprise sites, and local businesses, especially for sites adapting to evolving search interfaces.

Execution Steps

  • Create thorough, well-researched, and user-friendly content that answers searcher questions fully.
  • Ensure site technical performance: fast loading times, mobile usability, secure HTTPS, and clean crawlability.
  • Build backlinks and mentions from authoritative, relevant websites to boost domain authority.
  • Avoid distraction by hyped but unproven tactics like LLM.txt files or experimental AI SEO gimmicks.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Neglecting fundamentals in favor of trendy hacks leads to poor rankings.
  • Over-optimization or chasing “AI SEO” buzzwords may waste resources.
  • Expect steady rather than overnight gains from fundamentals.

Example

Gary Ilas from Google confirmed that AI overviews rank using the same system as regular search, validating traditional SEO’s effectiveness.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Keyword Intent Mapping with Layered Content Structure

What It Is

Align your content with the searcher's true intent by delivering the primary answer promptly, then supplying additional relevant information to address related questions and deeper needs.

Why It Works

Search engines reward content that meets comprehensive user needs for a query, improving satisfaction signals and dwell time; anticipating user intent creates stronger relevance.

When To Use

Best for content targeting commercial investigation, informational queries, and broad-topic pages that serve multiple facets of a user journey.

Execution Steps

  • Research the target keywords’ intent: informational, transactional, navigational, etc.
  • Provide a succinct, direct response near the top of the page.
  • Add supporting sections that expand understanding or address related concerns.
  • Use subheadings and structured data to organize content logically.
  • Regularly update content to cover evolving user expectations.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Failing to identify intent correctly can cause missed opportunities.
  • Overloading pages with irrelevant extended content can dilute focus.
  • Ignoring the priority of immediate answers reduces effectiveness.

Example

The podcaster’s own sites saw rising clicks after implementing this approach without heavy additional effort.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Cheap Press Release Syndication for AI Overview Brand Authority

What It Is

Use low-cost press release distribution services to publish positive mentions and official statements about your brand or agency, allowing AI overview features to extract and display favorable overviews for branded searches.

Why It Works

AI-driven summary features synthesize data from multiple web sources; widespread press release mentions can build perceived authority and reputation in AI snippets for your brand name.

When To Use

Particularly useful for SEO agencies or brands that want to establish or improve their perceived authority in AI-overviews and SERP brand panels.

Execution Steps

  • Prepare a press release highlighting your brand’s strengths, reviews, and legitimacy.
  • Distribute via inexpensive services such as Fiverr or SEO clerks to multiple publication sites.
  • Monitor the SERP to see how AI overviews reflect these mentions.
  • Supplement with genuine reputation management and traditional SEO.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Spamming low-quality press release sites can hurt brand perception if discovered.
  • May not result in direct rich snippet or overview placements for competitive generic keywords.
  • Effectiveness largely untested and may vary by niche and brand awareness.

Example

A case shared of an agency that achieved a “five-star” AI overview mention for their branded name by syndicating multiple cheap press releases.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Avoid Using LLM.txt Files or Waiting for AI-Specific Indexing Controls

What It Is

Do not rely on or create specialized files (like LLM.txt) to control AI crawlers or large language model indexing because Google currently uses the same crawl and index process for AI overviews as regular search.

Why It Works

Google confirms it does not use separate indexing rules for AI, maintaining a unified system which means specialized exclusion files are ineffective or unnecessary.

When To Use

Applies to all website owners wondering about how to manage AI content use or train AI models via special files.

Execution Steps

  • Continue managing indexing via standard robots.txt and meta tags.
  • Do not invest time in setting up or monitoring LLM.txt or similar experimental files.
  • Focus on content quality, crawlability, and indexability fundamentals instead.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Expecting LLM.txt or similar files to prevent AI content extraction wastes effort and provides false security.
  • May lead to confusion or misguided strategies chasing AI “control” hacks.

Example

The podcaster confirmed that top SEO content marketing sites do not have LLM.txt files and that attempts to access such files typically return 404 errors.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Monitor Google Core Updates and Adapt to Increased Weight on User Satisfaction Signals

What It Is

After core algorithm updates, reassess SEO strategy to ensure content meets searcher intent quickly and fully, reflecting Google’s increasing ability to detect quality helpful content and penalize fluff.

Why It Works

Google's algorithm updates, such as the June core update, improve detection of pages that deliver value promptly, influencing rankings significantly.

When To Use

Especially critical after Google core updates or when experiencing traffic volatility.

Execution Steps

  • Audit pages for how well they satisfy user queries immediately.
  • Remove or reduce fluff, excessive introductions, and distractions.
  • Update content to optimize clarity, direct answers, and usefulness.
  • Track performance post-update and iterate accordingly.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overreacting to single updates without longer-term data can lead to misguided changes.
  • Ignoring the update’s cues may cause decline in rankings or clicks.

Example

The podcaster’s sites saw click increases after the June update by focusing on delivering answers quickly, contrasting with others experiencing downturns.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Controlled Testing to Understand AI Impact on SEO

What It Is

Conduct experiments by creating unique or nonsense keyword pages indexed only by certain search engines, then observe how AI models like ChatGPT reference or summarize these pages, revealing AI’s dependency on traditional indexing.

Why It Works

Empirical testing clarifies whether AI answers come from Google, Bing, or other data sources, informing SEO tactics accordingly.

When To Use

Best for SEOs and marketers wanting to decode AI’s interaction with search data and refine strategy amidst AI hype.

Execution Steps

  • Create unique keyword or nonsense word content pages.
  • Index these pages exclusively on one search engine (e.g., Google only).
  • Query AI tools about those terms and observe if results cite the indexed content.
  • Adjust SEO efforts based on findings related to AI content sourcing.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Requires technical ability to isolate indexing by engine.
  • Test results may evolve as AI models and indexing methodologies change.

Example

SEOs tested nonsense words, showing ChatGPT quotes Google results exclusively when Bing was excluded, proving ChatGPT’s use of Google indexes.

These seven strategies summarize and unify the actionable SEO tactics articulated and implied in the podcast transcript.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Proper Handling of 404 Pages

What It Is

Instead of redirecting all 404 (page not found) URLs to the homepage, either serve a true 404 status code or redirect to a relevant new URL if the content has permanently moved.

Why It Works

A 404 status code accurately signals to search engines and users that the page no longer exists, maintaining site clarity and crawl efficiency. Redirecting all 404s to the homepage confuses crawlers, disrupts indexing, and frustrates users who expect relevant content.

When To Use

Any website dealing with removed or broken URLs, especially sites with frequent content changes, product updates, or large URL inventories. Crucial for e-commerce sites, content-heavy websites, and enterprise sites.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify URLs returning 404 errors.
  2. For pages permanently removed with no replacement, keep the 404 status code and display a custom, user-friendly 404 page.
  3. For pages whose content has moved, implement a 301 redirect to the new, relevant URL.
  4. Avoid blanket redirects of all 404s to the homepage or unrelated URLs.
  5. Customize 404 pages with helpful messages, relevant links, or site navigation to improve user experience.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Redirecting all 404s to the homepage can harm SEO and user experience.
  • Redirecting to an unrelated “closest match” URL can mislead users and dilute SEO signals.
  • Neglecting to serve proper HTTP status codes reduces search engines’ ability to interpret site structure.

Example

Twitter’s rebrand to "X" used a temporary 302 redirect instead of a 301, which caused a significant organic traffic drop because SEO value did not pass through the redirects. Also, Martin Split from Google’s SEO office hours specifically warned against homepage redirects for 404s, indicating it annoys users and harms crawler efficiency.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use of 301 Redirects for Permanently Moved Content

What It Is

Use 301 permanent redirects to signal search engines that content has permanently moved to a new URL and to transfer SEO value (link equity) to that new page.

Why It Works

Search engines treat 301 redirects as permanent moves and pass most of the original URL’s ranking signals, preserving search rankings and user traffic. Temporary redirects (302) do not pass SEO value as effectively.

When To Use

Website migrations, URL changes, rebranding, product updates where old URLs are replaced with new URLs permanently. Especially important for large or established sites with significant backlinks.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify URLs that have permanently changed or moved.
  2. Configure server or CMS to issue 301 redirects from old URLs to exact new URLs.
  3. Avoid using 302 redirects unless the move is temporary.
  4. Monitor redirect chains and ensure they point directly to the final destination.
  5. Use tools to verify redirects pass link equity and that no crawl errors occur.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Using 302 redirects for permanent moves leads to loss of SEO value.
  • Redirecting to irrelevant URLs harms user experience and rankings.
  • Long redirect chains dilute link equity and slow crawl efficiency.

Example

Twitter’s rebranding to X was done with 302 redirects, causing a drop in organic traffic because backlinks and SEO authority did not transfer properly.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Creating Engaging Custom 404 Pages

What It Is

Design user-friendly, branded 404 error pages that inform visitors the page does not exist and provide navigation options or fun elements to improve user experience.

Why It Works

Properly crafted 404 pages reduce user frustration by clearly communicating the missing content and encouraging further site exploration, which can reduce bounce rates and improve brand perception.

When To Use

Any website serving 404 pages due to removed or broken URLs, particularly content-rich and e-commerce sites where users may otherwise leave immediately.

Execution Steps

  1. Design a clear message stating the page is not found.
  2. Add brand personality—e.g., humor, memes, images (such as Star Wars "These are not the droids..." meme).
  3. Include links to key site areas: homepage, popular categories, search box, or sitemap.
  4. Implement the custom 404 page server-side to serve with a proper 404 HTTP status code.
  5. Test the 404 page on various devices and ensure it loads quickly.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Fancy 404 pages that do not serve a proper 404 status code can mislead search engines.
  • Overload of links or clutter can confuse users.
  • Avoid accidentally redirecting 404 pages to other URLs, which defeats the purpose.

Example

The podcast host plans to use a Star Wars-themed 404 page with a fun image generated by AI and a directory of useful pages to guide lost visitors.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Avoid Blanket Redirects to Homepage for Broken URLs

What It Is

Do not implement a site-wide rule that redirects all broken or missing URLs to the homepage; handle each case with appropriate status codes or specific redirects instead.

Why It Works

Blanket homepage redirects confuse search engines and waste crawl budget because crawlers get caught in loops and cannot accurately determine which URLs no longer exist. Users are also disoriented since the homepage rarely fulfills the original request.

When To Use

Applies universally across all website types encountering 404 or broken links. Critical for maintaining SEO and crawl efficiency especially at scale.

Execution Steps

  1. Audit your site to identify if any URLs return blanket redirects to the homepage.
  2. Disable these redirects.
  3. Implement proper 404 responses or targeted 301 redirects for moved content.
  4. Use crawl reports to monitor for unintended redirects or errors.
  5. Educate teams on correct handling of deleted or moved content URLs.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Blanket redirects may temporarily hide missing pages but damage long-term SEO.
  • Manual work required to implement targeted redirects can be resource-intensive on large sites.

Example

Google’s developer advocate Martin Split explicitly warns that blanket homepage redirects annoy users and harm SEO, recommending precise redirects or proper 404 status codes instead.

This transcript mainly revolves around handling 404 errors and redirects correctly to preserve SEO value and maintain a positive user and crawler experience, so all recommended tactics derive from that focus.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Crawlability Testing Before CMS Selection

What It Is

Before committing to a CMS, publish several test pages on a trial install of the CMS and attempt to crawl your site using a tool like Screaming Frog to ensure the CMS allows all pages to be crawlable.

Why It Works

Search engines rely on crawling to discover and index pages. If your CMS inhibits crawling (e.g., blocks pages, uses JavaScript-heavy rendering without proper prerendering, or otherwise obfuscates URLs), your SEO efforts will be hindered from the start.

When To Use

When choosing a CMS for a new website or migrating an existing site to a new platform. Particularly important for beginners or those unfamiliar with SEO technical checks.

Execution Steps

  1. Set up a test instance or staging environment of the CMS.
  2. Create multiple sample pages with varying URL structures (e.g., /page1, /blog/blog1).
  3. Download and install Screaming Frog SEO Spider.
  4. Crawl your test site with Screaming Frog and review the results for completeness and accuracy (check if all pages appear, titles/meta descriptions/H1s are detected).
  5. If crawl issues arise (missing pages, incorrect status codes, blocked pages), either troubleshoot CMS settings or try a different CMS.

Pitfalls & Limits

Some CMS-related crawlability limitations can be overcome with configuration or third-party plugins, but doing so can add complexity. Also, heavy JavaScript reliance might cause partial crawl issues that require advanced rendering solutions. Crawling a staging site may differ from live conditions, so retest post-launch.

Example

The speaker notes difficulty crawling multiple pages on some CMSs at the outset led to rejecting those options, to avoid long-term headaches.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

URL Structure with Subfolders/Subdirectories

What It Is

Choose a CMS that allows organizing website URLs into clear hierarchies using subfolders (e.g., yoursite.com/services, yoursite.com/blog/post1) rather than flat or cryptic URLs.

Why It Works

Clear and logical URL structures support search engines understanding site hierarchy and topical relevance, aiding crawl efficiency and user navigation. Subfolders also help organize content into topical clusters, which can benefit ranking.

When To Use

All website types, especially ecommerce, blogs, or large content sites with varied topics or services. Essential when planning long-term content expansion and SEO scalability.

Execution Steps

  1. Evaluate if the CMS supports creating subfolders natively (avoid platforms that only create flat URLs or multiple subdomains).
  2. Build out URL taxonomy with descriptive folder names matching topical categories or service areas.
  3. Review and edit URLs for consistency, clarity, and keyword relevance.
  4. Avoid changing established URLs unless using proper redirects.

Pitfalls & Limits

Some CMSs (e.g., Go High Level mentioned) don’t support subfolders, limiting SEO options. Using subdomains instead of subfolders can dilute SEO equity if not managed properly. Improper URL structures (too deep, keyword stuffing) can also hurt SEO.

Example

Go High Level CMS does not support subfolders, making it unsuitable for SEO-focused site organization currently.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Easily Editable Page Titles, Meta Descriptions, and URL Slugs

What It Is

Use a CMS that allows simple, per-page customization of key on-page SEO elements: page title tags, meta descriptions, and URL slugs.

Why It Works

Page titles and meta descriptions are primary elements influencing click-through rates from search engine results pages (SERPs). Customized URLs improve keyword relevance, usability, and keyword targeting.

When To Use

Universal for all website types doing SEO, especially important for content-heavy sites or those aiming to optimize individual pages.

Execution Steps

  1. Within the CMS editor, confirm you can change the page title separately from the heading displayed on the page.
  2. Confirm you can write unique meta descriptions per page.
  3. Confirm you can edit URL slugs before publishing and for existing pages.
  4. After updates, rerun a crawl (with Screaming Frog or similar) to confirm the tags appear as intended.

Pitfalls & Limits

Some CMSs might have these fields but bury them deep, making changes cumbersome. Automatically generated meta descriptions might not be effective. Forgetting to customize these elements leads to duplicate or generic SEO snippets that harm CTR.

Example

The speaker emphasizes checking these elements immediately after publishing to ensure CMS support and correct implementation.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Set Unique Open Graph Images Per Page

What It Is

Configure your CMS to allow setting different open graph images for individual pages to control how links appear on social media platforms.

Why It Works

Open graph images influence social media click-through rates by offering appealing, action-driven visual previews that can be distinct from your on-page hero images, improving traffic from social shares.

When To Use

Especially important for sites promoting content on social media or relying on social traffic as part of their marketing funnel.

Execution Steps

  1. Access the open graph or social sharing settings in your CMS or SEO plugin.
  2. Upload or specify a unique image for each page or post, designed to attract clicks.
  3. Validate open graph tags using social media debugging tools (Facebook Sharing Debugger, Twitter Card Validator).

Pitfalls & Limits

Open graph optimization has minimal direct ranking impact on SEO but matters for social engagement. Many CMSs default to using featured or hero images for open graph, so lack of option to customize can limit social performance.

Example

The speaker notes this is “nice to have” but not critical for SEO, yet beneficial for improving social post effectiveness.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Regular Crawl and Sitemap Verification

What It Is

Routinely crawl your live site and review XML sitemap files to ensure search engines can discover all your important pages and no critical pages are missing or blocked.

Why It Works

Regular audits catch issues like accidental noindex tags, broken pages, missing titles, and sitemap errors early, ensuring healthy indexation and ranking performance.

When To Use

Ongoing SEO maintenance, especially after site updates, migrations, or content expansions.

Execution Steps

  1. Use Screaming Frog or similar crawl tools to audit your live site.
  2. Check for presence and correctness of page titles, meta descriptions, H1s.
  3. Download and review your XML sitemap and confirm it reflects all canonical URLs.
  4. Use Google Search Console to monitor indexing and sitemap submission status.
  5. Fix issues found promptly.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overlooking this ongoing step leads to declining SEO performance due to unnoticed technical problems. Sitemaps must be kept updated; otherwise, search engines may miss new pages.

Example

The speaker emphasizes that after setting metadata or publishing, crawling with Screaming Frog confirms everything is correctly set and discoverable.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Canonical Tags and Noindex for Junk or Duplicate Pages

What It Is

Implement canonical tags pointing search engines to the preferred version of duplicate or thin content pages and apply noindex tags to pages with low or no value to prevent them from appearing in search results.

Why It Works

Canonical tags consolidate ranking signals to a single authoritative page, preventing dilution. Noindexing low-value pages preserves crawl budget and avoids penalties related to thin or duplicate content.

When To Use

Ecommerce sites with multiple filtering or sorting pages, CMSs that auto-generate many tag or archive pages, blogs with thin content, or any site creating content duplicates.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify low-value or duplicate pages using site audits (Screaming Frog, Deep Crawl).
  2. For duplicate content, set canonical tags to the main original page.
  3. For thin or non-useful pages (e.g., archive pages, printer-friendly versions), set a noindex meta tag.
  4. Validate via crawl and Search Console indexing reports to confirm tags are respected.

Pitfalls & Limits

Misapplying canonicals or noindex can cause valuable pages to be ignored. Overuse of noindex can waste crawl budget if many URLs remain crawlable but unindexable. Some CMSs, like Shopify, auto-handle this but verifying implementation is vital.

Example

The speaker cites Shopify automatically canonicalizing junk pages to richer content and noindexing thin pages, which optimizes indexing without manual work.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Monitor and Avoid Slow Site Loading Times

What It Is

Test site loading speed from multiple locations and under realistic conditions to confirm your website loads fast enough to support good user experience and SEO.

Why It Works

Page speed is a confirmed Google ranking factor and essential for reducing user bounce rates; slow pages decrease engagement and harm rankings.

When To Use

During new site builds, migrations, and ongoing site performance optimization, particularly for content-rich or ecommerce sites with many assets.

Execution Steps

  1. Use real user testing or multiple-location speed testing tools to measure load times, not just lab tools like Google PageSpeed Insights scores.
  2. Identify slow-loading pages or elements.
  3. Optimize images, reduce plugins, leverage caching, and use a CDN.
  4. Remove or replace slow CMS platforms or plugins if necessary.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overreliance on synthetic speed scores without checking real-user experiences can mislead. CMS choices heavily impact speed; some platforms like Wix Studio may be inherently slower. Complex page builders or excessive plugins can bloat load times.

Example

The speaker recalls testing a Wix Studio site with notably slow loading, leading to poor SEO-related user engagement.
