  • Does not replace the need for technical SEO or content optimization.

Example

SEO subreddit users emphasized the importance of building lasting brands to avoid invisibility as AI-based responses filter out unverified or blocked content.

Note: The transcript largely focuses on Cloudflare’s new AI crawler restrictions and monetization models as strategic moves to protect original content, maintain revenue, and enable site owners to control AI access. The above strategies encapsulate actionable tactics arising from this new ecosystem shift.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Optimize Instagram Captions with Target Keywords
What It Is: Writing Instagram post captions that start with a specific, researched target keyword followed by a detailed description that supports that keyword.
Why It Works: Search engines use captions to understand Instagram content context and relevance; placing a clear keyword at the beginning signals strong topical relevance, improving ranking. Detailed descriptions improve semantic understanding and prevent keyword stuffing penalties.
When To Use: Effective for businesses, creators, and brands with Instagram profiles aiming to increase organic visibility on Google, especially after July 2025 when Instagram content will be more widely surfaced. Ideal for local, ecommerce, and personal branding SEO.
Execution Steps:

  1. Research relevant, high-intent keywords your audience searches for.
  2. Begin your Instagram caption with the primary target keyword prominently.
  3. Write a detailed, natural-sounding description that explains or supports the content without keyword stuffing.
  4. For text carousels, use the carousel text as the caption body. For video reels with voice, include the video transcript after the keyword.
  5. Avoid generic hashtag dumping or brief captions; focus on meaningful descriptions.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Overusing keywords or writing too brief captions reduces effectiveness. Without engagement or follower signals, ranking may remain limited. Also, uncertainty exists if personal (non-professional) accounts will rank equally well.
    Example: The podcast host describes ranking Instagram reels the day after uploading captions with targeted keywords, demonstrating rapid ranking potential from well-optimized captions.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Enable Instagram’s Search Engine Visibility Setting
What It Is: Activating the Instagram setting that allows public photos and videos to appear in search engine results.
Why It Works: Instagram has announced and begun allowing search engines automatic rights to index and display user content. Enabling this setting allows Google and others to crawl and rank your content, increasing organic reach.
When To Use: All Instagram business or creator accounts seeking enhanced organic discovery and traffic from Google search results. Particularly relevant from July 10, 2025, onwards per Instagram’s announced policy change.
Execution Steps:

  1. Open Instagram app.
  2. Navigate to Settings > Activity > Account Privacy.
  3. Locate the setting labeled “Allow public photos and videos to appear in search engine results.”
  4. Toggle this option ON.
    Pitfalls & Limits: If privacy or brand restrictions require content not to appear in search, enabling this setting is inappropriate. Personal accounts or those without professional profiles may have reduced indexing or ranking benefits.
    Example: The podcast host received this notification in-app less than 2 weeks after Reddit’s massive Google traffic boost, signaling the importance and timeliness of enabling this feature.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Leverage Text Carousels on Instagram for SEO
What It Is: Creating Instagram carousel posts that feature multiple text slides (informational content) designed to rank on Google through Instagram’s search presence.
Why It Works: Text carousels resemble mini-blog posts or informational pages, which search engines can parse to understand topical relevance. Because Instagram is already the fourth most clicked site from Google, this approach leverages that traffic channel efficiently.
When To Use: Brands and creators who prefer not to use video content or personal photos but want to establish thought leadership, educate their audience, or rank informational keywords on Instagram. Also applicable for rapid content production versus traditional blog posts.
Execution Steps:

  1. Identify content topics and target keywords.
  2. Create multiple Instagram carousel slides containing well-structured text content, similar to a blog post outline or step-by-step instructions.
  3. Use the text from the carousel as extended Instagram caption content, starting with the target keyword as the first phrase.
  4. Publish and promote the carousel to generate engagement.
  5. Optionally, repurpose website content into shortened carousel text for multi-channel keyword targeting.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Carousel text must be clear and readable on mobile; excessive text or poor design may reduce engagement. Rankings also depend on profile authority and post engagement. This strategy may not replace long-form SEO content but supplements it.
    Example: The podcast cites Instagram biohacking influencer Brian Johnson and others who regularly use text carousels to achieve viral reach and appear in search results.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Build Instagram Profile Authority for SEO
What It Is: Developing an Instagram profile’s credibility and authority through consistent content, follower growth, engagement, and link building to improve search rankings.
Why It Works: Search engines favor profiles with demonstrated authority and a history of satisfying user intent, similar to website SEO. More authoritative profiles get higher visibility in search results.
When To Use: All levels of Instagram users who want organic discovery on Google, including businesses, creators, and enterprises seeking to extend their brand presence across multiple channels.
Execution Steps:

  1. Consistently publish high-quality, targeted content that satisfies audience intent.
  2. Engage actively with your followers to boost content interactions (likes, comments, shares).
  3. Grow your follower base organically or through strategic collaborations.
  4. Submit your Instagram profile link to reputable directories and local business listings to build backlinks.
  5. Maintain a professional or creator account to access advanced insights and features.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Artificially inflating followers or engagement may not yield real SEO benefits. Neglecting content quality reduces authority. Link building should be natural to avoid spam penalties.
    Example: The host compares Instagram SEO to traditional website SEO authority building and recommends submitting Instagram profiles to directories as a form of building relevant links.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Target Multiple Channels with the Same Keyword
What It Is: Coordinating keyword targeting across your website and social media accounts (Instagram in particular) to dominate search engine results for your brand’s target keywords without cannibalization.
Why It Works: Multiple ranking assets for the same keyword from one brand provide stronger brand signals and increase chances of occupying top search positions for a given keyword. This holistic approach amplifies overall visibility.
When To Use: Businesses and individuals with both websites and active social profiles seeking comprehensive SEO presence. Especially effective for mid-to-large brands or those with adequate content creation resources.
Execution Steps:

  1. Identify priority keywords to target.
  2. Create long-form content on your website centered around those keywords.
  3. Simultaneously create Instagram content (posts, reels, carousels) targeting the same keywords with optimized captions.
  4. Ensure content on each platform complements rather than duplicates—e.g., shorter, snackable Instagram carousel summarizing website content.
  5. Monitor performance on Google for each asset and adjust content as needed.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Poor coordination may cause keyword cannibalization or confusing signals. Repetitive identical content across platforms might dilute performance. This requires ongoing content planning and monitoring.
    Example: The host uses this method to target tens or hundreds of thousands of keywords with Instagram alongside a website, increasing overall market share and search dominance.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Prioritize Post Recency and Engagement on Instagram for SEO
What It Is: Publishing new Instagram posts regularly and encouraging user engagement to improve ranking signals in Google search results.
Why It Works: Google favors fresh, active content and user engagement as signals of relevance and quality, which increases likelihood of ranking higher and appearing in rich results or featured snippets.
When To Use: Brands/creators active on Instagram wanting to maintain or improve search visibility, particularly for news, trends, or rapidly evolving niches.
Execution Steps:

  1. Publish Instagram content frequently, focusing on topical or trending keywords.
  2. Promote interactions such as comments, shares, and likes through calls to action or community engagement.
  3. Track engagement metrics and adjust timing/content to maximize interaction.
  4. Combine recency with well-optimized captions and keyword targeting.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Content without genuine engagement may fail to rank well regardless of recency. Overposting low-value content can damage brand reputation. Recency alone is not sufficient; quality and relevance remain critical.
    Example: The podcast host reports seeing recency and engagement as strong ranking factors on Instagram posts appearing in Google search results.

These 6 strategies encapsulate all actionable SEO tactics shared in the podcast transcript, focusing on how to leverage Instagram and Google search realignment post-June 2023 core update and Instagram’s July 2025 search engine policy change.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leveraging Clickstream Data for SEO Insights

What It Is

Utilizing large-scale anonymized user clickstream data—which tracks users’ online browsing and search activities—to identify trending topics, emerging brands, and user behaviors that inform SEO strategies.

Why It Works

Clickstream data provides quantitative, real-world evidence of what people search for, visit, and engage with, allowing marketers to spot patterns and opportunities well before they become mainstream. It bypasses guesswork by relying on actual user behavior rather than assumptions.

When To Use

Enterprise SEO, competitive analysis, product launch planning, content strategy development, market research, and identifying rising trends for early content targeting.

Execution Steps

  1. Obtain access to reliable clickstream data from providers like Datos or similar vendors with large and diverse user panels.
  2. Analyze emerging search terms, website visitation patterns, and user traversal paths to identify rising interests or brands.
  3. Segment data by behaviors (e.g., purchase intent keywords vs. informational) and demographic signals if available (age/gender inferred by behavior).
  4. Map these patterns to SEO content and campaign strategies that align with emerging or growing user interests.
  5. Continuously update and refine using fresh clickstream data to capture ongoing shifts.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Clickstream data can be expensive and complex to analyze; requires expertise in data science and interpretation.
  • Privacy constraints mean individual-level data is unavailable; insights are aggregate and behavioral rather than personal.
  • Not all providers have the same scale or quality; small panels or biased samples can skew insights.
  • Data must be correctly interpreted to differentiate causation vs. correlation.

Example

Early identification of Pinterest’s rise by observing increased visits and engagement from a specific demographic (scrapbooking women in the Midwest and South US) gave advanced insight into a brand-new social platform before it became mainstream.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Compact Keywords SEO Funnel for Higher Conversion

What It Is

Building dozens of short, focused pages (around 400 words each) targeting narrowly defined transactional or buying-intent keywords, rather than big, broad informational articles, to rank better and convert more effectively.

Why It Works

These pages align precisely with what buyers are searching for, making them more likely to rank and convert since they meet intent directly. Short, focused content reduces excess information that might dilute conversion potential.

When To Use

Ecommerce sites, local businesses, new product launches, and any scenario where direct sales via SEO are the primary concern. Particularly useful for small to medium businesses that want results faster with less content creation effort.

Execution Steps

  1. Conduct keyword research focused on transactional intent keywords with clear purchase signals.
  2. Create multiple landing pages, each targeting a specific compact keyword phrase. Keep content concise (approximately 400-450 words).
  3. Ensure each page has clear calls-to-action and conversion elements (purchase buttons, lead capture forms).
  4. Use AI tools to assist in streamlining repetitive tasks in content creation while maintaining human oversight for quality.
  5. Monitor rankings and conversion metrics; refine content and keywords based on performance data.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overdoing short pages can lead to thin content issues if quality is compromised.
  • Not effective for branding or awareness-focused marketing; better for direct response.
  • Requires careful keyword selection to avoid cannibalization or keyword stuffing.

Example

The podcast mentioned a course called “Compact Keywords” that teaches this approach, stating it is less work than traditional SEO, works well with AI, and produces higher sales funnel conversions.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Optimize for Zero-Click Searches and AI Overviews

What It Is

Adjusting SEO success metrics and strategies to align with the increasing prevalence of zero-click search results, where users get answers directly on the SERP without clicking through to a website.

Why It Works

Google and AI engines provide direct answers to many informational queries, reducing referral traffic but still offering brand visibility and indirect value through citations and brand awareness, which eventually drive sales and engagement.

When To Use

Content sites, educational and informational publishers, brands focusing on awareness and authority, and ecommerce sites prioritizing long-term relationship building.

Execution Steps

  1. Audit current high impression but low click keywords for zero-click intent.
  2. Create content designed to be the source for featured snippets, knowledge panels, and AI-generated answers by structuring data and clarity of content.
  3. Track brand mentions and indirect conversions from visibility rather than just clicks.
  4. Advocate for a broader success metric framework beyond clicks (e.g., assisted conversions, brand lift, offline sales).
  5. Invest in content quality and topical authority to remain eligible for AI overviews and rich results.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Reduced referral traffic can lead to misinterpretation of SEO effectiveness if only clicks are measured.
  • Over-optimization for snippets can cause content to be “borrowed” by Google minimizing direct visits.
  • This strategy is less effective for direct sales-driven sites that rely solely on click-through traffic.

Example

Semrush and others found AI overviews reduce clicks by 30+%, yet users who see AI overviews tend to perform more searches over time, suggesting a legacy or nonlinear impact on user behavior.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Segment and Contextual Targeting Over Individual User Targeting

What It Is

Focus SEO and marketing efforts on broad user behavior patterns, segments, and contextual relevance rather than micro-targeting individuals, particularly in a privacy-compliant way using aggregate data.

Why It Works

Due to growing privacy regulations and the phasing out of third-party cookies, segment and context-based tactics are more sustainable long-term and can still reach the right audience effectively by matching their intent and contextual behavior patterns.

When To Use

All SEO and digital marketing contexts facing compliance or targeting challenges—especially enterprise, local SEO, and ecommerce looking for privacy-safe strategies.

Execution Steps

  1. Define relevant audience segments based on behavior, search intent, and aggregated demographic signals.
  2. Create content and campaigns optimized for the common intents and needs of these segments instead of individual profiles.
  3. Use aggregated clickstream data and privacy-safe analytics to validate and adjust segments regularly.
  4. Implement contextual ad targeting and SEO content alignment based on these segments.
  5. Ensure compliance with privacy laws and remove identification of individuals in data modeling.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Less precise than individual targeting, so campaigns might feel less personalized.
  • Requires sufficient data volume to make statistically significant segmentations.
  • Segments must be thoughtfully constructed to avoid overgeneralization.

Example

Datos specializes in “mile-wide, inch-deep” data, focusing on collective behaviors rather than individuals, which results in better long-term and privacy-compliant targeting.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Utilize AI Tools to Identify Patterns in Large Data Sets for SEO

What It Is

Employ AI and machine learning to analyze vast datasets (like clickstream data) to uncover hidden or non-obvious trends, search intent nuances, and ranking opportunities that manual analysis might miss.

Why It Works

AI excels at pattern recognition in large, complex datasets, helping marketers predict shifts and optimize strategies faster and more accurately. It supports forward-looking SEO planning rather than reactive.

When To Use

Enterprise SEO, sites with large content inventories, competitive intelligence, AI-focused marketing, and agencies managing multiple clients.

Execution Steps

  1. Gather large-scale behavioral and search data relevant to your niche or vertical.
  2. Deploy AI tools or partner with AI analytics providers capable of natural language processing and predictive modeling.
  3. Interpret AI insights to refine keyword targeting, topical clusters, and user intent mapping.
  4. Integrate findings into content creation and technical SEO prioritization.
  5. Monitor AI recommendations against real-world performance to iteratively optimize.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • AI output depends on data quality; garbage in, garbage out.
  • Without domain expertise, AI insights may be misunderstood or misapplied.
  • Overreliance on AI without human judgment can cause errors.

Example

Datos emphasizes using AI on anonymized clickstream data to predict trends like company earnings or emerging online behaviors, enabling clients to act ahead of competitors.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Track and Target Navigational and Transactional Search Intent Separately

What It Is

Differentiate SEO content and optimization efforts between navigational searches (users looking for a specific brand or site) and transactional searches (users looking to buy or convert) to tailor content strategy accordingly.

Why It Works

Navigational searches often yield direct visits with known destination intent, while transactional searches have immediate purchase intent; optimizing separately allows better user satisfaction and increases conversion rates.

When To Use

Ecommerce, brand marketing, local business SEO, and marketplaces.

Execution Steps

  1. Use keyword intent modeling to categorize keywords as navigational, transactional, or informational.
  2. For navigational intent, optimize brand SERPs, ensure accurate site links, and nurture branded content.
  3. For transactional intent, develop landing pages focused on buying signals with clear CTAs.
  4. Monitor search volume shifts between both types and adjust budget and focus accordingly.
  5. Enhance user experience to reduce friction from search to conversion.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Confusing informational content with transactional can dilute conversion rates.
  • Overemphasis on navigational intent might neglect new customer acquisition.
  • Intent can evolve; constant monitoring is required.

Example

The podcast notes that a large portion of Google searches are navigational (e.g., typing Amazon or Nike), reflecting entrenched user behaviors often overlooked by marketers focusing only on informational or transactional queries.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Prioritize Long-Term SEO Impact Over Immediate Click Metrics

What It Is

Shift SEO success measurement from immediate referral clicks to a longer-term view of user engagement and eventual conversions, recognizing that AI search and zero-click SERPs may reduce direct clicks but still generate brand awareness and downstream sales.

Why It Works

User decision journeys can be nonlinear and delayed; early exposure via AI answers or zero-click results can stimulate more searches and purchases later, which traditional last-click metrics miss.

When To Use

Brand marketing, content marketing, enterprise SEO, awareness campaigns, and publishers adapting to SERP feature changes.

Execution Steps

  1. Implement multi-touch attribution models that track assisted conversions and brand exposure impact.
  2. Use analytics tools capable of modeling nonlinear customer journeys and legacy traffic impact.
  3. Adjust internal KPIs to include measures like brand uplift, direct traffic increases, and repeat search behavior.
  4. Communicate these changes to stakeholders to reset expectations on decreased referral traffic but sustained or growing conversions.
  5. Continually gather behavioral data to refine models.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Requires advanced analytics capabilities often unavailable to small businesses.
  • Harder to prove short-term ROI which can impact budget approval.
  • Too much focus on long term can cause complacency in tactical adjustments.

Example

Sundar Pichai’s observation that users accessing AI overviews end up performing more searches overall supports the theory of legacy SEO impact beyond immediate clicks.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Monitor Emerging AI and Niche Search Platforms for SEO Opportunities

What It Is

Keep track of growing AI platforms, specialized search engines, and niche verticals (e.g., specific AI image generators or productivity tools) to capitalize early by tailoring SEO and content strategies to these environments.

Why It Works

Early movers gain competitive advantage in new channels where competition is less established and user bases can rapidly grow, capturing untapped demand.

When To Use

Advanced SEO practitioners, innovation-focused brands, tech sectors, and enterprise marketing teams.

Execution Steps

  1. Regularly review industry reports and data (such as Datos AI search landscape reports).
  2. Identify emerging AI search engines, chatbots, or vertical-specific platforms gaining traction.
  3. Research content and keyword optimization requirements unique to those platforms.
  4. Experiment with content formats and query targeting tailored to platform behavior.
  5. Measure engagement and adjust investment accordingly.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Platforms might be too small or niche to justify heavy investment.
  • Rapid platform evolution can make early strategies obsolete quickly.
  • Data coverage and tools might be limited for emerging channels.

Example

Tracking of AI companies like DeepSea and AI search overlays shows some are on the rise though still small; monitoring allows marketers to prepare for broader adoption.

These eight extracted and unified actionable SEO strategies represent all distinct, specific tactics discussed or implied in the podcast transcript. Each is crafted to be standalone and fully self-contained.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Eliminate Thin and Low-Value Content

What It Is

Remove or significantly improve pages and posts that have thin, outdated, or low-value content lacking depth or internal links.

Why It Works

Google’s June 2025 core update specifically targets individual pages with low value, often de-indexing or demoting them to maintain high-quality search results and reduce spam or parasite SEO.

When To Use

Especially effective for content-heavy sites, ecommerce stores, affiliate sites, news publishers, or any site with large volumes of pages, particularly after core algorithm updates targeting page quality.

Execution Steps

  1. Use Google Search Console to identify pages with declining impressions or those de-indexed.
  2. Audit your content portfolio for pages with shallow, outdated, or thin content.
  3. Enhance content by adding depth, original insights, updated information, and relevant media.
  4. Ensure proper internal linking to and from these pages.
  5. Remove or noindex pages that cannot be improved sufficiently.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Simply adding filler content without increasing actual value can backfire.
  • Removing pages en masse without considering their user value may reduce site breadth too much.
  • This approach is less effective if the entire site lacks overall trust or authority.

Example

Many websites reported mass de-indexing of thin, outdated pages during this update, especially those with poor internal linking structures.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Edit and Humanize AI-Generated Content

What It Is

Avoid publishing unedited AI-generated content; instead, thoroughly review, edit, and enhance AI-written text to meet quality standards.

Why It Works

Google’s quality raters are instructed to assign the lowest value to pure AI-generated content without human editing, as it often lacks expertise, authority, and trustworthiness.

When To Use

Suitable for sites employing AI content generation tools, particularly in niches sensitive to quality signals such as news, medical, financial, or authoritative knowledge domains.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify AI-generated content on your site.
  2. Review content thoroughly for accuracy, coherence, grammar, and user value.
  3. Add expert insights, data, sources, and updates to enhance credibility.
  4. Regularly refresh AI content to ensure it remains relevant and high quality.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Relying solely on AI-generated text without human input risks penalties.
  • Over-editing or inconsistency in tone can degrade user experience.

Example

The update targeted unedited AI content especially hard, causing rankings to drop for such pages even on strong domains.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Build Real Brand Signals Through Marketing

What It Is

Increase genuine brand mentions, branded searches, and overall off-site real-world marketing to strengthen your site’s topical authority and trust signals.

Why It Works

Google increasingly uses brand and entity signals beyond backlinks to assess trust and authority, favoring “real” businesses and authentic online presence.

When To Use

Valuable for any scale business aiming to improve topical authority, especially local businesses, ecommerce brands, and service providers looking to combat parasite SEO or AI-spam competition.

Execution Steps

  1. Increase PR efforts to gain genuine brand mentions on popular and relevant sites.
  2. Encourage branded searches via advertising, social media, and content campaigns.
  3. Cultivate community engagement and presence on forums, social channels, and real-world events.
  4. Monitor brand search volume and mentions in SEO tools and Google Analytics.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Artificially generating brand signals (e.g., spammy link schemes, fake mentions) will be filtered or penalized.
  • Small or new businesses may find it challenging to quickly establish strong brand signals.

Example

SEOs noted that Google is prioritizing brand signals and topical authority rather than just backlinks.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Monitor and Track Keyword and Traffic Fluctuations Closely After Updates

What It Is

Use tools like Google Analytics 4 and Google Search Console to detect traffic and ranking changes immediately after core updates, focusing on both targeted and branded keywords.

Why It Works

Early detection of traffic drops or ranking changes allows timely response to algorithm updates, enabling content audits, strategy adjustments, and mitigation before losses deepen.

When To Use

Critical after every major Google core algorithm update or when spotting sudden ranking changes. Essential for all website types and sizes.

Execution Steps

  1. Set automated reports or alerts for key KPIs such as organic traffic, impressions, clicks, and keyword rankings.
  2. Compare data before and after Google core update rollout dates (e.g., June 30 for June 2025 update).
  3. Identify pages or keyword groups with significant drops.
  4. Prioritize those pages for audit, improvement, or removal.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Data volatility during the rollout period may cause false positives; avoid knee-jerk reactions.
  • Over-monitoring and frequent re-optimization without a clear plan can waste resources.

Example

SEOs tracked keyword and traffic drops starting June 30 and saw up to 33% declines for some clients.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Focus on Real Experience and User-First Content Writing

What It Is

Produce content that reflects genuine experience, expertise, and prioritizes user needs over just keyword optimization or AI generation.

Why It Works

Google’s algorithm upgrades increasingly reward content that serves actual users well, showing real-world knowledge and topical authority rather than keyword-stuffed, spun, or AI-generated garbage.

When To Use

Important for sites requiring authority such as health, finance, education, or professional services but beneficial for all verticals aiming for long-term ranking stability.

Execution Steps

  1. Use writers or subject matter experts who have real experience in the niche.
  2. Address user questions comprehensively and clearly.
  3. Include personal insights, case studies, examples, and actionable advice.
  4. Avoid overly promotional or repetitive content designed only for SEO.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Creating experience-based content requires more resources, time, and expertise.
  • May not scale easily for large, content-heavy sites without trained contributors.

Example

The podcast highlighted that even strong domains lost rankings for “garbage content,” whereas user-first, real experience content was prioritized.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Conduct Regular Content Audits With Internal Linking Improvements

What It Is

Review your site’s content regularly, remove or enhance poor-quality pages, and ensure proper internal linking structure to help Google better crawl and understand your site.

Why It Works

Pages without sufficient internal links are often deemed low value or isolated, risking de-indexing or ranking drops under recent Google updates prioritizing page-level quality. Internal linking distributes authority and improves site architecture signals.

When To Use

Ideal for large sites with many pages, content-heavy sites, publishers, affiliate sites, or after slate core updates focusing on page-level quality.

Execution Steps

  1. Use site auditing tools (e.g., Screaming Frog, Sitebulb) to detect orphan pages or those with few inbound internal links.
  2. Identify low performing pages and improve or remove them.
  3. Add contextual internal links from authoritative, relevant pages to weaker pages to pass authority.
  4. Maintain a logical site structure that helps both users and search engines navigate easily.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Adding internal links without context or relevance can harm UX and dilute page authority.
  • Over-auditing and frequent structural changes might confuse Google or users if done too often.

Example

The update saw many poorly linked pages dropped or de-indexed, emphasizing the need for sound internal linking.

No direct examples with client names or exact numbers apart from the Reddit traffic growth and general SEO reports of traffic drops were given beyond what is noted in the relevant strategies above.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Compact Keywords SEO

What It Is

Focus on creating dozens of short landing pages (around 400 words each) targeting very specific buyer-intent keywords that directly serve searchers ready to purchase rather than general informational queries.

Why It Works

Buyers with high commercial intent are more likely to convert when landing on pages that perfectly match their search query. Ranking multiple highly focused pages increases opportunities to capture these intent-driven visitors while requiring less content than broad-topic articles.

When To Use

Ecommerce businesses, service providers targeting bottom-of-funnel keywords, small to medium sites wanting higher conversion rates with less content effort.

Execution Steps

  • Identify buyer-intent (transactional/commercial) keywords relevant to your niche.
  • Create concise pages (~400–500 words) targeting each keyword directly.
  • Include the target keyword in page title, URL, meta description, top heading, and opening sentence.
  • Optimize content for conversion with clear CTAs.
  • Launch and monitor rankings and conversions.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Ignoring keyword intent may result in poor conversions.
  • Too many thin pages with weak differentiation may be flagged as low quality by Google.
  • Not targeting bottom-funnel keywords lowers effectiveness.

Example

The speaker’s course "Compact Keywords" focuses on this methodology, stating it yields better ROI and rank compared to traditional articles, requiring less writing effort.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Keyword Discovery via Competitor Keyword Export + AI Filtering

What It Is

Extract all keywords a competitor website ranks for using an SEO tool, export that data, then use AI-powered spreadsheet formulas to automatically filter and identify niche-relevant and bottom-funnel keywords worth targeting.

Why It Works

Instead of guessing keywords, this method leverages a competitor’s existing rankings to discover lucrative, less competitive long-tail keywords that relate to your niche, improving chances of ranking and conversion. Using AI automates the tedious filtering process.

When To Use

Businesses entering competitive niches, new websites seeking untapped keyword opportunities, agencies handling keyword research at scale.

Execution Steps

  • Use an SEO tool (e.g., MOS, SEMrush, Ahrefs) to export competitor’s keyword rankings as a CSV.
  • Import the CSV into Google Sheets.
  • Use Google Workspace Labs AI formulas to apply natural language filters, such as "Does this keyword relate to [niche]?" with Yes/No answers.
  • Filter or sort the list by AI output to isolate relevant, bottom-of-funnel keywords.
  • Prioritize keywords with decent search volume and low direct competition.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • AI filtering is limited to around 200 rows per execution, requiring batching.
  • Niche relevance scoring can vary; manual review is recommended.
  • Requires basic knowledge of SEO export tools and spreadsheet formulas.

Example

A crypto marketing agency used this approach to discover the lucrative “cryptocurrency PR agency” keyword that had low direct competition but high conversion potential, worth an estimated $15,000 monthly revenue per client.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Keyword Placement Optimization in On-Page SEO

What It Is

Ensure the target search keyword appears in key on-page elements: page title, URL, meta description, main heading (H1), and start of the first paragraph.

Why It Works

Google’s algorithm and user behavior emphasize keywords in these strategic locations to understand page relevance and improve rankings; also helps users quickly scan and confirm content matches their query.

When To Use

All content creation, especially pages targeting commercial and transactional keywords.

Execution Steps

  • Research your target keyword.
  • Optimize page title to include the keyword, preferably near the start.
  • Include the keyword in the URL slug.
  • Write or ensure your meta description contains the keyword naturally (may get rewritten by Google).
  • Add the keyword to the primary heading (H1) on the page.
  • Start the first sentence or paragraph with the keyword or a close variant.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Keyword stuffing or unnatural usage can harm rankings.
  • Over-optimization may cause penalties; ensure content reads well.
  • Meta descriptions often get rewritten by Google, so focus on user clarity rather than SEO alone.

Example

The speaker emphasized these points as critical SEO “must-dos” for winning keyword rankings.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Podcast Transcript Structuring & Database Creation for SEO Content & Querying

What It Is

Automate the extraction and structuring of podcast episode data (guest name, episode topics, keywords) into a spreadsheet/database using scripts and AI APIs, making it searchable and queryable for content creation and research.

Why It Works

Instead of manually processing transcripts, structured databases let you quickly retrieve insights, keywords, and guest info to create targeted content, improved metadata, and internal linking strategies to boost SEO.

When To Use

Podcast publishers, multi-episode content creators, enterprise or agency scale content operations.

Execution Steps

  • Capture full episode transcripts.
  • Use Google Apps Script to locate and extract transcripts from Google Drive.
  • Call AI APIs (like OpenAI) to analyze and extract structured fields from transcript chunks.
  • Populate a spreadsheet/database with standardized columns (episode number, guest, industry, keywords, etc.).
  • Use AI-powered spreadsheet queries or external tools to search and retrieve relevant info for SEO or content repurposing.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Requires some scripting or technical knowledge to set up automation.
  • AI extraction quality depends on transcript accuracy and prompt engineering.
  • Live syncing issues if not automated fully.

Example

The speaker built a podcast database with Google Sheets and OpenAI integration to query past episodes by topic or guest, enabling efficient content repurposing and keyword research.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Using Google Workspace Labs AI Formula for Keyword Analysis

What It Is

Use Google Workspace Labs’ built-in AI formula functionality directly inside Google Sheets to bulk analyze long lists of keywords or phrases using natural language prompts with AI, for classification, filtering, or extracting insights.

Why It Works

It automates traditionally laborious keyword research and filtering tasks, allowing marketers to quickly identify relevant keywords, intents, or clusters by leveraging AI’s language understanding within a familiar spreadsheet environment.

When To Use

Keyword research for SEO and PPC campaigns, content planning, competitive analysis.

Execution Steps

  • Enable Google Workspace Labs in your Google account.
  • Import keyword data into a Google Sheet.
  • Use the AI formula: =AI("your prompt", range) to query multiple rows. For example, “Write yes/no: does this keyword relate to crypto?”
  • Filter or sort results based on AI outputs.
  • Iterate with new prompts to refine classification or extract useful info (e.g., user intent, category, volume estimates).

Pitfalls & Limits

  • AI can only process a limited number of rows per call (~200 max), requiring batching.
  • Quality of output varies based on prompt clarity and data cleanliness.
  • Still requires human validation before final decisions.

Example

The speaker used this to analyze 10,000 keywords exported from competitor rankings to isolate crypto-related keywords for a client, speeding up keyword discovery and prioritization.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Create Style Guides with AI for Consistent Content Voice & SEO

What It Is

Use AI models to distill your existing high-quality writing into a style guide that defines tone, voice, jargon, sentence structure, and content preferences to maintain brand consistency across SEO content.

Why It Works

Consistent voice strengthens brand recognition and trust, improving user experience and dwell time which indirectly support SEO rankings; AI speeds up the creation and refinement of style guidelines.

When To Use

Content agencies, brands scaling content teams, or individuals aiming for consistent content production.

Execution Steps

  • Gather a corpus of your best-written content.
  • Input that into an AI model with a prompt to “distill my writing style and tone into a style guide.”
  • Review, edit, and finalize the style guide output.
  • Use style guide when generating new SEO content either manually or by AI-generated drafts.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Initial outputs may require manual editing for accuracy and formatting.
  • Poor source content leads to poor style guides.

Example

The speaker spent a few hours creating a style guide from his written works, then uses it to inform AI when creating podcast transcripts, social media posts, and SEO descriptions, improving content quality and coherence.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use AI-Powered Large Context Windows for Content Analysis & Repurposing

What It Is

Employ AI tools (e.g., Notebook LM, Claude) with extended context windows (up to 1 million tokens) to analyze large volumes of related content (such as podcast transcripts), distill key points, and generate new content and insights.

Why It Works

Longer context windows allow AI to consider a bigger dataset holistically, extracting meaningful summaries, patterns, and use cases that can be repurposed into SEO assets, saving time and improving content depth.

When To Use

Enterprises or content creators with large archives of related material seeking to scale content recycling, research, and SEO.

Execution Steps

  • Collect a batch of related content (e.g., 40 podcast transcripts or equivalent).
  • Upload these into an AI tool supporting large context windows.
  • Use targeted prompts to extract step-by-step SEO or marketing use cases, summaries, guest insights, or FAQs.
  • Use outputs to create content briefs, guides, or brand assets to drive traffic or build linkable assets.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Maximizing context window can degrade output quality; needs balancing.
  • Some AI tools hallucinate or produce inaccurate summaries less suitable for direct publishing without review.

Example

The speaker chunked his 200 podcast episodes into groups and used Notebook LM to extract actionable AI use cases and distilled brand messaging to create assets for SEO and content marketing.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Build Linkable Assets from AI-Derived Brand Guides & Interactive Apps

What It Is

Convert AI-generated synthesized content (brand messaging, heuristics, frameworks) into digital assets such as apps or interactive guides hosted on subdomains, designed to attract backlinks and traffic.

Why It Works

Linkable assets are valuable resources that naturally attract backlinks from journalists, bloggers, and users, improving domain authority and SEO rankings for competitive keywords.

When To Use

Brands or businesses looking to boost authority, startups creating differentiation, content marketers focused on link building.

Execution Steps

  • Use AI to synthesize insights, heuristics, and brand elements from your content archive.
  • Convert this output into an interactive web app or guide hosted on a subdomain (e.g., brand.yoursite.com).
  • Promote the asset through product launches, press releases, and relevant communities.
  • Encourage sharing by providing useful, evergreen content.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Requires development resources to build and host apps or guides.
  • If the asset lacks genuine value, it won’t attract natural backlinks.

Example

The speaker describes turning podcast insights into an app-like "brand guide" hosted on a subdomain to generate backlinks and enhance SEO authority.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

AI-Assisted Employee Onboarding & Knowledge Management for SEO Teams

What It Is

Use AI to create dynamic, queryable style guides, workflows, and onboarding documents that new SEO or content team members can use to independently find answers and reduce dependency on managers.

Why It Works

Automates training and reduces bottlenecks, allowing faster productivity and consistent application of SEO best practices, ensuring quality and strategy alignment.

When To Use

Growing SEO teams, agency onboarding, remote or distributed teams where synchronous training is challenging.

Execution Steps

  • Record onboarding sessions and team workflows.
  • Transcribe recordings and feed into AI with prompts to generate structured playbooks, FAQs, and style guides.
  • Make these resources accessible to new team members via internal knowledge bases integrated with AI query tools.
  • Continuously update documents based on ongoing conversations and feedback using AI summarization.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Initial setup and transcription require time investment.
  • AI hallucination or outdated info if not regularly updated.
  • Still requires human review for complex or nuanced instructions.

Example

The speaker used this method with an intern’s onboarding, turning transcripted discussions into a 12-week roadmap and playbook that the intern queries independently, saving manager time.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Recording & Transcription to Reduce Communication Ambiguity

What It Is

Record all SEO or business-related meetings and conversations, transcribe them, and use AI to generate summaries and records to ensure clear understanding and reduce communication gaps.

Why It Works

Creates unambiguous documentation of decisions and action items, preventing misunderstandings and reducing follow-up clarifications, indirectly boosting productivity and enabling more consistent SEO execution.

When To Use

Teams with frequent collaboration, remote teams, workflows involving contractors or freelancers.

Execution Steps

- Use recording tools like Limitless Pendant or Zoom to capture discussions.  
- Use transcription services or AI transcription tools.  
- Use AI to summarize key points, decisions, and action items.  
- Share summaries and archive recordings for team reference.

Pitfalls & Limits

- Privacy and consent considerations for recordings.  
- Transcription errors may cause confusion if not reviewed.  
- Over-reliance on recordings may reduce real-time communication.

Example

The speaker records all conversations and uses transcripts to generate explicit documentation for accountability and clarity during SEO project management.

This list includes all actionable SEO strategies explicitly or implicitly described in the transcript, emphasizing practical implementation, situational use, and potential pitfalls.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Social Proof through Public Speaking Engagements

What It Is

Position yourself as an expert by securing and delivering talks at relevant local and industry events, then leverage these engagements as demonstrable social proof on your website and social channels.

Why It Works

Public speaking enhances perceived expertise and credibility, which increases trust from potential clients and event organizers. The Google algorithm and users favor authoritative, trustworthy sources, and social proof signals trustworthiness.

When To Use

Best for agency owners, freelancers, B2B service providers, and professionals looking to establish credibility and attract leads, especially in competitive industries or new businesses.

Execution Steps

  • Search for local or niche events on platforms like Meetup, Eventbrite, Facebook groups, and business groups.
  • Email event organizers with a compelling speaker pitch, including a professional one-sheet PDF with a strong bio, headshot, topic list, and any testimonials or past speaking clips.
  • Prep thoroughly for your talks to maximize value and impression.
  • After speaking, request referrals for other event opportunities.
  • Share event appearances on social media, email lists, and personal/professional networks.
  • Highlight association with high-profile speakers by mentioning shared stages, even if on different days.
  • Gradually scale to bigger events, new locations, and larger audiences.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overly embellishing bios can risk credibility if exposed; use cautiously.
  • Underpreparing talks can damage your reputation.
  • Speaking at empty or irrelevant events can waste time—choose events thoughtfully.
  • Requires persistence and consistent follow-up.

Example

James Reynolds started speaking at small local events found via Meetup and Eventbrite, sending organizer one-sheets. Over time, he spoke at bigger events nationwide, building credibility that led to hundreds of client conversions and acquiring an SEO fulfillment company’s employees. Sharing these speaking engagements on LinkedIn and social media amplified his authority and helped attract more business.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Manufacturing Social Proof with Influencer Inclusion in Content

What It Is

Create high-quality research reports or articles featuring SEO influencers’ experiments or insights, then proactively involve them by sharing drafts for feedback and encouraging their promotion.

Why It Works

Featuring influencers creates vested interest, social proof, and encourages them to share your content, resulting in increased backlinks, credibility, and distribution. Google values authoritative, well-linked content, and influencer shares drive organic traffic and links.

When To Use

Effective for SEO agencies, content marketers, and thought leaders aiming to build authority and backlinks in competitive niches. Works well for mid-stage to advanced sites with some content baseline.

Execution Steps

  • Research and compile a comprehensive, well-written article or report involving known industry influencers (e.g., listing their experiments).
  • Reach out to these influencers before publishing, sharing the draft and requesting feedback or additional detail.
  • Incorporate influencer feedback to improve the content and demonstrate collaboration.
  • Publish the article and coordinate with influencers to share it simultaneously on social media channels.
  • Monitor backlink acquisition and leverage these backlinks as further social proof.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Requires strong writing and content production skills.
  • Difficult if influencers do not respond or engage.
  • The piece must be high quality and credible to merit sharing.
  • Overly promotional or self-serving content can harm reputation.

Example

James Reynolds produced the “21 SEO Experiments” article featuring major SEO figures. After sending drafts for influencer input, the article was widely shared by those influencers, resulting in 213 backlinks from 110 domains and significant industry recognition for James’s agency SEO Sherpa.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Using Journalist Quote Platforms to Gain Expert Mentions and Backlinks

What It Is

Regularly respond to journalists’ requests for expert quotes on platforms like Help a Reporter Out (HARO), Source of Sources, and feature.com to get cited with backlinks in media stories.

Why It Works

Earning quotes in reputable media outlets provides authoritative backlinks, raises brand awareness, and signals trustworthiness to search engines and users alike. High-quality backlinks from news sites improve domain authority and rankings.

When To Use

Useful for new or growing businesses seeking quick, credible backlinks and media exposure, especially B2B and personal brands.

Execution Steps

  • Sign up for HARO, Source of Sources, feature.com or similar services.
  • Commit to responding to at least one journalist query daily with a clear, concise, expert comment.
  • Once you get a mention or backlink, use it as social proof in pitches for future HARO responses, public speaking, or client meetings.
  • Track placements and increase outreach for higher tier or larger publications as you build reputation.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Responses must be relevant and valuable or will be ignored.
  • Low-quality or rushed replies reduce chances of being quoted.
  • HARO can be competitive and time-consuming with many pitches required for few results initially.

Example

The podcast host shared that by doing one journalist response a day on HARO, they gradually gained multiple media inclusions, leveraging these mentions to attract bigger opportunities and clients over time.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leveraging Podcasts as Platforms for Social Proof and Public Speaking Credentials

What It Is

Appear regularly on industry podcasts to demonstrate expertise and build social proof, which also can be used to gain acceptance for speaking at larger events.

Why It Works

Podcasts serve as live, accessible demonstrations of your knowledge and personality, increasing authority and trust for SEO and user conversion. Being a podcast guest signals subject matter expertise to both listeners and event organizers.

When To Use

Ideal for new or emerging experts, consultants, and agency owners looking to build audience and credibility from scratch.

Execution Steps

  • Use tools like aipodcastmatcher.com to find relevant podcasts to pitch.
  • Approach podcast hosts with a concise, customized pitch explaining why you are a good fit.
  • Prepare engaging and informative podcast appearances.
  • Promote your podcast episodes on social media, email newsletters, and pitches to event organizers.
  • Use your podcast appearances as proof of expertise when requesting speaking opportunities.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Multiple podcast appearances require time and preparation.
  • Low-quality podcast appearances with poor audio or weak content won’t boost credibility.
  • Some niches have fewer relevant podcasts.

Example

The podcast host used aipodcastmatcher.com to go on 30 podcasts in 3 months before having social media presence, building credibility that helped secure future speaking gigs and client leads.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Snowball Referrals by Networking After Each Engagement

What It Is

After speaking or any public engagement, actively ask organizers for referrals to other similar speaking opportunities to generate a growing list of events.

Why It Works

Referrals leverage existing relationships and trust, making outreach warmer and increasing acceptance rates. Snowball effects accelerate growth in exposure and social proof.

When To Use

Best when involved in public speaking circuits, networking events, or any dialogue-based branding activities. Ideal for agencies or professionals seeking rapid growth of visibility.

Execution Steps

  • After each talk or presentation, thank the organizer genuinely.
  • Ask who else they know who hosts similar events and if they’d be willing to introduce you.
  • Follow up on any referrals quickly with tailored pitches.
  • Continue to build your speaking portfolio with each new engagement.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Over-asking or pressuring organizers can harm relationships.
  • Depends on organizers’ own networks and willingness to refer.
  • Requires tracking and managing contacts effectively.

Example

James Reynolds used this to expand from local small events to bigger and more distant venues, generating a steady stream of speaking opportunities and clients.

These five strategies capture all specific, actionable SEO and backlink-building tactics mentioned in the transcript, structured as requested.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

AI-Powered Keyword Filtering in Google Sheets

What It Is

Use Google Sheets’ AI formula to quickly classify and filter large keyword lists based on relevance to specific topics by running natural language prompts that return yes/no answers.

Why It Works

Automating keyword relevance filtering saves time and reduces manual effort when sorting through thousands of keywords from multiple niches. It harnesses AI’s natural language understanding to group keywords meaningfully, aligning the dataset with your business intent.

When To Use

  • When handling very large keyword datasets from multiple competitor sites or sources
  • For niche-specific keyword research, especially for startups or agencies targeting specific verticals (e.g., crypto, fintech)
  • When needing to quickly isolate topic-relevant keywords before deeper analysis

Execution Steps

  1. Compile your large keyword dataset in Google Sheets, with keywords in one column (starting from A2).
  2. Join Google Workspace Labs (free and immediate acceptance), and use a VPN connected to the US if outside the US.
  3. In an adjacent column, enter the formula: =AI("Write yes or no. Does this relate directly to [your topic or niche]?", A2) replacing [your topic or niche] accordingly.
  4. Drag the formula down to apply it to all keyword rows.
  5. Highlight the cells with the formula and click “Generate and Insert” to populate yes/no answers.
  6. Apply a filter on this new column to show only “yes” rows, isolating keywords relevant to your target niche or business.
  7. Review filtered keywords manually for further qualification (competition, search intent).

Pitfalls & Limits

  • AI may misclassify or miss semantic subtleties depending on prompt quality; verify results manually.
  • Does not reliably identify bottom-of-funnel (BOFU)/transactional keywords; manual judgment still required.
  • Requires some familiarity with Google Sheets formulas and access to Google Workspace Labs.
  • Using poor prompts yields inaccurate or unhelpful results.
  • VPN may be necessary to access the full functionality from outside the US.

Example

The speaker used this method to filter 26,000 keywords from a competitor marketing agency site (NinjaPromo.io) and isolated crypto and blockchain-related keywords in under five minutes. This led to discovering a lucrative, undertargeted keyword expected to generate $15,000 monthly recurring revenue.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Target Underserved Bottom-of-Funnel Keywords with Transactional Modifiers

What It Is

Focus keyword research on transactional, bottom-of-funnel keywords that indicate strong purchase or conversion intent (e.g., keywords containing terms like “services,” “agency,” “buy,” “best”).

Why It Works

Bottom-of-funnel keywords typically correspond to searchers closer to making a purchase decision, offering higher conversion rates. Such keywords are often overlooked or less competitive, especially if they contain specific service descriptors, making them easier to rank for with less content or fewer backlinks.

When To Use

  • For ecommerce, service-based businesses, or agencies aiming to drive leads or conversions
  • When identifying keywords with commercial intent suitable for direct sales or service sign-ups
  • For competitive niches where high-volume broad keywords are too difficult to rank for

Execution Steps

  1. Identify transactional modifiers relevant to your industry (e.g., “services,” “agency,” “buy,” “best”).
  2. Use keyword tools or competitor keyword lists and filter for keywords containing these modifiers.
  3. Manually review search engine results pages (SERPs) for competitiveness and relevance.
  4. Select keywords that appear undertargeted or poorly optimized by competitors.
  5. Create targeted landing pages with clear calls to action optimized for these keywords.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Terms like “best” can attract comparison shoppers who may not be ready to convert immediately; consider the funnel stage carefully.
  • Automated tools or AI prompt attempts to identify BOFU keywords currently produce low accuracy; manual validation remains crucial.
  • Over-reliance on transactional keywords can narrow keyword diversity and miss earlier funnel traffic opportunities.

Example

The crypto marketing agency client discovered several bottom-of-funnel crypto-related agency keywords that were undertargeted and easy to rank for, leading to a significant potential revenue stream.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Competitor Keyword Scraping and Filtering for Niche Focus

What It Is

Extract large sets of keywords that competitors rank for, then filter these to find those relevant and underutilized within your niche or vertical.

Why It Works

Competitors’ keyword portfolios reveal market demand and content opportunities, but sorting through their entire keyword set is time-intensive. Targeting only relevant and undertargeted keywords helps find “low-hanging fruit” for faster ranking gains.

When To Use

  • For new sites or agencies entering a competitive space but with limited content resources
  • Industries with many cross-niche competitor rankings needing topical focus
  • When looking to scale keyword research beyond generic, broad searches

Execution Steps

  1. Use tools like Ahrefs, SEMrush, or others to extract competitor ranking keywords.
  2. Import the list to Google Sheets for easier manipulation.
  3. Apply AI filtering (see Strategy 1) or manual filtering to extract relevant niche keywords.
  4. Analyze SERPs to assess keyword competitiveness and identify underserved queries.
  5. Prioritize keywords where competitors have weak content or no dedicated pages.
  6. Develop targeted pages or content assets optimized for these keywords.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Competitor keywords may be mixed with irrelevant terms; filtering accuracy is vital.
  • Some large competitors may rank for unrelated niches, causing noise in datasets.
  • Tools may have data lag or incomplete keyword data, so supplement with manual checking.

Example

The speaker’s client targeted keywords from NinjaPromo.io’s extensive 26,000+ keyword list, extracting only crypto-related keywords to build a relevant strategy.

These are the primary actionable SEO strategies presented in the transcript.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

SEO Skills for AI Content Optimization

What It Is

Applying traditional SEO knowledge and techniques to create content that ranks highly both in search engines and in AI-generated answers.

Why It Works

Many AI-generated responses are trained on top-ranking SEO content, so well-optimized SEO content is more likely to be incorporated in AI tools’ outputs, increasing visibility across AI and search platforms.

When To Use

For content creators and marketers aiming to maximize visibility both on traditional search engines and voice/AI-powered search interfaces.

Execution Steps

  1. Conduct SEO keyword research and target relevant keywords.
  2. Optimize on-page elements like titles, headers, and meta descriptions.
  3. Create high-quality, authoritative, and user-intent-focused content.
  4. Ensure the content is easily crawlable and indexed by search engines.
  5. Monitor rankings in regular search and AI answer platforms, adjusting as needed.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overreliance on SEO alone without considering AI-specific formats (e.g., conversational tone) may reduce effectiveness; AI tools evolving could shift which content gets pulled.

Example

Study shows AI answers correlate highly with top SEO content, so SEO skills help your content be surfaced in AI tools as well as Google search.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Cross-Platform Algorithm Insights via SEO Principles

What It Is

Using SEO knowledge around user engagement metrics, content structure, and click behavior to optimize content not only on Google but also on social media platforms such as YouTube, Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, X (Twitter), and LinkedIn.

Why It Works

Search engine and social media algorithms share common ranking factors like click-through rate (CTR), dwell time, content structure, and matching user intent. Understanding SEO principles helps create content that performs well universally.

When To Use

When creating content for multi-channel digital marketing strategies that include organic search and social media platforms.

Execution Steps

  1. Study SEO metrics such as CTR and time on page to understand engagement.
  2. Adapt content structure (e.g., use compelling headlines, hooks, and logical flow).
  3. Use internal linking/navigation on websites and apply equivalent linking/funneling on social media profiles and posts.
  4. Optimize fresh and trending content to maximize recency signals.
  5. Use keyword research for hashtags and platform-specific search terms.
  6. Craft hooks and lead content with target keywords upfront (e.g. video intros, captions).

Pitfalls & Limits

Treating all platforms exactly like Google may hurt effectiveness; each platform has unique content formats and user behaviors. Always tailor to platform specifics.

Example

YouTube is the most clicked site from Google, so understanding SEO helps optimize YouTube videos for higher watch time; similarly, optimize Instagram reels with hooks to increase engagement.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Placing Target Keywords at the Start of Key Elements

What It Is

Positioning target keywords at the very beginning of page titles, headers (H1), first sentences, and URL slugs, as well as within the opening moments of videos and social post captions.

Why It Works

Search engines and platform internal search engines prioritize keywords placed early as they are seen as more relevant to the content, improving indexing and ranking. User attention is also highest at the start, making early keyword placement boost CTR and engagement.

When To Use

For SEO on web pages, blogs, videos (YouTube, TikTok, Instagram Reels), social media posts, and any content with an internal or external search function.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify your main target keyword(s).
  2. Start page titles and H1 headers exactly or closely with the target keyword.
  3. Include the keyword within the first sentence or paragraph of the content.
  4. Create URL slugs that contain the target keyword and are concise.
  5. For videos and social posts, mention or display the keyword idea immediately in the intro or caption.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overstuffing keywords at the start can appear unnatural and harm user experience; forced keyword placement can reduce content quality.

Example

Google increasingly indexes social content, so placing keywords early in social posts and videos helps the content rank well on both platform internal searches and Google.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Bottom-of-Funnel SEO Targeting

What It Is

Focusing SEO efforts on keywords and pages targeting users who are ready to buy or convert, such as transactional and service/product category terms, rather than top-of-funnel informational content.

Why It Works

Bottom-of-funnel users exhibit high purchase intent, resulting in higher conversion rates with less effort spent on education or nurturing compared to top-of-funnel traffic. Search engines rank these pages well when intent and content match, and AI tools recommend them often.

When To Use

In ecommerce, SaaS, professional services, and any niche where users have clear purchase queries or urgent needs.

Execution Steps

  1. Perform keyword research to identify high-intent transactional keywords.
  2. Create well-structured landing pages targeting these keywords with relevant, concise content.
  3. Optimize on-page SEO (titles, headers, CTAs) aligned with purchase intent.
  4. Build authority and trust signals (reviews, testimonials, schema).
  5. Continuously monitor rankings and traffic; expand to related bottom-funnel queries.

Pitfalls & Limits

Limited volume for long-tail bottom-funnel keywords may restrict traffic scale; ignoring top-of-funnel content can reduce brand awareness growth over time.

Example

A landing page for “HIPPA compliant video therapy platform” attracted warm leads with zero ad spend; an emergency roof repair page in Austin generated 10+ organic calls daily; an accounting software product page grew from 25 users/month to 500 monthly users in a year with no paid ads.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leveraging Social Media Engagement to Boost SEO Rankings

What It Is

Using social media platforms (X, Instagram, TikTok, etc.) to drive shares, clicks, and engagement that create an immediate ranking boost for SEO content pages in search engines.

Why It Works

Google and other search engines factor user engagement signals such as CTR and sharing into rankings; increased social engagement causes an instant boost by signaling content relevance and popularity.

When To Use

When launching new landing pages or content that target high-value keywords; especially effective for websites with existing social media followings or active marketing campaigns.

Execution Steps

  1. Build and engage a social media following in your niche.
  2. Publish SEO-optimized content pages targeting bottom-funnel keywords.
  3. Share these pages on social media using posts, videos, or reels to maximize engagement.
  4. Encourage followers to click, share, and interact with the content.
  5. If possible, instruct users on how to find the page via Google search to increase direct click-throughs.
  6. Monitor impact on search rankings and refine social amplification based on results.

Pitfalls & Limits

Social engagement alone won’t sustain rankings without quality SEO and content; artificially inflating clicks can risk penalties; success requires an active, relevant social audience.

Example

Ran Fishkin’s experiment showed 228 social clicks in 3 hours boosted a page from #7 to #1 ranking for “iMac lab” keyword; social content generating thousands of views and users in hours increased SEO traffic rapidly.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Creating Linkable Assets to Earn Backlinks Organically

What It Is

Developing highly useful, interesting, or unique content/tools/assets that naturally attract backlinks from other websites, blogs, newsletters, and social shares, thus boosting domain authority and SEO rankings.

Why It Works

Backlinks are a strong ranking factor; a linkable asset provides value that compels others to link to your domain, driving organic traffic and improving SEO metrics. Redirecting legacy backlinks to the main site can magnify authority transfer.

When To Use

For companies looking to improve domain authority, grow organic traffic sustainably, or enhance brand exposure through backlinks without paid link building.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify a valuable content gap or tool idea in your niche.
  2. Develop a simple, user-friendly tool or content asset that offers real utility or entertainment.
  3. Launch and share it on platforms like Product Hunt, Reddit, or social media.
  4. Encourage organic sharing and monitor backlink acquisition.
  5. If the asset is on a separate domain, set up a 301 redirect to your main site to transfer link equity.
  6. Promote the asset to relevant bloggers, influencers, and newsletters for additional amplification.

Pitfalls & Limits

Creating valuable assets can require significant upfront effort; there is no guaranteed backlink volume; redirecting from a different domain requires technical setup and trust.

Example

A sleep cycle calculator got 35,000 backlinks from 4,500+ domains after Product Hunt launch; backlinks were redirected to the main company site boosting SEO. Another simple AI reason generator video gained 3,100 users in one day with minimal effort.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Optimizing Blog Content for Smarter Targeting

What It Is

Continuing to use blog posts for SEO but focusing on top-of-funnel discovery with smarter targeting due to AI overviews reducing click volume on generic informational content.

Why It Works

AI answer overviews reduce clicks on many blogs by ~35%, but blogs still drive top-of-funnel traffic and awareness when targeted properly and curated; they feed users into your conversion funnel.

When To Use

When your goal is brand discovery, education, and nurturing future potential customers. Best suited alongside bottom-funnel SEO and other channels.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify niche, less-competitive informational keywords not dominated by AI overview snippets.
  2. Create well-researched, detailed, and engaging blog articles.
  3. Incorporate internal linking to bottom-of-funnel pages to guide users down the funnel.
  4. Monitor AI snippet usage and adjust targeting accordingly.
  5. Promote blogs across channels to maintain traffic flow.

Pitfalls & Limits

Over-investing in generic, informational blog content may result in wasted clicks due to AI competition; lower conversion rates than bottom-funnel content.

Example

Ahrefs study found AI overviews cut blog click-throughs by about 34.5%, indicating decreased but still viable value of blogs for top-funnel SEO.

These 7 strategies encapsulate all actionable SEO tactics described in the transcript and provide clear, actionable guidance for implementation with context, benefits, and limitations.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Amplify Organic Content with LinkedIn Ads

What It Is

Promote thoughtful, regular organic content from a company or personal thought leader on LinkedIn using LinkedIn Ads Manager to amplify reach and engagement.

Why It Works

LinkedIn’s ad inventory for content amplification (especially personal thought leader ads) tends to be cheaper and less competitive because many large companies restrict employee account usage for ads, making this an underused inventory. Promoting pre-existing organic posts capitalizes on proven content and can significantly boost reach and conversion metrics.

When To Use

B2B marketing targeting professional audiences active on LinkedIn, especially HR, marketing, or sales sectors; companies producing bi-monthly or more frequent thought leadership content; brands with defined buyer personas and reasonable ad budgets.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify existing organic posts with reasonable engagement, ideally those that performed well or have potential.
  2. Upload or boost these posts via LinkedIn Ads Manager, using the personal thought leader’s account or company page.
  3. Monitor ad metrics and demographics to adjust audience targeting and exclusions.
  4. Use this approach primarily for awareness and engagement, not expecting bottom-funnel conversions from cold traffic.
  5. Combine with retargeting campaigns to nurture engaged users toward conversions.

Pitfalls & Limits

Organic posts that flop or perform mediocrely may not yield good paid results; blindly amplifying low-quality or irrelevant content wastes budget. LinkedIn is not effective for cold direct response with senior technical audiences due to low engagement. Expectations for immediate conversions in cold campaigns should be moderated.

Example

Performance lifts of 2–4x in click-through and engagement rates compared to traditional LinkedIn ad campaigns promoting identical content.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

LinkedIn Ads Audience Exclusion via Demographics Reporting

What It Is

After launching LinkedIn ads, review the LinkedIn demographics report to identify irrelevant job titles or functions showing in your audience, and exclude them manually to tighten ad targeting.

Why It Works

LinkedIn’s algorithm often expands targeting beyond set parameters, introducing irrelevant users and wasting ad spend. Manual exclusion refines audience quality, increasing engagement and lead quality.

When To Use

B2B LinkedIn campaigns with defined buyer personas; especially important when selling technical or niche products where irrelevant impressions lead to poor ROI.

Execution Steps

  1. Launch LinkedIn ads with your initial tightly defined audience targeting.
  2. After 1-2 weeks, review the demographics report to identify unwanted job titles or roles appearing in ad impressions.
  3. Add exclusions for these irrelevant titles or roles in the campaign’s targeting settings.
  4. Continue monitoring and refine exclusions over time to optimize audience quality.

Pitfalls & Limits

Time delay in getting meaningful demographic data; inability to fully prevent LinkedIn’s audience expansion may require continuous exclusions. Over-exclusion may shrink your audience too much and increase costs or limit reach.

Example

Selling digital adoption software required excluding sales development representatives and junior sales roles to avoid wasting budget on non-decision makers.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Start Google Ads with Exact Match Transactional Keywords and Clean Search Term Reports

What It Is

Begin PPC campaigns by targeting only exact match keywords that are transactional and tightly aligned with landing pages, and actively manage search term reports to exclude irrelevant queries.

Why It Works

Exact match limits ad spend to highly relevant search queries indicating strong purchase intent, avoiding wasted impressions on broad or loosely related traffic. Cleaning the search terms by adding negatives reduces exposure to junk traffic, improving cost efficiency and lead quality.

When To Use

B2B lead generation, enterprise SaaS or higher-ticket products with sales-led models demanding qualified leads and controlled ad spend.

Execution Steps

  1. Define a list of transactional keywords tightly matching your product or service offerings.
  2. Use exact match keyword types in Google Ads to control traffic quality.
  3. Turn off “Search Partners” and “auto apply recommendations” settings to avoid automatic, low-quality traffic.
  4. Monitor search terms regularly; add irrelevant or broad keywords as negative keywords to the campaign.
  5. Avoid testing broad match or Performance Max campaigns early on in lead generation efforts.

Pitfalls & Limits

Too narrow targeting may limit traffic volume; Google still introduces close variants even with exact match, requiring active management. Performance Max and Display campaigns tend to generate spam leads in B2B lead generation.

Example

Campaigns ignoring negative keywords or running broad match early on resulted in junk traffic and wasted budget.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Build a Multi-Layered B2B Funnel: LinkedIn Cold Video Ads + Thought Leadership + Retargeting + Google Ads Remarketing

What It Is

Use short LinkedIn video ads to build a cold audience and retarget engaged users with a mix of value proposition and thought leadership ads, complementing with bottom-funnel Google Ads to close leads.

Why It Works

Video ads have a lower engagement threshold (25% watch time) to retarget, making audience building cost-effective.
