Retargeting nurtures interest and builds credibility before pushing for demo requests or conversions. Combining LinkedIn and Google Ads covers multiple funnel stages for efficient lead driving.

When To Use

B2B SaaS and sales-led models targeting decision makers with longer sales cycles and higher acquisition costs.

Execution Steps

  1. Create short (20-40 seconds) LinkedIn videos with clear, visually compelling messaging aligned with your audience.
  2. Run cold LinkedIn ads promoting personal or company thought leadership content to build awareness.
  3. Define remarketing segments: 30-day (recent engagers) and 90-day (warm but non-converting users).
  4. Target 30-day remarketing group with strong direct value proposition ads focusing on speed, ease, or key differentiators.
  5. Target 90-day remarketing group with a softer mix of thought leadership and lighter value messaging to build trust.
  6. Use bottom-funnel Google Ads (exact match, search campaigns) remarketing to these audiences to capture high-intent leads.
  7. Continue nurturing or removing users after a set period (e.g., 6 months) based on engagement.

Pitfalls & Limits

Video hook is critical since LinkedIn auto-plays videos on mute; avoid bait-and-switch tactics that attract irrelevant users and waste budget. Low budget or small audiences can hurt data quality and funnel effectiveness. Sales cycles may require prolonged nurturing and patience.

Example

Caspian Studios used thought leader videos combined with a serialized content promotion strategy, achieving 4-5% click-through rates and converting leads via call requests.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Produce Serialized Content for B2B Thought Leadership and Demand Generation

What It Is

Develop a series of related content pieces (e.g., podcasts, blog posts, white papers) released over time to build ongoing engagement and authority rather than one-off content items.

Why It Works

Serialized content creates audience continuity and reduces audience acquisition costs by maintaining interest and fostering loyalty, leading to higher efficiency in long-term demand generation. It aligns with natural B2B sales cycles and supports multi-touch attribution.

When To Use

B2B companies with content marketing budgets and strategies targeting complex purchase decisions where nurturing and authority building matter.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify a coherent theme or format (e.g., interview podcast, fiction series, white paper series) aligned with your market and audience needs.
  2. Plan a content calendar for multiple episodes or pieces spread over a year (e.g., 12-16 episodes).
  3. Produce initial episodes or materials with an experienced content partner or agency.
  4. Promote the serialized content via LinkedIn Ads, organic social, and email nurture campaigns.
  5. Measure engagement over time and iterate on content topics and formats.

Pitfalls & Limits

High upfront content production investment; risking producing a failed series without traction; requires consistent commitment and messaging discipline over time.

Example

Caspian Studios created “Pipeline Visionaries” and “CIO Exchange” interview podcasts and a fictional HR mystery podcast, building genuine audiences and authority leading to cost-effective lead generation.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Video Ads for Efficient LinkedIn Remarketing Funnel Audience Building

What It Is

Run short video ads on LinkedIn that users only need to watch 25% of to enter a remarketing audience for subsequent higher-value ads.

Why It Works

Watching 25% of a video is an easy engagement signal that costs less than clicks or form submissions. This creates a warm retargeting audience that’s more likely to convert with follow-up direct response or thought leadership ads.

When To Use

B2B campaigns on LinkedIn needing efficient funnel building with limited budgets and small audiences.

Execution Steps

  1. Produce engaging, short (20–40 seconds) video creatives with clear messaging.
  2. Set up cold LinkedIn campaigns targeting defined audiences with these videos.
  3. Define remarketing audiences based on users who watched 25% or more of videos.
  4. Target these audiences with value prop or nurturing ads as subsequent funnel stages.

Pitfalls & Limits

Poorly designed videos may not retain viewers to 25% threshold. Visual hooks are critical as many users watch muted. Using non-related bait-and-switch creatives risks attracting irrelevant users and wasting budget.

Example

Caspian Studios used founder’s thought leader video as cold traffic ad to build a remarketing pool that had a higher conversion rate on downstream ads.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Avoid Google Performance Max and Display Campaigns for B2B Lead Gen

What It Is

Do not use Google’s Performance Max or broad display ad campaigns for B2B lead generation since they often generate spam or low-quality leads.

Why It Works

Performance Max and Display inventory often includes low-quality or fake sites running ads. The conversion algorithms may be gamed by fraudulent sites generating fake conversions, leading to wasted spend and eroded trust from sales teams.

When To Use

B2B sales-led models requiring clean, qualified lead flow from paid search channels.

Execution Steps

  1. Use only paid search campaigns with exact match keywords and tightly controlled targeting.
  2. Disable search partner sites in Google Ads.
  3. Avoid activating Performance Max or broad display campaigns for lead gen purposes.
  4. Monitor form quality closely and exclude problem traffic sources.

Pitfalls & Limits

May limit scale of campaign reach but ensures lead quality and sales team confidence. Not advised if your business tolerates spam leads or if lead quality is not a concern.

Example

Running Performance Max in B2B lead gen led to many spam form submissions damaging internal credibility with sales teams.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Combine LinkedIn Awareness Ads with Cold Email Outreach for Better Response Rates

What It Is

Use LinkedIn ads to build top-of-funnel awareness and then engage the same prospects via cold email outreach to increase email open and reply rates.

Why It Works

When prospects see professional LinkedIn ads from a company, cold emails from that company appear less “cold” or spam-like, increasing the likelihood of engagement and response.

When To Use

B2B account-based marketing or outbound sales targeting mid-to-upper funnel buyers.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify target accounts and contacts.
  2. Run LinkedIn awareness ads with thought leadership or brand messaging to these targets.
  3. Sequence cold emails to the same contacts after or during the ad campaign.
  4. Track performance and adjust messaging for both channels as necessary.

Pitfalls & Limits

Requires proper coordination between marketing and sales teams. Over-emailing or excessive ads can annoy prospects. Without clean targeting, responses may be low.

Example

LinkedIn ads promoting serialized content increased response rates and engagement to cold sales emails by making the outreach feel warmer and more credible.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Limit Ad Creative Variations in LinkedIn Ads for Budget Efficiency

What It Is

Test only 2-3 ad creatives per campaign when running LinkedIn Ads with modest budgets (~$1,000/month) to focus spending and gather meaningful data.

Why It Works

LinkedIn’s smaller niche audiences and higher CPMs mean spreading budgets too thin over many creatives can’t generate statistically meaningful data or frequency for testing. Focusing on fewer creatives optimizes learning and cost-per-result.

When To Use

Any LinkedIn ad campaign with limited budget or audience size aiming for meaningful optimization data.

Execution Steps

  1. Develop 2-3 strong ad creatives, ideally variants of strong-performing organic content.
  2. Run ads simultaneously and monitor performance metrics (CTR, engagement).
  3. Pause or cut underperformers and iterate based on results.

Pitfalls & Limits

Testing too many variables with low budget causes inconclusive results; stopping at 2-3 creatives may miss some creative winners but balances testing depth and budget constraints.

Example

With $1,000 monthly budget, campaigns testing more than two creatives often unable to reach audience frequency for significant results.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Thought Leadership Ads as a Lower-Cost LinkedIn Inventory Leveraging Employer Accounts

What It Is

Promote thought leadership content via personal LinkedIn accounts of employees or executives to capture underpriced ad inventory and achieve better cost efficiency than classic company page ads.

Why It Works

Many large companies limit usage of employee accounts for ads, reducing demand and competition in this ad segment, lowering CPC and CPM. Such ads can produce higher engagement due to perceived authenticity and trusted voices.

When To Use

B2B companies where senior employees or thought leaders produce relevant content; when budget efficiency on LinkedIn Ads is important.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify personal LinkedIn accounts of thought leaders willing to promote content.
  2. Obtain permissions to run ads via these accounts or have them post organic content to amplify.
  3. Launch ads boosting thought leadership posts targeting defined buyer personas.
  4. Monitor reach and engagement relative to company page promotions.

Pitfalls & Limits

Employee willingness and brand policies may limit usage; potential reputational risks if the personal feed content does not align perfectly with brand messaging; requires careful audience targeting.

Example

Observed 2-4x better performance metrics vs. typical company page LinkedIn ads when amplifying thought leader content.

These 10 strategies represent specific, actionable SEO and paid advertising tactics extracted from the podcast transcript, focusing on LinkedIn ads, Google Ads setup for B2B, content marketing, and funnel building practices.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Focus on Bottom-of-Funnel (Transactional) Content

What It Is

Creating content specifically targeted at users ready to make a purchase or take a conversion action, such as product pages, detailed service documentation, and comparison guides.

Why It Works

Transactional keywords trigger user intent that is commercial and conversion-focused, which AI overviews and AI modes rely on less heavily for direct answers, meaning that users still click through to these pages. Also, such content is less competitive and higher converting.

When To Use

Ecommerce sites, SaaS businesses, service providers, or any site looking to directly convert visitors into customers or clients. Especially important as AI-generated search answers reduce clicks for informational content.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify bottom-of-funnel keywords with clear commercial intent.
  2. Create detailed product or service pages focused on benefits, features, pricing, and purchase guidance.
  3. Produce customer documentation and usage guides explaining various use cases of your products/services.
  4. Optimize content with transactional intent keywords and ensure clear calls to action.
  5. Regularly update content to maintain relevance and accuracy.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Not useful for purely informational topics with no intended transaction.
  • Excessive focus on transactional content without supporting top-of-funnel content can limit overall organic traffic growth.
  • Costs and effort in maintaining detailed documentation can be significant.

Example

The podcast host mentions a 13-hour course on creating transactional SEO content and notes it has “always been easier, faster, higher converting, less competitive,” emphasizing its ongoing importance with the rise of AI-powered search answers.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Create Extensive Documentation for Products and Services

What It Is

Developing comprehensive, clear, and structured documentation that explains every aspect of your products and services in detail.

Why It Works

AI search models rely on large corpora of transactional and technical content to understand and recommend products during AI-powered search sessions, especially in AI mode that provides conversational recommendations. More detailed documentation helps AI accurately recommend your offerings.

When To Use

SaaS companies, ecommerce businesses, and any organization with complex products or services that require explanation or multiple use cases.

Execution Steps

  1. Audit existing product/service pages and identify content gaps in FAQs, use cases, and technical details.
  2. Produce thorough, easy-to-understand guides, tutorials, and FAQs.
  3. Use structured data (schema) where appropriate to highlight product details.
  4. Keep documentation updated to reflect new features, updates, and user feedback.
  5. Promote links to this documentation internally and externally to increase crawlability and authority.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overly technical documentation without user-friendly language can alienate some audiences.
  • If documentation is shallow or incomplete, AI recommendations may overlook your products.
  • Labor-intensive to maintain as products and services evolve.

Example

Sundar Pachai explicitly states that AI relies on transactional content and large corpora of documentation to recommend products and services in AI mode.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Prioritize Unique Perspectives in Informational Content

What It Is

Creating informational content that offers unique insights, viewpoints, or analyses rather than generic summaries or widely available information.

Why It Works

AI overviews aggregate answers from top-ranking pages, which reduces clicks for standard informational content; unique content is harder for AI to replicate and more likely to attract clicks from users seeking differentiated value.

When To Use

Publisher websites, blogs, thought leadership sites, content marketing for brand awareness, and industries with competitive informational topics.

Execution Steps

  1. Research competitor informational content to identify gaps and common narratives.
  2. Develop original angles, personal stories, expert interviews, case studies, or data-driven analyses.
  3. Optimize content for relevant keywords but ensure depth and originality.
  4. Promote this content via social media, newsletters, and outreach to build engagement and backlinks.
  5. Monitor AI overview summaries to understand where your content is being sourced or overlooked.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Unique content demands more time and expertise to produce.
  • Highly niche or opinionated content might have a smaller audience.
  • Can be overshadowed if AI-generated answers satisfy users fully.

Example

The podcast notes that users are more likely to click on informational content with a unique perspective or content where AI is more likely to make errors.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leverage AI as Contextual Layer, Not Sole Content Focus

What It Is

Designing your SEO strategy and content creation to work alongside AI-powered search by providing depth and context that AI can use, rather than trying to compete against AI-generated summaries.

Why It Works

Google’s AI features provide summaries and context but still link users to the original content for deeper exploration. Ensuring your content supplies rich context encourages users to visit your site for more.

When To Use

All types of sites aiming to maintain organic visibility as AI search evolves, especially informational and educational sites.

Execution Steps

  1. Structure content to provide comprehensive answers with useful context and additional insights.
  2. Use headings, lists, examples, and multimedia to enrich the user experience and depth of content.
  3. Incorporate conversational or follow-up question content that AI might flag as useful.
  4. Combine SEO optimization with user engagement metrics to improve trustworthiness.
  5. Monitor AI feature updates to adapt content strategy accordingly.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Over-reliance on AI context may reduce direct traffic if users are satisfied with summaries.
  • Without continuous updates, content may be deprioritized as AI learns better sources.

Example

Sundar Pachai described AI as a layer providing context and summary while still linking out to the human-created web, encouraging exploration beyond the AI answer.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Ensure Accurate Tracking and Analytics for AI Referrals

What It Is

Implementing tracking solutions that can measure and attribute traffic and conversions coming from AI overview features and AI mode in search engines.

Why It Works

Without accurate tracking, publishers cannot measure AI-driven referral traffic, which undermines understanding of AI’s SEO impact and frustrates publishers reliant on this data for optimization and revenue.

When To Use

Publishers, affiliate marketers, ecommerce sites, and any site concerned about changes in traffic patterns due to AI search features.

Execution Steps

  1. Use URL parameters or structured URLs to track referral sources when possible.
  2. Monitor server logs for direct traffic patterns and user agents indicative of AI clicks.
  3. Use third-party analytics tools capable of detecting AI-generated traffic signals.
  4. Advocate for industry-wide standards for AI referral tracking with platforms like Google.
  5. Adjust SEO strategy based on insights from AI referral data.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Google currently delays or limits enabling accurate tracking of AI referrals, so data may be incomplete.
  • Over-interpretation of incomplete data can mislead strategy decisions.
  • Technical limitations may prevent perfect tracking currently.

Example

The podcast highlighted publisher skepticism due to Google’s delay in enabling accurate AI referral tracking, which undermines trust and the perceived value of the human-created web.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Schema Markup to Support AI Understanding

What It Is

Applying structured data (schema) to your site’s content to help search engines, including AI-powered models, better understand your content’s context, products, and services.

Why It Works

Structured data improves the clarity of content for AI models, increasing the likelihood of accurate inclusion in AI-generated responses and recommendations.

When To Use

Ecommerce sites, product pages, service providers, recipe sites, and any publisher wanting enhanced SERP features or AI recognition.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify relevant schema types according to your content (e.g., Product, FAQ, HowTo, Review).
  2. Implement schema markup using JSON-LD format embedded in your HTML.
  3. Validate schema using tools like Google Rich Results Test and Schema.org validators.
  4. Monitor performance via Google Search Console for errors and enhancements.
  5. Update schema regularly to reflect any changes in content or offerings.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Incorrect or excessive schema can cause errors and negative SEO impact.
  • Schema alone doesn’t guarantee AI inclusion but supports it as a signal.

Example

Although not explicitly detailed in the transcript, the emphasis on documentation and transactional content implies use of schema to help AI understand product/service context.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Adapt SEO for Mobile-First and Contextual Search Behavior

What It Is

Optimizing for mobile users and for search scenarios where users expect direct answers and contextual AI assistance rather than just traditional blue links.

Why It Works

Google moved away from the “10 blue links” format due to mobile user behavior and evolving technology, demanding content that delivers quick, comprehensive answers with easy exploration.

When To Use

Websites with significant mobile traffic, local SEO, voice search optimization, and content targeting information-seeking queries.

Execution Steps

  1. Implement responsive design and improve site speed on mobile devices.
  2. Structure content to provide concise answers and supplementary context.
  3. Incorporate featured snippets optimization techniques.
  4. Use question-and-answer formats to align with AI dialogue search models.
  5. Monitor and optimize for user engagement and satisfaction metrics on mobile.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Over-optimizing for snippets can lead to loss of deeper content ranking.
  • Some complex queries may not fit neatly into concise answer formats.

Example

Sundar Pachai explains the disappearance of the 10 blue links as a natural evolution linked to mobile growth and changing user expectations for search answers with context.

These strategies collectively reflect how SEO practitioners can adapt to Google’s evolving AI-powered search ecosystem by focusing on transactional content, comprehensive documentation, unique insights, and technical optimizations that align with AI’s requirements and user behavior shifts.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Avoid Niche Schema Markup

What It Is

Refrain from implementing highly specialized or niche schema types on your website, as they are often unsupported or ignored by Google.

Why It Works

Google’s algorithm does not guarantee the display of structured data, especially niche schema, and often chooses search features based on user-specific factors (location, device, history). Additionally, Google recently dropped support for several niche schema types due to low usage.

When To Use

Best for most websites including small businesses, bloggers, and general content sites where specialized schema is not prioritized by Google. Avoid for industries where niche schema is actively supported and verified to impact rich results.

Execution Steps

  1. Audit your current schema implementation using the Rich Results Test or Schema Markup Validator.
  2. Identify any niche schema types (e.g., book actions, course info, vehicle listing).
  3. Remove or replace unsupported niche schema with basic schema types like Article, Product, FAQ, or Review.
  4. Rely on page builders or plugins that provide standard schema by default.
  5. Monitor search appearance and click-through rates for changes after removal.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Adding niche schema consumes a lot of time with little to no payoff.
  • Google may not show your markup even if implemented correctly.
  • Removing niche schema may temporarily reduce certain rich features if Google supported them before.
  • Some specialized sites still might need niche schema but should verify Google support first.

Example

Google dropped support for seven niche structured data types, such as course info and vehicle listings, indicating the low value of niche schema investment.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Basic Schema via Page Builders/Plugins

What It Is

Implement foundational, standard schema types (e.g., Article, Breadcrumb, Product) through your website’s page builder or popular SEO plugins rather than custom coding.

Why It Works

Basic schema enhances Google's understanding of your content and can enable common rich results without heavy manual work. Popular content management tools automatically maintain and update these schemas reliably.

When To Use

Effective for most sites, especially small to medium-sized businesses, blogs, ecommerce stores using WordPress, Shopify, Wix, or other platforms with robust plugin support.

Execution Steps

  1. Choose a reputable SEO or schema plugin compatible with your platform (e.g., Yoast SEO, Rank Math for WordPress).
  2. Enable the plugin’s default schema settings or basic structured data options.
  3. Add core content types such as Articles, Products, FAQs, or Reviews via the plugin interface.
  4. Test your pages with Google’s Rich Results Test tool to confirm schema presence.
  5. Update your plugins regularly to maintain schema compliance and Google compatibility.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Over-reliance on plugins without understanding may cause misplaced or incomplete schema.
  • Plugins may add generic schema that isn't tailored to nuanced content, limiting maximum results.
  • Rarely useful if your business relies on rich, specialized data types unsupported by these tools.

Example

Most popular page builders and SEO plugins automatically add basic schema, reducing the need for manual input.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Do Not Rely on Schema for AI Search Visibility

What It Is

Avoid investing significant time into schema markup specifically aimed at improving visibility in AI-powered search tools or large language models (LLMs).

Why It Works

Google and other AI tools currently do not factor niche or advanced schema markup into AI search result algorithms, and no evidence shows schema drives AI-based content recommendations. Basic SEO and ranking factors remain the primary driver.

When To Use

When targeting AI search tools like ChatGPT, Gemini, or Perplexity for content discovery or traffic.

Execution Steps

  1. Focus on standard SEO best practices such as quality content, backlinks, and user experience rather than schema.
  2. Ensure basic schema is implemented but do not spend extra effort on complex or niche schema solely for AI visibility.
  3. Monitor AI tool coverage and exposure via analytics or direct queries, focusing on ranking improvements instead of markup.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overhyping advanced schema for AI and wasting resources on low-impact tasks.
  • Falling prey to fear-based marketing pushing unnecessary schema services.
  • Ignoring traditional SEO signals that actually influence AI search rankings.

Example

Article from Search Engine Journal and insights from SEO experts debunk the myth that niche schema increases AI search ranking.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Avoid or Cautiously Implement LLMs.txt Files

What It Is

Refrain from deploying the experimental llms.txt file on your website unless you can confidently implement and manage it without errors.

Why It Works

Currently, no AI system, including Google’s, uses llms.txt to crawl or index content, and poor execution may confuse language models or negatively impact AI-driven content referencing.

When To Use

If experimenting with AI content discoverability on new or enterprise websites where you have resources to manage advanced technical SEO, but generally avoid for most businesses.

Execution Steps

  1. Research the current official documentation and community consensus about llms.txt.
  2. If you decide to implement, generate the file methodically based on your sitemap or canonical URLs to avoid accidental inclusion of non-primary content.
  3. Avoid quick toggles or automated tools that create incomplete or markdown-based files.
  4. Monitor AI content references and user feedback for any unintended side effects.
  5. Stay updated on Google or AI ecosystem announcements regarding llms.txt adoption.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Currently useless as confirmed by John Mueller of Google.
  • Can be harmful when implemented poorly, e.g., exposing markdown files or irrelevant URLs to AI systems.
  • No ranking or AI visibility benefit exists yet.
  • Risk of confusing AI crawlers and damaging user experience in AI-generated content.

Example

Major SEO and content marketing companies like Moz, Semrush, HubSpot have not adopted llms.txt, highlighting its limited utility at this stage.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Focus on Ranking Signals Over Schema or LLMs.txt for AI Coverage

What It Is

Prioritize improving core ranking factors like PageRank, content quality, and backlinks rather than relying on niche schema or llms.txt files to achieve AI search visibility or inclusion.

Why It Works

AI-powered search tools commonly synthesize results based on existing rankings on traditional search engines, meaning ranking highly on Google influences AI content coverage more than specialized markup or files.

When To Use

Effective for all website types aiming for better organic visibility both on traditional and AI-powered search platforms.

Execution Steps

  1. Optimize on-page SEO (title tags, meta descriptions, content relevance, keyword targeting).
  2. Build authoritative backlinks to improve PageRank and domain authority.
  3. Produce high-quality, comprehensive, and user-friendly content to increase rankings.
  4. Monitor rankings on Google and corresponding AI platforms to assess overlap and AI visibility.
  5. Avoid distractions like unnecessary schema or experimental files unless clear benefit is confirmed.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Underestimating the importance of fundamentals may cause poor visibility on both Google and AI platforms.
  • Over-investment in technical gimmicks without ranking improvements wastes resources.
  • This strategy assumes you already have or can build good content and authority.

Example

The “King of SEO” case study where page ranking alone led AI tools to cite the page, without any schema or llms.txt.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Testing by Elimination to Validate Schema Impact

What It Is

Remove or disable schema markup to test whether it directly affects your site's rankings or visibility, instead of assuming positive outcomes from schema implementation.

Why It Works

Isolating variables helps identify the actual SEO impact of schema, preventing false attribution of ranking improvements that might be due to factors like branded searches or existing authority.

When To Use

When investing time and resources into schema markup on established sites, or when clients request proof of schema effectiveness.

Execution Steps

  1. Document the current state and performance metrics of your pages with schema active.
  2. Temporarily remove or disable schema markup on a test page or site section.
  3. Monitor rankings, traffic, and visibility changes over an appropriate period (1-2 weeks).
  4. Analyze results to determine if schema presence correlates with ranking improvements.
  5. Re-enable schema if beneficial; discontinue if it shows no impact.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Testing periods must be long enough to account for ranking fluctuations.
  • External variables (seasonality, algorithm updates) may confound results.
  • Some schema benefits may occur only in certain niches or for specific search features, limiting generalization.

Example

SEO professional tested removal of schema after a claim that it improved rankings; the user refused to remove schema for testing, indicating the need for such elimination tests.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Descriptive Image File Naming Convention

What It Is

Use clear, keyword-rich, and consistent naming conventions for your image files by incorporating the relevant page or post name and a descriptive phrase of the image.

Why It Works

Search engines use image file names as a ranking signal and to understand the context and content of the image, improving image and page SEO. Well-structured names also help AI and other indexing systems correctly classify and recommend your images.

When To Use

Ecommerce sites with product images, blogs, content-heavy sites, any website with many images needing contextual relevance.

Execution Steps

  1. Choose a clear folder structure that mirrors site sections (e.g., “articles,” “blog,” “products”).
  2. Name your image files using this format: [Section][Page-or-Post-Name][Image-Description].webp (e.g., articles_biggest-seo-opportunity_SER-example.webp).
  3. Use hyphens or underscores consistently to separate words.
  4. Convert images to lightweight, optimized formats like WebP for better performance.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Overly generic or random file names do not help.
  • Keyword stuffing in file names can appear spammy.
  • Changing existing file names without proper redirects can break existing links.

Example

The podcast host used “articles_biggest-seo-opportunity_SER-example.webp” as a file name to clearly describe the image and page context, aiding SEO and AI recommendations.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Optimized Alt Text with Target Keywords

What It Is

Add concise, descriptive alt text to images that explains the image content and includes relevant target keywords when appropriate, especially for the first image related to the main page topic.

Why It Works

Alt text improves accessibility for users and helps search engines understand the image’s subject, which influences both image search rankings and overall page relevance. Including keywords in alt text also enhances topical signals.

When To Use

All websites, especially ecommerce product images, blogs with informative images, and sites aiming for image and featured snippet visibility.

Execution Steps

  1. Locate the alt text field when uploading or editing images in your CMS or page builder.
  2. Write clear, precise descriptions of the image content first and foremost.
  3. If the image is closely related to a target keyword or phrase, incorporate that keyword naturally into the alt text, limiting this to key images to avoid spammy signals.
  4. Avoid keyword stuffing or overly generic alt text like “image1”.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Adding unrelated keywords can be penalized or reduce user experience.
  • Overusing keywords in alt text across multiple images can appear spammy.
  • Ignoring alt text altogether forfeits important ranking signals and accessibility benefits.

Example

The host uses target keywords in the first image’s alt text when the image matches the keyword focus, helping with SEO without spamming.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Contextual Page Optimization to Support Image SEO

What It Is

Optimize the page’s key SEO elements (title, URL slug, meta description, H1, and early page content) using target transactional or purchase-intent keywords that match the image content.

Why It Works

Search engines use page context to understand where and when to display images in results or AI-generated recommendations. Aligning page content and images helps reinforce relevance signals for both.

When To Use

Ecommerce product pages, content pages targeting buying keywords, and any site seeking enhanced image search visibility or AI recommendations.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify your main transactional or target keywords for the page.
  2. Include this keyword naturally in the page title, URL, meta description, and H1 heading.
  3. Mention the keyword early in the first sentence or paragraph of page content.
  4. Ensure images on this page visually represent or relate closely to these keywords and are properly named and alt tagged.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Having good image optimization on an irrelevant or poorly optimized page decreases effectiveness.
  • Overloading page content with keywords without user context reduces readability and may trigger penalties.
  • New sites without page authority may still struggle initially despite good optimization.

Example

Product pages with purchase-intent keywords in titles and URLs show better integration of their images in Google Images and AI search results.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Modern Lightweight Image Formats (WebP)

What It Is

Convert and upload images in modern, lightweight formats such as WebP that reduce file size without compromising quality.

Why It Works

Faster loading images improve user experience, reduce page load times, and contribute positively to page speed signals, which Google uses as a ranking factor. Efficient images also improve crawl efficiency and reduce bounce rates.

When To Use

All websites with images, particularly ecommerce and media-heavy sites where speed is critical.

Execution Steps

  1. Convert existing images to WebP format using image editing software or plugins.
  2. Replace legacy image formats (JPEG, PNG) with WebP on your site.
  3. Test images on multiple browsers to ensure compatibility and fallback where needed.
  4. Monitor core web vitals and page performance metrics to gauge impact.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Compatibility issues on older browsers require fallback images.
  • Conversion tools may reduce image quality if settings are too aggressive.
  • Not all CMS or plugins support WebP out-of-the-box.

Example

The host strongly recommends WebP for all SEO images due to its lightweight features and positive SEO impact.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Host Images on Higher-Quality Hosting Environments

What It Is

Use premium or dedicated hosting rather than cheap shared hosting to serve your website and images.

Why It Works

Experiments show that sites on dedicated IPs and premium servers tend to rank better, likely due to association of low-quality shared hosting with spammy sites. Better hosting can enhance site speed, uptime, and overall quality signals to search engines.

When To Use

Medium to large-scale ecommerce stores, enterprise sites, and sites where SEO is a critical business driver.

Execution Steps

  1. Evaluate your current hosting environment and its performance.
  2. Migrate to a reputable hosting provider offering dedicated IPs or premium shared hosting options.
  3. Ensure your site speed and uptime improve post-migration via monitoring tools.
  4. Confirm that images load reliably and fast from the new host.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Dedicated hosting can be more costly; small budget sites may not see proportional benefits.
  • Migration risks like downtime or broken links if not planned carefully.
  • Hosting alone doesn’t guarantee rankings; site content and SEO must still be strong.

Example

Referenced experiment from seoserpa.com showed 80-90% of top results ranking on dedicated IP addresses rather than cheap shared hosting.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Images to Enhance Brand Awareness and User Engagement

What It Is

Leverage recognizable or branded images in your content and social media to build brand recognition and keep users engaged through image search and AI platforms.

Why It Works

Images help users recall brands visually and encourage deeper site exploration, which can lead to higher user engagement, brand discovery, and eventually conversions. Google and AI frequently show images, amplifying potential brand exposure.

When To Use

Ecommerce brands, personal brands, social media-driven businesses, and sites targeting customers in the discovery or informational stage of the buyer journey.

Execution Steps

  1. Include your brand name or unique visual elements in images where appropriate.
  2. Use images in AI and social media-friendly formats to encourage sharing.
  3. Upload images optimized with great file names and alt text to increase chances in image search and AI results.
  4. Encourage discovery by connecting images across multiple pages/products.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Over-branding images may distract from key information if not balanced well.
  • Brands with less visual recognition may see little direct impact.
  • Images alone don’t convert without quality supporting content.

Example

The host described using a known agency’s image in the podcast and how it boosted recognition and engagement, illustrating image-driven brand awareness.

These six strategies comprehensively capture the actionable image SEO tactics discussed in the transcript. Each is standalone and provides clear, practical advice for improving SEO via images.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Remove or Update Thin, Outdated Content

What It Is

Identify and either remove or update pages that are outdated and contain very little content (under 100 words).

Why It Works

Google de-indexes pages that provide poor user value—thin, outdated content lowers site quality signals and wastes crawl budget. Keeping only quality content helps maintain or improve indexation and rankings.

When To Use

Sites with large content inventories, especially older blogs or ecommerce catalogs with outdated product pages. Useful in ongoing site maintenance and technical SEO cleanup.

Execution Steps

  1. Audit site to find pages with very low word count and/or those not updated recently.
  2. Evaluate user value: if the content provides little or no value, mark for removal or consolidation.
  3. For pages that can be updated, refresh content to add substantial, valuable, original information.
  4. Remove removed pages with proper 301 redirects or canonical tags to avoid broken links.
  5. Resubmit updated sitemap to Google Search Console.

Pitfalls & Limits

Removing pages without proper redirects can cause loss of link equity. Simply expanding thin content without improving quality or user intent can be ineffective. Does not solve ranking issues for inherently low-value topics.

Example

The transcript mentions that pages getting de-indexed are mostly “bad pages” with shallow content, and that good pages rarely get de-indexed.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Target Transactional Keywords Over Informational Ones

What It Is

Focus SEO efforts on keywords where searchers are looking to buy or take commercial action rather than only providing informational content.

Why It Works

Transactional keywords typically have less competition, require shorter content (~400-500 words), need fewer or no backlinks, and attract higher-converting, qualified traffic because users have stronger purchase intent. AI overviews impact mostly informational queries, so transactional queries offer more stable organic opportunities.

When To Use

Ecommerce sites, service providers, local businesses, and any sites aiming to drive conversions and sales. Particularly effective for newer or lower-authority sites.

Execution Steps

  1. Conduct keyword research to identify bottom-of-funnel transactional keywords relevant to your niche.
  2. Create dedicated pages targeting each transactional keyword with concise, focused content (~400-500 words).
  3. Optimize on-page elements like title tags, meta descriptions, headers, and call-to-action.
  4. Launch pages gradually—about 10 to 15 new transactional pages per month suggested for scaling.
  5. Promote these pages to drive engagement and natural backlinks within niche communities.
  6. Monitor rankings, traffic, and conversions, and iterate content or targeting as needed.

Pitfalls & Limits

Underestimating keyword intent and mistakenly targeting informational queries can reduce ROI. Low search volume for niche transactional terms may require larger content breadth. Scalability should be tempered to avoid mass low-value content production.

Example

The speaker put out hundreds of such pages starting in 2019 and consistently ranked quickly even with low domain authority, resulting in user acquisition and requests for product features.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Scale Up AI-Generated Content Slowly with Human Review

What It Is

Use AI tools to create content at a controlled pace and apply rigorous human editing to ensure quality and compliance, rather than mass spamming AI content at high velocity.

Why It Works

Google is increasingly penalizing websites that publish large volumes of low-quality AI-generated content rapidly. Slow scaling and human review reduce the risk of penalties and align content with user needs and Google's quality standards.

When To Use

For content teams leveraging AI writing tools across blogs, ecommerce, or transactional landing pages, especially in competitive niches or on sites with existing SEO risk sensitivity.

Execution Steps

  1. Create AI content in manageable batches (e.g., no more than 10-15 pages/month).
  2. Perform heavy human review for factual accuracy, original insight, and natural language tone.
  3. Regularly update and maintain published AI content based on performance and feedback.
  4. Monitor Google Search Console and ranking reports for signs of penalty or drop.
  5. Combine AI content with genuine marketing efforts to drive engagement and sharing.

Pitfalls & Limits

Rapid mass publishing of AI content without editing leads to penalties. Over-reliance on AI without adding value risks ranking drops. This approach requires resource investment in reviewing content despite AI assistance.

Example

The speaker recommends a steady output pace and notes doing 10-15 transactional AI-assisted pages in a month with good marketing results and no penalties.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Optimize Content for User Intent, Especially Before Scrolling

What It Is

Align content closely with user search intent so that the most relevant information is visible “above the fold” or immediately, satisfying user needs quickly to reduce bounce and improve engagement.

Why It Works

Google’s algorithms reward pages that satisfy user intent and keep users engaged. Quick content relevance reduces pogo-sticking and improves dwell time, supporting higher rankings and click-through rates.

When To Use

Any website targeting both informational and transactional keywords, especially important for mobile and voice search where quick answers are preferred.

Execution Steps

  1. Analyze SERP intent and user behavior for target keywords.
  2. Craft headlines and opening paragraphs that directly answer user questions or present key transactional info upfront.
  3. Use clear formatting, bullet points, and visuals to enhance scannability.
  4. Test page layout on multiple devices for immediate clarity and value.
  5. Measure user engagement metrics like bounce rate and time on page to optimize further.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overloading above-the-fold content with ads or irrelevant info can hurt UX. Ignoring deeper content can reduce value for users seeking more detail. Some queries require longer explorations that can’t be compressed too much.

Example

The speaker states that providing users what they want before they start scrolling leads to satisfying search intent and maintaining good click rates despite evolving search rules.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Build Topical Authority via Consistent Publishing and Engagement

What It Is

Develop a strong niche authority by regularly publishing relevant, high-quality content targeting closely related topics and encouraging user sharing and natural link acquisition.

Why It Works

Topical authority signals to search engines that a site is a go-to resource in its field, improving rankings across multiple keywords and reducing dependence on backlinks alone. Engagement and sharing amplify organic reach and generate authoritative links.

When To Use

Medium to large sites with resources for consistent content creation, covering niches with established competition or informational ecosystems. Also effective for ecommerce blogs or service-based businesses.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify core topics within your niche and relevant transactional keywords.
  2. Plan a content calendar with regular publishing cadence (weekly/monthly).
  3. Promote content through social media, newsletters, and influencer outreach to increase shares.
  4. Monitor performance and adjust content topics based on user interest and ranking evolution.
  5. Engage with your audience via comments or forums to build community trust and gather link opportunities.

Pitfalls & Limits

Sporadic publishing undermines authority building. Poor-quality or irrelevant content dilutes topical relevance. Pure reliance on topical authority without on-page optimization can limit gains.

Example

The speaker notes that by doing good marketing alongside transactional content, they get shares in relevant language, generating “enough links” naturally, making backlink-building easier and more worthwhile.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use 400–500 Word Focused Pages for Niche Transactional Keywords

What It Is

Create relatively short, concise pages of about 400 to 500 words focusing tightly on specific, low-competition transactional keywords.

Why It Works

Many transactional queries require straightforward product/service information, which can be effectively communicated in shorter content. Shorter pages are quicker to produce and easier to scale, while still ranking well for niche terms where user intent is clear.

When To Use

Sites seeking to rapidly expand content breadth for long-tail transactional keywords; startups or low-authority domains targeting bottom-of-funnel keywords.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify low-competition long-tail transactional keywords with buyer intent.
  2. Write a dedicated page around each keyword, including product/service details, benefits, pricing, and calls to action within ~400-500 words.
  3. Optimize title tags, H1, and meta descriptions to include the target keyword.
  4. Publish and internally link from relevant pages.
  5. Promote via niche marketing efforts for engagement and linking.

Pitfalls & Limits

Trying to rank short pages for highly competitive, broad transactional keywords can fail. Overly generic or thin 400-word pages without meaningful content won’t rank. Such pages work best when tightly focused on clear intent.

Example

The speaker has been using this approach since 2019 with great success across niches, ranking fast and driving valuable user contacts even with low domain authority.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Monitor and Adjust to Indexation and Traffic Anomalies Using Google Search Console

What It Is

Use data from Google Search Console to track index coverage, impressions, and clicks, analyzing patterns like rising impressions but falling clicks, and adjust content strategy accordingly.

Why It Works

Monitoring indexing and user interaction metrics helps detect issues like content de-indexing, AI-generated summary impacts, or changes in user behavior, enabling proactive SEO adjustments.

When To Use

Continuous SEO audits, especially for sites experiencing traffic fluctuations or indexing issues. Important for larger sites and agencies managing multiple domains.

Execution Steps

  1. Regularly review index coverage reports to identify de-indexed pages.
  2. Compare impression vs. click data to detect rising impressions but falling clicks.
  3. Investigate causes, such as AI overviews or thin content.
  4. Refresh or remove poor-performing pages and emphasize transactional content where clicks hold steady.
  5. Use findings to adjust content focus, production velocity, and engagement strategies.

Pitfalls & Limits

Misinterpretation of data (e.g., ignoring external factors like seasonality) can lead to wrong conclusions. GSC data delays and sampling may produce incomplete pictures.

Example

The transcript discusses many users reporting mass de-indexing of thin content pages and a 34.5% click drop attributed to AI overviews, highlighting the importance of monitoring these signals.

These 7 strategies represent the core actionable SEO tactics conveyed in the podcast transcript.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

130-Day Crawl Frequency Indexation Rule

What It Is

Google tends to de-index pages that have not been crawled for 130 days or more, removing them from the index even if they were previously indexed.

Why It Works

Google’s crawl budget and index storage are limited and managed to optimize resources. Pages not crawled within 130 days are considered low-value or unlikely to improve, leading to their removal to reduce operational costs.

When To Use

This is relevant for all websites aiming to maintain their indexed pages, especially large sites with many pages, frequently updated content sites, and ecommerce platforms with changing inventories.

Execution Steps

  1. Use tools like Screaming Frog connected to Google Search Console API to analyze crawl frequency and indexation status.
  2. Identify pages not crawled in the last 130 days.
  3. Audit these pages for quality, content richness, and site importance.
  4. Improve content quality and internal linking to increase crawl frequency.
  5. Re-submit improved pages for indexing and monitor their crawl status regularly.

Pitfalls & Limits

Not all pages uncrawled for 130 days are de-indexed, and some de-indexing may happen for other reasons. This rule applies mainly to technically indexable pages. Attempting to keep junk or thin-content pages indexed by artificially increasing crawl frequency wastes effort.

Example

In multiple case studies (tire manufacturer in Portugal, French sports news site, Italian fashion magazine, corporate forum site, French government site), pages not crawled for 130 days were consistently removed from the Google index.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Crawl Frequency Improvement Through Content Quality Enhancement

What It Is

Improving the quality of pages that are not being crawled often can increase their crawl frequency and likelihood of staying indexed.

Why It Works

Google allocates crawl resources based on perceived content quality and page importance, so higher-quality pages are crawled more frequently. Google search analyst Gary Ilas confirms that increased quality signals lead to higher crawl demand.

When To Use

For pages that have stopped being crawled regularly or are in danger of de-indexation, especially those identified as thin content, duplicate, or low-value. Useful for media sites, ecommerce category pages, or sites with user-generated content.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify pages with low crawl frequency or nearing the 130-day limit.
  2. Analyze content for thinness, duplications, lack of product or differentiating detail.
  3. Add unique, valuable, and comprehensive content to these pages.
  4. Optimize metadata and user experience to improve engagement signals.
  5. Monitor crawl frequency after updates and adjust as necessary.

Pitfalls & Limits

Simply adding filler or non-unique content may not improve crawl frequency. Quality improvements must be meaningful and relevant. Pages blocked by robots.txt, noindex tags, or canonicalized elsewhere won’t benefit.

Example

In the case studies, category pages with insufficient differentiation, social-media-focused short content, and similar-tag pages improved crawlability after enrichment.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Using Screaming Frog SEO Spider Connected to Google Search Console API for Indexation Audit

What It Is

Crawling your website with Screaming Frog integrated with Google Search Console API to get detailed data about indexation status, last crawl date, and coverage issues at scale.

Why It Works

Manual URL inspection in Google Search Console is slow and limited; API integration allows for automated, bulk retrieval of crawl and indexation data enabling data-driven decisions.

When To Use

For medium to large websites needing detailed and scalable indexation audits, developers and SEOs needing to track crawl behavior and indexation health across many pages.

Execution Steps

  1. Obtain Screaming Frog’s paid version (free allows up to 500 URLs).
  2. In Screaming Frog, go to Configuration > API Access > Google Search Console, and connect your Google Search Console account.
  3. Enable URL inspection API options: enable URL inspection and ignore non-indexable URLs.
  4. Start crawling your website.
  5. Analyze the “Google Search Console” tab in Screaming Frog for columns like indexation status, last crawl date, days since last crawl, and coverage issues.
  6. Export data and sort/filter by days since last crawl to identify problematic pages.

Pitfalls & Limits

Limited to 2,000 URL inspections per day per property (can be mitigated by creating multiple properties). Requires technical knowledge to set up and interpret data.

Example

The article’s author used this setup to discover the 130-day de-indexing rule across multiple types of websites.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Monitoring Crawl Depth and Internal Linking to Preserve Page Importance

What It Is

Analyze the site’s internal linking structure and reduce crawl depth (number of clicks from homepage) to ensure important pages are crawled more frequently and remain indexed.

Why It Works

Google’s crawl budget and PageRank flow are influenced by how easily a page can be reached; deep pages with few internal links appear less important and get crawled less frequently.

When To Use

Large websites with complex structures, sites with deep product categories, or content buried deeply in the hierarchy that risk being de-indexed.

Execution Steps

  1. Use site crawling tools to map page depth (click distance from homepage).
  2. Identify pages that are too deep or receive few internal links.
  3. Restructure site navigation and internal linking to bring key pages closer to homepage or more accessible.
  4. Use internal links with relevant anchor text pointing to important pages.
  5. Monitor crawl frequency and indexation changes post-optimization.

Pitfalls & Limits

Over-linking or irrelevant internal links can confuse users and dilute PageRank. Structural changes should maintain usability and user experience.

Example

In cases mentioned, pages with high crawl depth were prone to de-indexing; improving their internal link profiles helped maintain crawl frequency.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Cross-Referencing Server Log Files with Crawl Data to Identify Non-Indexed Pages

What It Is

Analyze server log files alongside crawl data to identify pages Googlebot has not visited in over 130 days, indicating likely de-indexation.

Why It Works

Googlebot’s presence in log files directly shows crawling activity. Pages unvisited despite being crawled by tools are signals of de-indexation or crawl prioritization issues.

When To Use

For all sites aiming for a comprehensive audit of crawl activity and indexation status, especially sites with large numbers of dynamic or evolving pages.

Execution Steps

  1. Ask your hosting provider or development team to export raw server log files for at least 130 days.
  2. Obtain crawl data from tools like Screaming Frog or Google Search Console API.
  3. Cross-reference the URLs crawled by your SEO tool with the URLs visited by Googlebot in your log files.
  4. Identify pages missing from logs but present in the crawl data as uncrawled by Google.
  5. Investigate those pages for content quality, crawlability, and indexing issues.

Pitfalls & Limits

Requires technical ability to parse and analyze server logs. Log files can be large and complex. Not all user agents in logs are Googlebot—must filter accurately.

Example

The article recommends this method as one of the most reliable ways to measure crawl frequency and predict de-indexation.

These five fully detailed, actionable strategies capture the core SEO tactics and insights presented in the transcript.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Remove Noindex Tags After Staging to Production

What It Is

Ensure that when a website moves from staging to production, any noindex tags used to block staging from search engines are removed so the live site is indexed.

Why It Works

Noindex tags prevent search engines from crawling and indexing pages. Leaving a noindex tag on a production site makes it invisible in search results, killing traffic and SEO value.

When To Use

Critical for small and medium businesses (SMBs) launching new websites or relaunching existing ones; applies broadly to all website migrations or launches involving staging environments.

Execution Steps

  1. Before launch, add noindex to staging to block indexing.
  2. On launch day, remove all noindex tags from live pages.
  3. Verify robots.txt does not block crawling.
  4. Use tools like Google Search Console to check which pages are indexed.
  5. Monitor indexation in the following weeks to confirm pages are visible.

Pitfalls & Limits

Forgetting to remove noindex frequently happens, causing serious downtime and traffic loss. Be sure to check canonical tags as well to avoid accidentally canonicalizing to staging URLs.

Example

A small site went offline for a weekend after launch due to noindex left on, losing rankings temporarily until corrected.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Correct Canonicalization After Site Launch or Migration

What It Is

Update canonical tags from staging URLs to production URLs to correctly signal the preferred version of pages to search engines.

Why It Works

Canonical tags prevent duplicate content issues and consolidate ranking signals by identifying the “master” URL for content. Using staging URLs as canonical on production causes indexing and ranking confusion.

When To Use

Essential during site migrations, relaunches, and large ecommerce product variant setups to avoid duplicate content.

Execution Steps

  1. Audit pages for canonical tags referencing staging or outdated URLs.
  2. Update canonical tags to production URLs.
  3. Ensure canonical tags point to self or relevant preferred production URL.
  4. Monitor Search Console for canonicalization warnings.

Pitfalls & Limits

Not all canonical issues directly cause rankings drops but ignoring them can create indexing inefficiencies and dilute link equity, especially problematic on large scale ecommerce sites with many variants.

Example

Correcting canonicals led to a site regaining rankings within days in a small SMB site referenced by the speaker.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Optimize and Compress Images for Speed and SEO

What It Is

Reduce image file sizes and use modern formats (WebP), descriptive, concise alt text, and keyword-relevant file names to improve page load times and SEO signals.

Why It Works

Faster page load times improve user experience and reduce bounce rates, factors directly influencing rankings. Alt text and file names help search engines understand image content and contribute to keyword relevance.

When To Use

Universal for all types of websites, especially large ecommerce or media-rich sites where images dominate page weight.

Execution Steps

  1. Use image optimization tools to compress images without visible quality loss.
  2. Convert images to WebP or other next-gen formats.
  3. Name image files with concise, relevant keywords matching the page context.
  4. Write brief, descriptive alt text focused on actual content without fluff.
  5. Implement lazy loading if applicable.

Pitfalls & Limits

Over-compressing can degrade user experience. Keyword stuffing in alt text can look spammy to search engines. Avoid generic or fluffy descriptions.

Example

Speaker cited examples of big brands with 1.8MB homepage images that could be optimized for better performance.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Target Bottom-of-Funnel Purchase Intent Keywords ("Compact Keywords")

What It Is

Focus SEO efforts on creating many concise, conversion-focused pages targeting keywords that signal clear buying intent rather than broad informational searches.

Why It Works

Bottom-funnel keywords often have lower search volume but higher conversion rates, providing better ROI and sales more reliably than informational keywords. Such pages perform well in rankings and revenue generation.

When To Use

Best for ecommerce, SMBs, and direct-to-consumer businesses aiming for higher sales conversions with SEO.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify compact keywords with clear transactional or commercial intent.
  2. Create short (approx. 400 words) focused pages directly selling or promoting the product/service.
  3. Include calls-to-action and incentives to convert.
  4. Optimize page titles, meta descriptions, and on-page content for these keywords.
  5. Track performance and adjust based on conversion data.

Pitfalls & Limits

Not suitable for brand awareness or top-of-funnel informational content. Over-focusing on transactional keywords can narrow reach.

Example

Speaker referenced a proprietary course “Compact Keywords” showing pages with ~415 words converting better than traditional long-form content, generating sustained sales at lower effort.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leverage User-Generated Content (UGC) for Informational SEO

What It Is

Use and optimize user-generated content from platforms like Reddit, YouTube transcripts, TikTok, Instagram Reels, and forums as a source of genuine, raw informational content favored by AI assistants and search engines.

Why It Works

UGC provides authentic, diverse third-party perspectives and a wide range of content that AI models and search engines increasingly trust and use, especially as traditional informational content on websites declines.

When To Use

Useful for brands in consumer niches, community-heavy markets, and informational-focused sites trying to rank for long-tail or complex queries.

Execution Steps

  1. Encourage users to create and share content on owned platforms or communities.
  2. Aggregate or embed relevant UGC (reviews, comments, Q&A) on your site.
  3. Ensure proper schema markup to highlight UGC to search engines.
  4. Monitor and moderate content quality.
  5. Keep content fresh and updated.

Pitfalls & Limits

Risk of spam and low-quality content if not moderated properly. Some UGC might not fit brand voice or cause compliance issues.

Example

Speaker discussed Google’s acquisition of Reddit and the rise of AI training on social UGC as a shift away from traditional owned informational content.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use MCP (Memory Control Plane) AI Agents to Aggregate and Analyze SEO Data

What It Is

Integrate multiple SEO data sources (Search Console, Semrush, Screaming Frog, etc.) into an MCP AI agent to enable conversational queries and actionable insights across datasets.

Why It Works

Aggregating multilayered SEO data in one AI-driven knowledge base allows faster, smarter decision-making and keyword prioritization without manual spreadsheet work. It turns raw data into strategy conversations.

When To Use

Effective for technical SEOs and agencies working with multiple clients or big data sets who want to speed up keyword analysis and reporting.

Execution Steps

  1. Export relevant SEO data from multiple sources (search console, rank trackers, crawlers).
  2. Configure an MCP server or use a platform that supports MCP.
  3. Upload all SEO data to the MCP.
  4. Connect an AI assistant (e.g., Claude) with access to the MCP.
  5. Query the AI conversationally for keyword recommendations, performance summaries, and auditing insights.

Pitfalls & Limits

Requires initial setup and technical knowledge; AI hallucinations still require human verification. Overreliance without expertise may cause errors.

Example

Speaker referenced Richard Baxter’s post on using MCP with Search Console and Claude to pick insights within minutes instead of extended manual analysis.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Produce Concise, Clear Text Content Tailored for LLM (Large Language Model) Consumption

What It Is

Write website and alt text content that is concise, benefit-focused, and straightforward without fluffy or overly emotional language to improve interpretation by AI-based search and recommendation engines.

Why It Works

LLMs prefer clear, concise, and direct content as it allows better comprehension and extraction of key information for assisting users. Fluffy or vague content confuses AI and diminishes SEO value.

When To Use

Critical for all websites wanting to perform well in AI-driven search results and voice search. Particularly useful for product pages and service descriptions.

Execution Steps

  1. Use simple sentences focusing first on benefits, then features.
  2. Avoid jargon, fluffy phrases, and vague claims.
  3. Keep alt text short but descriptive, prioritizing essential info.
  4. Use keywords naturally in titles and file names.
  5. Review and edit to remove unnecessary filler.

Pitfalls & Limits

Over-simplifying can reduce user engagement. Balance is needed to maintain human readability and appeal alongside LLM-friendliness.

Example

Speaker contrasts verbose startup “about us” pages with effective concise pages that state plainly what the business does, optimized for LLM comprehension.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Implement LLM.txt File to Guide AI Models on Important Site Content

What It Is

Create and upload an llms.txt file (similar to robots.txt) that provides a concise sitemap or overview of your site’s most important pages and content to assist AI in finding and understanding your site better.

Why It Works

LLMs need guidance to crawl, digest, and prioritize site content relevant to queries. llms.txt can act as a ‘first view’ for AI, improving the likelihood of your best content being used in AI-powered search and answer generation.

When To Use

Effective for medium to large sites wanting early adoption and advantage in AI-driven search. Works well alongside structured data and traditional SEO.

Execution Steps

  1. Create an llms.txt file listing cornerstone and recent important URLs.
  2. Keep the file concise—not a full XML sitemap—focusing on key content only.
  3. Upload the file to the root directory (e.g., yourdomain.com/llms.txt).
  4. Optionally, update regularly to reflect new cornerstone or priority content.
  5. Monitor for adoption and signals from AI search platforms.

Pitfalls & Limits

Still experimental with limited adoption; can be abused by overstuffing URLs. Should not replace existing sitemaps or structured data.

Example

Speaker cited Yoast’s manual llms.txt and the massive (96,500 word) llms.txt from Search Engine Land as two different approaches to show variability in adoption.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Prioritize Brand Building and Word-of-Mouth in SEO Strategy

What It Is

Shift SEO focus toward enhancing brand presence and encouraging natural mentions and user engagement rather than manipulating traditional link-building tactics.

Why It Works

With AI and search evolving beyond links, the ‘word-of-mouth’ effect becomes a powerful trust and relevance signal to search engines, mimicking offline marketing trust dynamics online.

When To Use

Crucial for all businesses, especially SMBs and those facing declining returns from traditional link-building.

Execution Steps

  1. Create authentic brand experiences and engage customers.
  2. Encourage genuine user reviews, shares, and social mentions.
  3. Avoid manipulative link building in favor of earning natural links.
  4. Monitor branded search volume as a key KPI.
  5. Align SEO messaging consistently with brand values across channels.

Pitfalls & Limits

Slow build; requires broader marketing and outreach. Not directly measurable like links in the short term.

Example

Speaker contrasted old link-building reliance with future SEO’s emphasis on brand signals and third-party perspectives.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Focus SEO Content on Combining Multiple Search Intents (Informational + Commercial + Transactional)

What It Is

Develop content that addresses several types of user search intent simultaneously to meet broader user needs and provide incentives for conversion within informative content.

Why It Works

With changing search behavior and AI filtering, users expect assistance not only answering questions but guiding buying decisions, requiring blended content to satisfy search engines and users alike.

When To Use

Ideal for ecommerce, SaaS, or complex buying cycles where users research and purchase on-site.

Execution Steps

1. Analyze keywords for mixed intent signals.  
2. Create content that provides detailed information plus clear calls-to-action or purchase guidance.  
3. Embed incentives (discounts, trial info, demos) while answering informative queries.  
4. Use structured data to highlight commercial intent.  
5. Update content regularly based on evolving user behavior data.

Pitfalls & Limits

Risk of confusing LLMs or users if intent mix isn’t seamless. Improper balance can reduce clarity or conversion potential.

Example

Speaker described that ads are beginning to integrate more with such content, requiring SEO to evolve likewise.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use AI Tools for Content Ideation and Titles But Maintain Human Oversight

What It Is

Use AI language models like ChatGPT 4.0 to generate content ideas, headlines, and titles, then evaluate and select the best outputs manually to improve click-through and engagement.

Why It Works

AI provides volume and diversity of options quickly, but manual curation ensures quality, brand voice consistency, and prevents AI’s generic or off-brand suggestions from being published.

When To Use

Useful for content marketers, podcasters, and bloggers producing frequent content looking to scale ideation workflows.

Execution Steps

1. Provide AI with transcripts or content summaries.  
2. Generate multiple title ideas (10+ recommended).  
3. Manually review and select the most compelling titles.  
4. Optionally test titles via A/B testing or feedback from team.  
5. Use AI to also suggest thumbnails or related content with manual refinement.

Pitfalls & Limits

Blindly using AI-generated titles without review can harm brand reputation. Some AI platforms may produce casual or off-tone suggestions needing editing.

Example

Speaker uses ChatGPT 4.0 to generate 90% of podcast titles and credits better engagement with AI-generated titles compared to self-written ones.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Monitor and Avoid Risks of Scaled AI-Generated Content and Black Hat SEO

What It Is

Be cautious with mass-produced AI content and aggressive black hat tactics (e.g., link spam, link buying, blackhat scaled content) that may cause penalties in evolving AI-powered SEO algorithms.

Why It Works

Search engines increasingly identify unnatural patterns in backlinks and AI content, displaying or penalizing sites involved with manipulative practices. Trust and quality signals take precedence.

When To Use

Critical for all SEOs, especially in competitive verticals with temptation to shortcut SEO efforts.

Execution Steps

1. Avoid bulk AI content generation without quality review.  
2. Monitor Google Search Console for manual actions and unusual traffic spikes.  
3. Avoid unnatural link acquisition strategies with no branded search growth.  
4. Invest in genuine content creation and organic promotion instead.  
5. Stay updated with Google’s latest algorithm changes on AI and link spam.

Pitfalls & Limits

Risk of domain penalization or deindexing; short-term gains often offset by long-term losses. Not sustainable for trusted brands.

Example

Speaker warned of properties penalized for AI and manipulative link building, emphasizing it as a risky long-term strategy.

Note: The above strategies synthesize the actionable SEO insights discussed, with no generic filler or outputs that assume prior knowledge from the transcript. Each entry can stand alone for SEO professionals to apply directly.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Homepage for Brand Authority and User Navigation

What It Is

Use the homepage primarily to establish brand authority, build trust, and guide visitors to deeper, keyword-targeted pages rather than trying to rank it for multiple keywords.

Why It Works

Google expects homepages to reflect brand identity and provide a good user experience, rather than targeting many keywords simultaneously. A focused homepage encourages backlinks due to its credibility and directs users effectively, increasing engagement and conversions.

When To Use

All websites, particularly brand-focused sites, affiliate sites, and businesses with multiple product or service pages. Essential for medium to large sites and those aiming for strong topical authority.

Execution Steps

  • Design the homepage to showcase brand elements such as logos, testimonials, product/service screenshots, and FAQs.
  • Include clear calls to action and internal links directing users to specific product, service, or blog pages.
  • Avoid keyword stuffing or targeting many unrelated keywords on the homepage.
  • Focus content on establishing trust, credibility, and brand recognition.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Trying to cram many keywords or multiple thin content sections on the homepage reduces topical focus and confuses users and search engines.
  • Creating a homepage that acts like a shallow landing page for many keywords results in poor rankings and weak user experience.

Example

The transcript contrasts outdated homepages full of multiple H2 subheadings each targeting different keywords with current best practice emphasizing homepage branding and navigation.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Target Keywords with Specific, Dedicated Pages

What It Is

Create individual pages that each target a single, focused keyword or closely related set of keywords instead of targeting many keywords on the homepage or a single page.

Why It Works

Google favors pages that provide in-depth, specific content matching user intent. Dedicated pages have better topical relevance, are easier to optimize, and offer a stronger user experience.

When To Use

All site types aiming for keyword ranking gains, especially ecommerce, local SEO, and content-rich sites. Ideal for new or existing websites expanding keyword targeting.

Execution Steps

  • Research target keywords and group them by relevance and intent.
  • Create a unique page for each target keyword or keyword cluster.
  • Develop comprehensive, quality content on that page that satisfies the search intent fully.
  • Include internal links from the homepage and related pages to these keyword-targeted pages.
  • Optimize URL structure and on-page SEO elements (titles, headers, meta descriptions) for the target keyword.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Creating thin or shallow content pages with only minimal text will not satisfy search intent or rank well.
  • Avoid keyword cannibalization by not creating multiple pages targeting the same keyword.
  • Poor internal linking or navigation can hide these pages from both users and search engines.

Example

The transcript states that thin one-paragraph blurbs below H2s on a homepage are ineffective and the best way is to have dedicated pages for each keyword.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Avoid Exact Match Domains (EMDs) for Keyword Targeting

What It Is

Do not rely on owning domains that exactly match your target keywords; avoid using such EMDs as a primary keyword ranking strategy.

Why It Works

Recent Google algorithm updates and leaks reveal that EMDs can be actively demoted as they are associated with spammy keyword stuffing practices. Also, EMDs limit branding flexibility and the breadth of keyword targeting.

When To Use

Businesses evaluating domain strategies, especially local SEO and ecommerce sites considering keyword-rich domains. Most relevant when deciding domain names for new sites.

Execution Steps

  • Choose a brandable domain rather than an exact match keyword domain.
  • Focus on building topical authority and keyword-targeted content on dedicated pages instead.
  • If using an EMD, understand it will likely only rank for the narrow set of keywords in the domain name and may face algorithm demotion risks.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Using an EMD limits you to variations of that keyword and reduces your ability to expand keyword targeting.
  • An EMD domain is often viewed as spammy by search algorithms, reducing ranking potential.
