Fixing inconsistencies in a law firm’s business name across all signals led to the site obtaining a Google Knowledge Panel, improving brand visibility.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Strategic Use of Trusted Press Mentions and Knowledge Graph Sites for Trust Building

What It Is

Building trust and authority by securing links and mentions from authoritative websites that are already part of or recognized by Google's Knowledge Graph (e.g., Wikipedia, LinkedIn, high-authority press sites).

Why It Works

Connections from trusted entities that Google recognizes in its Knowledge Graph boost brand/entity trust signals which can help improve overall domain authority and ranking potential.

When To Use

New websites, rebranding efforts, brands looking to gain E-A-T signals, local businesses aiming to increase trust.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify authoritative sites related to your industry or brand that participate in the Knowledge Graph.  
  2. Secure placements such as Wikipedia mentions, press releases, professional listings (e.g., LinkedIn Company Page).  
  3. Use press release distributions or relation-building methods to gain mentions in reputable media outlets.  
  4. Ensure these mentions clearly and consistently use your business/brand name (see previous strategy).

Pitfalls & Limits

  - Manipulative or spammy press releases can backfire and reduce trust.  
  - Wikipedia and similar sites have strict editorial standards and removing incorrect info can be difficult.

Example

Websites linked or mentioned by Wikipedia and trusted news sites gained improved trust scores which correlated with better rankings.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Consistent Content Publishing with AI-generated Articles Using Custom Prompts

What It Is

Using AI tools to rapidly produce a steady stream of news-style or topic-related articles, customized with carefully crafted prompts and manual edits, to keep content fresh and claims of authority in niche topics.

Why It Works

Consistent publishing increases crawl frequency, signals active site health, and early coverage of news or trending topics can capture traffic and backlinks from companies and social shares.

When To Use

News websites, blogs focused on trending industry topics, affiliate and content arbitrage sites.

Execution Steps

  1. Curate daily newsworthy topics relevant to your niche via press releases, alerts, and industry news sources.  
  2. Use custom AI prompts containing multiple detailed instructions to rewrite and enrich press releases or news snippets into unique articles.  
  3. Manually review/edit AI outputs for accuracy, style, and helpfulness.  
  4. Publish one to several articles per day, submitting them promptly through Google Search Console for rapid indexing.  
  5. Update or expand articles over time to improve their rankings and relevance.

Pitfalls & Limits

  - Pure copy-paste or superficial rewriting of press releases will not get indexed or rank well.  
  - Excessive publishing (velocity) without quality or trust can trigger manual actions or penalties.  
  - Heavy reliance on AI must be balanced with manual editing to ensure human-like, engaging content.

Example

An SEO expert’s testing revealed publishing AI-augmented press release rewrites led to articles being indexed and ranking within minutes to hours, sometimes getting backlinks and social mentions from the companies themselves.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leverage Brand Name Keyword Targeting by Covering Company News

What It Is

Writing and publishing articles about companies’ news and updates to rank for searches on their brand names, piggybacking off the brand’s own search traffic.

Why It Works

Many people search for exact company names; being an early publisher of their news creates an opportunity to capture valuable brand-specific search traffic with less competition on general keywords.

When To Use

News blogs, affiliate sites, or niche content sites focused on industry companies, tech news, or social media apps.

Execution Steps

  1. Monitor news or press releases about relevant companies.  
  2. Publish timely articles about these announcements as soon after news breaks as possible.  
  3. Optimize articles for the exact company name and product terms.  
  4. Build relationships so companies or news aggregators may link or mention your coverage.  
  5. Keep updating these articles as stories or company info evolves.

Pitfalls & Limits

  - Dependent on continuous monitoring and fast publishing; old or outdated news won’t perform.  
  - Requires maintaining good site authority and content quality to outrank official sites and competitors.

Example

Coverage of a viral issue about Google Business Profile name changes on high schools led to increased links and traffic over months as the article was updated regularly.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Manage Content Velocity to Avoid Penalties from Excessive Page Launches

What It Is

Controlling the rate of new page creation to avoid unnatural spikes that may raise red flags with Google, even if content is unique and helpful.

Why It Works

Sudden massive increases in indexed pages with AI-generated or semi-automated content often trigger manual actions or quality filters as Google detects unnatural site scaling or possible spam behaviors.

When To Use

Large content sites, affiliate networks, SaaS or tool companies generating many user-generated pages or summaries.

Execution Steps

  1. Plan gradual page creation rather than thousands of new pages at once.  
  2. Monitor indexing trends using tools like SEMrush or BrightEdge.  
  3. Combine content creation with link acquisition and trusted brand signals to help Google accept growth naturally.  
  4. Avoid large sudden content dumps; scale up production smoothly.  
  5. Have a fallback plan to remove or adjust low-performing pages fast.

Pitfalls & Limits

  - Failure to follow natural scaling often results in manual penalties or ranking losses.  
  - Content quality, uniqueness, and user engagement must still be maintained regardless of velocity.

Example

A tool gained 350,000 keyword rankings in under a year by creating massive amounts of summarized content linked via good architecture but later had to remove pages after a press-related surge; another site that added tens of thousands of AI pages suddenly saw penalties.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Prioritize Engagement Metrics Over Pure Backlink Quantity for Long-term Ranking

What It Is

Focus on creating content that satisfies search intent, reduces pogo-sticking, and encourages user interaction rather than relying solely on exact-match or volume backlink building.

Why It Works

Google increasingly uses user engagement data (bounce rate, dwell time, click-through, pogo-sticking) to evaluate page relevance and quality, reducing the influence of backlinks alone over time.

When To Use

Competitive informational or transactional queries, sites with existing backlink profiles needing to improve quality signals, content-driven sites.

Execution Steps

  1. Audit pages targeting key queries for user engagement metrics (Google Analytics, Search Console behavior reports).  
  2. Improve content quality, UX, and relevance to reduce bounce and pogo-sticking.  
  3. Build authoritative and relevant backlinks but avoid over-reliance or spammy link tactics.  
  4. Regularly refresh and optimize existing top pages for improved user satisfaction.  
  5. Monitor rankings for sustained improvement driven by engagement signals.

Pitfalls & Limits

  - Engagement is just one factor and doesn’t fully replace link authority.  
  - Small sites with few backlinks and poor domain authority may struggle without link support.

Example

Despite a website having exact match backlinks and ranking #1 temporarily, over time, a competitor with better user engagement and superior content overtook the top spot, even with fewer links.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Secure and Maintain Your Own Domain and Website to Own Your Content and Brand

What It Is

Invest in owning a branded domain and website as your main platform rather than depending solely on social media platforms to publish and distribute your content.

Why It Works

Social media platforms can remove or suspend accounts at any time, taking down your content and causing loss of traffic and revenue, whereas having your own domain provides stable, full control and long-term SEO benefits.

When To Use

All types of content creators, social media influencers, business owners wanting sustainable digital presence.

Execution Steps

   1. Register a relevant, trustworthy domain name aligned with your brand.  
   2. Build a website or blog on the domain hosting your content, products, or services.  
   3. Use social media primarily as a traffic & engagement channel directing users to your website.  
   4. Regularly update and secure your website.  
   5. Archive important content on your own platform, not only on social channels.

Pitfalls & Limits

   - Owning a domain requires some technical and financial commitment.  
   - Neglecting social media reduces reach but owning only social media holds no long term value.

Example

Many top mommy bloggers lost all presence because their domains expired while their social channels could be taken down; owning a domain is essential for brand continuity.

This list reflects all specific, actionable SEO-related strategies extracted from the transcript, presented independently and completely to enable direct implementation without referencing the source discussion.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Viral "First Order" Content for Momentum

What It Is

Create and post authentic, narrative-style videos documenting milestone moments, such as your very first order, to build early momentum and emotional connection with your audience.

Why It Works

Authentic storytelling triggers emotional engagement and social sharing, signaling relevance and quality to social algorithms, which increases organic reach and follower growth.

When To Use

Ideal for new ecommerce brands or startups launching their first products and building an initial audience.

Execution Steps

  • Identify a significant milestone (e.g., first order).
  • Film a short, genuine vlog-style video showing the moment and your reaction.
  • Post it with a compelling title or caption highlighting the milestone.
  • Engage with early commenters to boost engagement.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overuse of milestone content can dilute impact; authenticity is key—faking moments can backfire. Early luck helps but isn't guaranteed.

Example

The business owner filmed her reaction to the first Shopify order; the video went viral with millions of views, fueling rapid early growth.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Posting "Spicy" and Emotional Content for High Engagement

What It Is

Mix bold, humorous (“spicy”) content with emotionally resonant stories (e.g., pet loss, miscarriage) to drive shareability and virality.

Why It Works

Polarizing and emotionally charged content tends to generate strong reactions, encourage comments and shares, which the platform algorithms reward with higher visibility.

When To Use

Suitable for lifestyle, apparel, personalized products, or brands willing to address sensitive topics authentically.

Execution Steps

  • Create content that’s either humorous/spicy or deeply emotional but respectful.
  • Use storytelling or relatable characters to connect with diverse audience segments.
  • Monitor audience response and refine content tone accordingly.

Pitfalls & Limits

Emotional content requires sensitivity; mishandling can alienate or upset audiences. Not every brand or niche can balance spicy or serious topics well.

Example

Videos about customer's dogs that passed away and spicy personalized products both went viral for Soulmate Customs.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Consistent High-Volume Content Creation

What It Is

Produce and post multiple videos daily, maintaining a consistent posting schedule to maximize organic reach and engagement.

Why It Works

Platforms like TikTok reward frequent content with increased exposure; consistent content keeps the audience engaged and feeds the algorithm continuous data to optimize distribution.

When To Use

Effective for ecommerce, personal brands, and social-first businesses with resources or creators dedicated to content output.

Execution Steps

  • Commit to a daily goal (e.g., 7+ videos per day).
  • Create a simple, repeatable filming and editing process.
  • Avoid perfectionism; prioritize speed and volume.
  • Use time blocking to dedicate focused content creation periods.

Pitfalls & Limits

High volume risks burnout; content quality can suffer without systems. Consistency is critical; missing days reduces momentum.

Example

Kayada routinely creates 7+ videos daily for years and credits content volume as the backbone of her business’s millions in sales.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Building “Content Houses” or Dedicated Social Teams

What It Is

Assemble a specialized team focused solely on content creation, editing, and posting to scale content output systematically.

Why It Works

Dedicated personnel enables higher volume and diversified content, improves efficiency, and sustains consistent brand presence across platforms.

When To Use

Best for scaling ecommerce or personal brands once initial growth validates content marketing as a central growth lever.

Execution Steps

  • Hire/training content creators and social media assistants focused on your preferred platforms.
  • Set clear content goals and processes (e.g., posting frequency, repost schedules).
  • Oversee content quality and maintain brand voice.

Pitfalls & Limits

Hiring too fast or with mismatched culture causes team dysfunction and decreased productivity. Training is time-consuming.

Example

Kayada plans to expand from solo content creation to a full content house after learning from 3 years of heavy video output.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Using Two TikTok Accounts (Business & Personal) to Access Trending Sounds

What It Is

Use a separate non-business TikTok account to find trending sounds and create videos, then post on the business account to avoid music restrictions.

Why It Works

TikTok restricts trending sound use on business accounts, limiting virality potential; using a personal account circumvents these limitations to reach wider audiences.

When To Use

Ecommerce and brands restricted by business account sound licensing on TikTok.

Execution Steps

  • Create a personal TikTok account to explore and download trending sounds.
  • Film and edit videos using those sounds from the personal account.
  • Post final videos on your main business account without directly reposting from TikTok.
  • Avoid reposting videos directly between accounts to prevent algorithm penalties.

Pitfalls & Limits

Requires extra management and discipline. TikTok may detect reposting and penalize accounts if rules are not followed.

Example

Kayada logs into TikTok Studio via a random non-business account to film and save videos, then posts uploading them freshly to the business account.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Reposting Viral and Near-Viral Videos Regularly

What It Is

Schedule regular reposts of previously viral or near-viral videos (with ~2k-3k likes) spaced one month or more apart to maximize reach over time.

Why It Works

Viral content can have multiple lifecycles; reposting taps new audience segments or reignites interest; near-viral videos may perform better with more exposure.

When To Use

Useful for creators and ecommerce brands with a large content library and strong performing past videos.

Execution Steps

  • Identify past videos with at least ~2,000 likes or 50K views (viral-proof).
  • Use social media managers or scheduling tools to repost these videos spaced by at least 1 month or more.
  • Monitor engagement and adjust repost frequency as needed.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overposting exact same videos too often leads to audience fatigue or backlash. The platform’s algorithm may downrank excessive reposting if too close in time.

Example

Kayada reposts some videos every month, with some hitting 30 million views repeatedly.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Cross-Platform Repurposing of Content

What It Is

Distribute identical or slightly adjusted videos across multiple platforms (TikTok, Instagram, Snapchat, YouTube Shorts, Pinterest, Facebook) to maximize exposure.

Why It Works

Each platform has unique audiences and algorithms; repurposing ensures content hits broader demographics and leverages platform-specific engagement mechanics.

When To Use

Highly effective for e-commerce creators, personal brands, or any business seeking organic growth on social media.

Execution Steps

  • Upload videos simultaneously or staggered across all platforms.
  • Tweak formatting, captions, and sound choices to match platform expectations.
  • Use tools like Google Drive, repurpose.io, or social schedulers that support multiple platforms.

Pitfalls & Limits

Minor platform differences can cause mismatched audience preferences. Not all formats or content styles perform identically everywhere.

Example

Kayada’s videos are posted across TikTok, Instagram, Snapchat, YouTube Shorts, and Pinterest achieving consistent audience growth and virality.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Time Blocking for Efficient Daily Workflow

What It Is

Rigorously schedule and divide each day into dedicated blocks for content creation, operations, and other business tasks to maintain focus and productivity.

Why It Works

Time blocking reduces decision fatigue, improves workflow discipline, and maximizes efficiency in high volume environments critical for content-heavy businesses.

When To Use

Useful for solo founders and small teams managing multiple roles, especially in content marketing-dependent ecommerce.

Execution Steps

  • Plan daily schedule in advance, splitting time (e.g., 9am-3pm content only, rest day for operations).
  • Enforce discipline to avoid multitasking during blocks.
  • Adjust schedule regularly to optimize creative and operational output balance.

Pitfalls & Limits

Over-scheduling without flexibility can lead to burnout. Requires discipline and realistic task estimation.

Example

Kayada blocks mornings exclusively for content creation and afternoons for operations, leading to sustainable workflow.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Batch Content Creation Days

What It Is

Dedicate specific days solely for filming and producing enough content to cover multiple future posting dates.

Why It Works

Batching increases efficiency by minimizing setup time and helping creators get into a flow state, reducing daily pressure to produce content.

When To Use

Effective for creators or businesses posting daily or multiple times daily on social media platforms.

Execution Steps

  • Schedule 1-2 days per week purely for content filming.
  • Prepare scripts or ideas ahead.
  • Produce enough videos to cover content calendar for the week or more.
  • Edit and schedule posts accordingly.

Pitfalls & Limits

Risk of content becoming stale if overproduced without timely updates; requires storage and organization.

Example

Kayada uses two days of only content creation to produce ~30 videos per day for the entire week.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Prioritizing Short-Form Video with Trending Sounds

What It Is

Use trending and relevant sounds aligned with video content themes to maximize discoverability and virality.

Why It Works

Social platforms prioritize videos with trending sounds because they are more engaging and familiar to users, increasing the chances of “For You” page placement.

When To Use

Essential for TikTok, Instagram Reels, and Snapchat Spotlight content creators.

Execution Steps

- Regularly browse the “For You” page and trending sounds sections on a personal TikTok account.  
- Select sounds matching the mood, theme, and caption of your videos.  
- Avoid using irrelevant or cringeworthy sounds.  
- Analyse previous posts' performance with different sounds and refine choices.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overusing a single sound can lead to saturation; irrelevant sounds reduce engagement. Business accounts face limitation on trending sound access, hence workarounds are needed.

Example

Kayada finds trending sounds either on her non-business TikTok or by manually searching and sorting sounds by most liked rather than most recent.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leveraging Live Streaming for Community and Reach

What It Is

Regular live streams on multiple platforms to engage new audiences, build community, and increase overall profile visibility and video views.

Why It Works

Live videos tend to be pushed to new users, offer direct interaction, and drive traffic to your profile, increasing views and orders.

When To Use

Great for ecommerce brands, personal brands, and businesses focusing on authentic audience engagement.

Execution Steps

- Schedule recurring live sessions across platforms (Instagram, TikTok, YouTube).  
- Use multiple devices if simultaneous streaming tools are lacking.  
- Engage viewers interactively: answer questions, do giveaways, or offer exclusives.  
- Promote live sessions beforehand to maximize attendance.

Pitfalls & Limits

Resource intensive without automation tools; requires consistent energy; not all audiences respond well to live.

Example

Kayada describes her live streams boosting profile views and community loyalty; Mary Ruth Organics runs affiliate live streams 24/7.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Automated Giveaways Integrating Email & SMS List Building

What It Is

Use giveaway tools integrated with social platforms to automate engagement actions (like emoji commenting) that trigger entry and gather email and SMS contacts.

Why It Works

Giveaways rapidly increase engagement while capturing valuable leads for future marketing, turning social interactions into owned audience assets.

When To Use

Brands ready to scale email and SMS lists from social followers, especially ecommerce businesses.

Execution Steps

- Use platforms like High Tide or similar to automate giveaway entries via comments.  
- Configure the tool to collect participant emails and numbers through DMs automatically.  
- Promote giveaways heavily through social and live streams.  
- Follow up with email and SMS marketing campaigns.

Pitfalls & Limits

Poorly executed giveaways can attract non-target leads; must comply with platform rules; giveaways should offer relevant prizes to attract quality leads.

Example

Kayada uses High Tide to give bonus entries on emojis, automatically collects leads, and nurtures them with ongoing marketing.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Starting Ecommerce on Social Marketplaces Before Shopify

What It Is

Launch initial sales on platforms like Etsy or TikTok Shop instead of immediately setting up an independent Shopify store.

Why It Works

Marketplaces have built-in traffic and some marketing promotion features, lowering barriers to initial sales and validating product-market fit with less upfront investment.

When To Use

New entrepreneurs or small ecommerce sellers with limited marketing budget or experience.

Execution Steps

- Choose a marketplace suitable for your product (e.g., Etsy for handmade, TikTok Shop for ready products).  
- Setup a seller profile or store page.  
- List a small batch of products with appealing descriptions and visuals.  
- Promote heavily on social media platforms linking back to marketplace pages.  
- Once demand is validated, consider migrating to Shopify or own site.

Pitfalls & Limits

Limited branding control on marketplaces; fees apply; less direct customer relationship unless captured later.

Example

Kayada advises starting with TikTok Shop or Etsy for ready-made product businesses and emphasizes consistent posting to drive sales.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Hiring and Cultivating a High-Performing Team Culture

What It Is

Hiring selectively to build a team aligned with company values and vision to maintain culture and avoid team dysfunction during growth.

Why It Works

Culture fit ensures motivation, honesty, and effectiveness, all crucial to sustaining rapid growth and operational efficiency.

When To Use

When scaling a business beyond solo or small family operations.

Execution Steps

- Clearly define company values and vision.  
- Conduct thorough interviews prioritizing mindset and work ethic.  
- Onboard new hires with culture training and integration activities.  
- Monitor culture fit regularly and be prepared to let go of individuals damaging team cohesion.

Pitfalls & Limits

Rushing hires leads to toxic culture; poor communication can undermine culture; requires leadership effort.

Example

Kayada experienced quick team deterioration due to fast, unselective hiring, leading to founder conflicts and failures elsewhere.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leveraging Authentic Personal Storytelling in Marketing

What It Is

Share personal struggles and genuine stories transparently to inspire audience connection and trust.

Why It Works

People resonate with vulnerability and authenticity, fostering emotional bonds that increase loyalty and advocacy.

When To Use

Effective for personal brands and small businesses wanting to differentiate themselves.

Execution Steps

- Identify meaningful personal stories connected to your brand journey.  
- Share them thoughtfully in social content or podcasts.  
- Ensure privacy and sensitivities around others involved are respected.  
- Use storytelling to motivate and inspire, not just sell.

Pitfalls & Limits

Over-sharing can harm personal privacy or distract from brand message; balance is essential.

Example

Kayada shared her family’s financial struggles pre-business launch, which strengthened her authentic connection with followers.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Discipline & Mental Health Practices to Sustain Content Creation

What It Is

Prioritize regular sleep, breaks, self-care, and mental discipline to maintain sustainable high-volume content creation.

Why It Works

Burnout is a major risk at high volume; self-care and discipline improve creativity and long-term productivity.

When To Use

Critical for solo creators or small teams managing high output.

Execution Steps

- Schedule consistent wake/sleep cycles (e.g., waking at 5am with adequate sleep).  
- Take regular breaks and incorporate mental health activities (e.g., meditation, walking).  
- Avoid stimulants that lead to crashes; listen to your body.  
- Build routines that support productivity and well-being.

Pitfalls & Limits

Ignoring self-care leads to burnout and inconsistency.

Example

Kayada stresses 8 hours sleep whenever possible and has routines to avoid burnout despite daily multi-video output.

Note: The transcript focused mostly on social media and content-driven organic marketing strategies related to ecommerce growth more than classic SEO tactics. Nevertheless, many extracted strategies have direct or ancillary SEO value, especially in organic discoverability and content marketing on video/social search engines.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Document Your Business Journey via Social Media

What It Is

Regularly create and share authentic, unscripted content documenting the real-time progress and daily activities of your business on platforms like TikTok and Instagram.

Why It Works

Authentic, behind-the-scenes content builds trust and engagement by showcasing the human side of a brand, which resonates with audiences and can lead to viral growth due to genuine connection and storytelling.

When To Use

Best for new or growing businesses aiming to build brand awareness, especially in niches where authenticity is valued (e.g., small businesses, lifestyle brands, ecommerce).

Execution Steps

  1. Start documenting your business activities from day one.
  2. Keep content spontaneous and unscripted to maintain authenticity.
  3. Post consistently on social platforms with video-first content.
  4. Use relatable hooks like "Biggest side hustle 2021" to grab attention.
  5. Engage with comments and messages to deepen connections.

Pitfalls & Limits

Over-polishing or scripting content can reduce authenticity. Requires discipline to post regularly and engage. May not work as well in highly regulated or sensitive industries.

Example

Joshua Ryan Shaver’s microgreens business gained 8–12k followers overnight after a viral authentic post titled “Biggest Side Hustle 2021,” which ultimately generated media coverage from CNN and MSNBC.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Create and Sell an In-Depth Educational PDF (Tripwire Offer)

What It Is

Package your business knowledge and operating procedures in a detailed PDF guide (e.g., 80+ pages) combined with personalized support calls, and sell it as a low-ticket product to monetize your expertise early.

Why It Works

Provides high value at a low price point, enabling quick revenue generation and building trust through direct communication (calls). It also segments warm leads interested in deeper engagement.

When To Use

Ideal for entrepreneurial ventures where step-by-step operational knowledge is valuable (e.g., farming, handcrafting, service industries). Effective early-stage monetization strategy.

Execution Steps

  1. Compile your standard operating procedures and tutorials into a comprehensive PDF with images and graphics.
  2. Set a reasonable price (e.g., $100) reflective of the value.
  3. Offer support via scheduled calls to add personalized value.
  4. Promote through social media posts and direct messages.
  5. Manage incoming sales manually to maintain high customer satisfaction initially.

Pitfalls & Limits

High-touch calls don’t scale well; significant time investment required. May lead to burnout if demand grows too fast without automation.

Example

Joshua sold 200 copies in two weeks, making $20,000 via calls and PDF, with a high conversion rate due to genuine engagement.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Social Media Comments to Drive Lead Capture and Sales via Free Ebooks

What It Is

Encourage viewers to comment a trigger word (e.g., “seeds”) on social media posts; then personally DM commenters a free ebook that includes affiliate/product links, capturing emails in exchange.

Why It Works

Leverages social proof and engaged comments as qualifiers, enabling direct outreach to a targeted, warm audience. Gating valuable content by email captures leads for future marketing.

When To Use

Highly effective for product-based businesses with a growing and engaged social audience (e.g., ecommerce, digital products).

Execution Steps

  1. Produce engaging social media videos related to your niche.
  2. At the end, instruct viewers to comment a specific keyword to receive a free ebook.
  3. Manually or via automation, DM the commenter a link to a landing page.
  4. On the landing page, require email collection to access the ebook.
  5. Include affiliate and product links strategically inside the ebook to drive conversions.
  6. Follow up with email sequences if possible.

Pitfalls & Limits

Manual DM’ing is time-consuming; over-automation can lead to account flags (e.g., using ManyChat on Instagram). Comment-to-DM automation must be carefully rate-limited to avoid penalties.

Example

Joshua’s free ebook grew his email list close to 25,000 subscribers, with a conversion rate of 6.43%, well above industry average.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Pivot from Affiliate Marketing to Own Product Line to Capture Full Revenue

What It Is

Use initial affiliate relationships as market research and demand validation, then launch your own product or brand to capture more revenue and ownership of customer relationships.

Why It Works

Affiliate deals often have limited payouts and no ongoing commissions; owning the product allows scaling revenue, brand control, and long-term customer engagement.

When To Use

When affiliate payouts decline or are unstable, and you have industry insight and operational capability. Often suited for ecommerce, vertical-specific niches, or productized services.

Execution Steps

  1. Track affiliate performance and commissions diligently.
  2. Identify declining revenue or issues with partner payments.
  3. Explore opportunities for brand ambassador or fixed payment agreements.
  4. If unsatisfactory, initiate own product development aligned with market demand.
  5. Launch your own product line with the existing audience and leverage social proof.

Pitfalls & Limits

Product development requires upfront investment and operational know-how. Risk of alienating affiliate partners. Must have competitive product advantages.

Example

Joshua experienced dwindling affiliate commissions and payment issues and decided to start his own seed business, which is now his biggest revenue stream.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

High Posting Volume Strategy on Social Platforms to Maximize Reach

What It Is

Post frequently (multiple times per day up to 100 posts per day as extreme examples) to maximize content output and increase chances of virality and audience growth.

Why It Works

Social platform algorithms favor frequent, consistent posting; higher volume increases chances of hitting high-performing content and gaining more impressions.

When To Use

Particularly useful for new accounts, rapidly growing brands, and content creators aiming for quick audience growth on TikTok and Instagram.

Execution Steps

  1. Plan to post at least multiple times daily, aiming for quality content but with quantity prioritized early.
  2. Experiment with different content formats and hooks.
  3. Repurpose content across platforms efficiently.
  4. Monitor engagement and refine content based on analytics.
  5. Consider live streaming to engage directly with audiences.

Pitfalls & Limits

Risk of content quality dropping if quantity prioritized excessively; audience fatigue with repetitive content; platform posting limits and account warnings possible if automation misused.

Example

MrBeast’s partner posting 100 pieces per day achieved 9.2 billion monthly impressions and 31.5 million followers. Joshua suggests posting 3+ times a day or more for best results.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Hook Testing and Repurpose Best-Performing Hooks / Videos

What It Is

Identify specific video hooks that consistently generate high engagement and replicate or reuse those hooks in new content and redistribute top-performing videos periodically.

Why It Works

Reusing proven hooks lowers risk by tapping into known audience interests, while repurposing content saves time and maintains content pipeline. Algorithms favor consistent engagement.

When To Use

Ongoing strategy after initial growth phase for content creators and marketers optimizing social media reach.

Execution Steps

  1. Analyze video performance data to identify top hooks (e.g., “Take a look at this comment”).
  2. Maintain a list of proven hooks and incorporate them regularly in content creation.
  3. Repost high-performing videos periodically, monitoring for renewed engagement.
  4. Engage deeply with comments to discover what content resonates most.

Pitfalls & Limits

Overuse can lead to audience fatigue if content feels repetitive; no analysis or experimentation can limit further growth.

Example

Joshua’s top 10 hooks from videos created in 2021 still perform well today; reposting videos from Google Drive backups yields new viral spikes.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Manual Comment-to-DM Engagement to Convert Viewers to Leads

What It Is

Instead of automating DM responses, personally reply to people who comment a specific keyword with curated messages and ebook links to build trust and avoid platform penalties.

Why It Works

Personalized interactions increase likelihood of conversion and avoid algorithmic penalties associated with spammy automation.

When To Use

Best for creators/small businesses with manageable engagement volume and high-value leads.

Execution Steps

  1. Monitor comments and identify those containing your trigger keyword.
  2. Use platform tools to message commenters directly with templated responses.
  3. Include links to lead magnets and ask for email addresses if necessary.
  4. Keep the tone authentic and engaging.

Pitfalls & Limits

Time-consuming; becomes unscalable as following grows; risk of missing comments if overwhelmed.

Example

Joshua replies to ~1,000 comments manually over a week using copy-paste DM responses, avoiding ManyChat due to account flagging risks.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Build a Simple Funnel: Social Media ➔ Free Lead Magnet ➔ Email Capture ➔ Product Sales

What It Is

Use social media to drive traffic to a free ebook (lead magnet) where users submit their email; then nurture those leads with email marketing and direct them to an online store to purchase products.

Why It Works

Capturing emails allows direct communication and ongoing engagement; free valuable content builds trust, warming the audience for eventual sales.

When To Use

Ideal for ecommerce entrepreneurs and info-product sellers seeking to build an owned audience beyond social media algorithms.

Execution Steps

  1. Create valuable free ebook related to your niche.
  2. Promote on social media with call to action to comment for the ebook.
  3. DM commenters a link to an email-gated landing page.
  4. Deliver ebook via email and start nurturing sequence.
  5. Include product and affiliate links inside the ebook and emails.
  6. Use cart abandonment and retargeting automations as business scales.

Pitfalls & Limits

Requires good lead magnet quality and strong email follow-up sequences for best conversion; customer journey must be frictionless.

Example

Joshua’s funnel has captured about 25,000 email subscribers with high conversion rates and transitions free users into paying seed customers.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Automate Multi-Platform Video Distribution with Manual Upload for Sensitive Platforms

What It Is

Use automation tools to post videos from TikTok automatically to platforms that allow such automation (LinkedIn, Snapchat, Pinterest), combined with manual uploads for platforms (Instagram, YouTube Shorts) that penalize automated postings from shared IPs.

Why It Works

Maximizes content reach with minimal manual effort while avoiding platform penalties that can reduce organic reach or trigger account warnings.

When To Use

Social media creators scaling content distribution across multiple platforms, especially with large video volumes.

Execution Steps

  1. Use tools like Reus.video to automatically distribute TikTok videos to most platforms.
  2. Store videos on cloud (Google Drive) for backup.
  3. Manually upload videos to Instagram and YouTube Shorts to avoid automation penalties.
  4. Repurpose top-performing videos using cloud storage for re-sharing.

Pitfalls & Limits

Manual upload steps required; risk of missing timely posting windows; harder for smaller teams.

Example

Joshua backs up videos to Google Drive via Reus.video, automates posting everywhere except Instagram and YouTube Shorts, where manual posting preserves reach and engagement.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leverage Comment Analysis to Discover New Product/Service Opportunities

What It Is

Monitor customer and audience comments on social media to identify repeated pain points, desires, and unmet needs that can be developed into new products or services.

Why It Works

Real-time customer feedback in comments provides direct insight into market demand and product gaps, reducing guesswork and validating new business ideas.

When To Use

Suitable for content creators, ecommerce stores, and service providers looking to expand product/offerings and align with audience needs.

Execution Steps

  1. Regularly read and categorize audience comments on posts and videos.
  2. Identify frequently mentioned problems or requests.
  3. Validate demand by engaging or surveying audience deeper if needed.
  4. Develop products or services to solve identified needs.
  5. Market the new offerings back to the audience with proof of demand.

Pitfalls & Limits

Comments may be anecdotal or from small sample sizes; requires discernment to filter genuine demand from noise.

Example

Joshua noticed recurring complaints about seed quality from affiliate product customers in comments, which inspired him to launch his own seed company.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Use Cross-Promotion within Videos via Hypnotizing/Entertaining Background Visuals

What It Is

Combine educational or business commentary with engaging, hypnotizing video footage related to your niche as the background to hold viewer attention and increase watch time.

Why It Works

Better viewer retention signals to algorithms improved content quality, boosting reach. Visual stimulation complements verbal information for a richer experience.

When To Use

Ideal for educational content creators, business channels, and niche product marketers on video platforms like TikTok and Instagram.

Execution Steps

  1. Film or source visually captivating videos related to your industry (e.g., power washing).
  2. Create video content with yourself on green screen or picture-in-picture, adding these videos as backgrounds.
  3. Overlay commentary discussing business insights or product info.
  4. Post regularly and monitor engagement metrics.

Pitfalls & Limits

Visuals must be relevant and not distract from the message. Requires some video editing skill.

Example

Joshua’s friend Chris combines business talk with power washing videos as background, resulting in hypnotizing, high-engagement content.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Implement Cart Abandonment and Retargeting Automations in Ecommerce Funnels

What It Is

Use ecommerce automation tools (e.g., Shopify apps) to send automated messages or emails to visitors who abandon carts or show interest, gently nudging them to complete purchases.

Why It Works

Reduces lost sales by capturing attention of warm leads and reminding them to buy, improving conversion rates and ROI on marketing efforts.

When To Use

Essential for ecommerce businesses with online stores aiming to improve sales funnel efficiency.

Execution Steps

  1. Integrate cart abandonment apps into your online store.
  2. Configure email/SMS sequences that trigger when carts are abandoned.
  3. Personalize messages with product info, offers, or incentives.
  4. Monitor results and optimize sequences over time.

Pitfalls & Limits

Over-messaging can annoy customers; requires compliance with SMS/email marketing laws. Setup complexity may be high for beginners.

Example

Joshua mentions his partner brand uses multiple software setups for reclaiming and retargeting carts, though his own setup is simpler.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Prioritize Long-Term Funnel Development and Consistent Testing

What It Is

Build your marketing funnel gradually over years, continuously testing and tweaking aspects like social media channels, lead magnets, email sequences, and sales methods to improve performance.

Why It Works

Funnels require iteration and adjustment with real data; long-term persistence allows compound growth and refining based on customer behavior and trends.

When To Use

All businesses building digital marketing and sales funnels; especially relevant for startups and scaling brands.

Execution Steps

  1. Launch a simple funnel quickly and start collecting data.
  2. Analyze results regularly to identify bottlenecks or weaknesses.
  3. Test new hooks, formats, and offers based on feedback.
  4. Iterate over months and years to improve conversion rates and expansion.
  5. Be patient and avoid premature scaling or abandonment.

Pitfalls & Limits

Requires patience and discipline; frequent strategy shifts without enough data can cause confusion.

Example

Joshua took 3+ years of consistent effort to build the effective funnel he currently uses with only a simple social media lead magnet and ecommerce store, emphasizing persistence.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Avoid Excessive Reliance on Third-Party Automation Tools That Risk Platform Penalties

What It Is

Be cautious with automation tools (e.g., ManyChat on Instagram) that send mass unsolicited or aggressive messages that could trigger platform restrictions or account bans.

Why It Works

Platforms monitor user behavior to prevent spam; over-automation can reduce organic reach or result in account suspensions, harming growth.

When To Use

Business accounts on social platforms particularly Instagram and TikTok, where DMs and interactions are sensitive to spam detection.

Execution Steps

  1. Research public experiences and platform policies before adopting new automation tools.
  2. Use automation sparingly and implement strict rate limits.
  3. Consider manual outreach when possible, especially during high growth phases.
  4. Monitor account health closely after deploying automation.

Pitfalls & Limits

Sacrifices scalability; requires more manual work; can slow down outreach.

Example

Joshua and peers experienced Instagram account throttling and bans from overuse of ManyChat-style DM automation and prefer manual messaging for now.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Utilize Zapier and Similar Integration Tools to Automate Workflow Without Large Budgets

What It Is

Use no-code automation platforms like Zapier to connect apps (email marketing, CRM, Google Sheets, forms) and automate repetitive business and marketing tasks.

Why It Works

Automations save time, reduce errors, and streamline complex workflows without need for custom software development.

When To Use

Businesses with multiple digital tools that require cross-platform coordination but no internal engineering resources.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify repetitive tasks that involve moving data between apps.
  2. Map out how triggers and actions should flow (e.g., email signup → CRM entry → marketing sequence).
  3. Set up Zaps or workflows in Zapier linking desired apps.
  4. Test thoroughly and monitor for errors.
  5. Scale automation incrementally.

Pitfalls & Limits

Limited to API capabilities of integrated platforms; complex automations may require paid Zapier plans.

Example

Joshua uses Zapier extensively for automating marketing processes and recommends it for streamlining workflows before custom development.

These 15 extracted strategies represent the core actionable SEO and marketing tactics discussed in the transcript with clear definitions, rationales, contexts, steps, pitfalls, and examples.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Hyper-Targeted Content and Advertising on Social Media
What It Is: Deliver customized messages to users based on their language, location, interests, and social circles using a unified platform that supports precise segmentation and targeting.
Why It Works: Search engines and social platforms prioritize user engagement and relevance. Targeting by multiple user attributes increases relevance, engagement, and conversion rates as it aligns with user intent and context.
When To Use: Global ecommerce, multinational brands with diverse audiences, social media campaigns requiring high personalization.
Execution Steps:

  • Choose or develop a platform that supports multilingual, geo-targeted, and interest-based content delivery.
  • Create localized and language-specific content variations.
  • Use social and platform analytics to build audience segments (by location, language, interests, social connections).
  • Publish content tailored for each segment.
  • Run targeted paid campaigns using the same segmentation criteria to amplify effective organic content.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Requires sophisticated platform capabilities; manual content creation for many variations can be resource-intensive. Over-targeting can fragment audience reach or fail if segments are too small.
    Example: Buddy Media enabled companies like Unilever to deliver different Facebook content to a Spanish-speaking visitor in Florida versus an English-speaking visitor in Colombia, increasing message relevance.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Event Sponsorship and Strategic Branding Partnerships
What It Is: Dominate physical event touchpoints such as bag drops, coffee cups, client dinners, and branded giveaways to maximize brand exposure with limited budget.
Why It Works: Physical branded collateral at events creates repeated passive impressions and leverages the captive attention of attendees, boosting brand recognition and credibility.
When To Use: Startups and small businesses with limited marketing budgets seeking to build presence at industry conferences or trade shows.
Execution Steps:

  • Identify key industry events attended by target audiences.
  • Reach out to event organizers 6–12 months in advance to propose high-visibility sponsorship opportunities (e.g., bags, coffee cups).
  • Negotiate bundled deals including speaking slots, exclusive branding, and client dinners to maximize ROI.
  • Provide branded giveaways that participants will use after the event (e.g., chocolates with logo).
  • Leverage speaking opportunities to share thought leadership content adjacent to branding.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Requires persistence and negotiation skills; the impact can be limited if the sponsorship is too generic or attendees ignore collateral. Also, not ideal if events have limited relevance or low attendance.
    Example: Buddy Media owned bag drops and coffee cups at Facebook and other digital events, combined with speaker appearances and client dinners to maximize visibility with minimal budget.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Thought Leadership via PR and Influencer Relationship Building
What It Is: Build credibility and market dominance by regularly securing speaking engagements, media commentary, and influencer collaborations focused on your market’s future and innovation.
Why It Works: Search engines and social proof favor authoritative, trusted voices. Thought leadership drives inbound interest, backlinks, and organic mentions that improve SEO and brand trust.
When To Use: B2B SaaS, emerging technology sectors, startups seeking market credibility and early traction, brands aiming to become known authorities.
Execution Steps:

  • Hire or designate a PR person early to manage outreach and media relations.
  • Build relationships with reporters, influencers, and conference organizers via consistent, valuable communications (lunches, calls, events).
  • Secure frequent speaking slots that align with industry trends and company vision.
  • Produce high-value content (blogs, podcasts) that reporters and influencers want to reference.
  • Invite media and influencers to branded events and content tapings.
    Pitfalls & Limits: PR can be expensive and time-consuming, and unrelated or overly promotional pitches can reduce opportunities. Requires consistent effort over time; not a quick fix.
    Example: Buddy Media had PR ahead of 15 employees from early, securing commentary spots on CNN, CNBC, and others, which built their reputation in the social media marketing space.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Targeting High-Intent Customers with SEO Using Compact Keywords
What It Is: Focus SEO efforts on keywords and queries that indicate immediate purchasing intent using short, precise terms and minimal content to reach customers at the moment they want to buy or use a product or service.
Why It Works: Google and search algorithms prioritize intent; users who search with high-intent keywords are closer to conversion, so ranking for these terms directly boosts sales effectiveness without heavy content or backlink investment.
When To Use: Ecommerce, service providers, businesses seeking quick customer acquisition without large content creation or backlink building teams.
Execution Steps:

  • Identify compact, highly transactional keywords representing strong purchase intent in your niche.
  • Develop focused landing pages or social content (including videos, forums) optimized for these keywords, using few words but clear calls-to-action.
  • Apply on-page SEO best practices focusing on title tags, meta descriptions, and URL structure.
  • Use internal linking and schema where appropriate to help search engines understand the intent.
  • Track rankings and conversions, refining keywords and messaging iteratively.
    Pitfalls & Limits: May miss broader audience education or brand awareness benefits. Limited content may reduce rankings for related informational keywords and may not scale well for brand building.
    Example: The transcript’s speaker launched a program called Compact Keywords that achieved high customer acquisition with few backlinks and short pages, showing “insane results” by getting customers when they have cash in hand.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Strategic Relationship Building and Value-First Outreach
What It Is: Approach network building and outreach as a process of adding value first rather than asking for favors, focusing on building genuine relationships over time with specific, tangible asks.
Why It Works: People with influence receive many requests; those offering clear value or specific, well-researched questions are more likely to get responses and collaboration, leading to trust and longer-term opportunities.
When To Use: Entrepreneur networking, influencer marketing, B2B lead generation, PR outreach, and expert collaborations.
Execution Steps:

  • Research people thoroughly before outreach, demonstrating knowledge of their work and relevance.
  • Craft messages with specific questions or offers that clearly add value to them or their network.
  • Avoid generic “pick your brain” requests; instead, be precise and prepared.
  • Be persistent but respectful in follow-ups; try to build rapport with insights or helpful resources.
  • Maintain relationships post initial contact by sharing valuable info or opportunities.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Effort-intensive; requires time and research. Overly transactional attempts or spammy mass outreach can burn bridges. Some influencers may not respond regardless.
    Example: Mike Lazarro’s approach to Scott Galloway and other influencers was to educate them on the Facebook platform and not ask for direct favors, resulting in strong ongoing collaborations.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Building and Maintaining a Strong Company Culture (“Positive Cult”) to Retain Talent and Support Pivoting
What It Is: Develop a consistent, positive internal culture where employees align on mission and vision, helping to maintain morale through business pivots or challenges.
Why It Works: Employee engagement reduces turnover, maintains productivity, and preserves institutional knowledge critical for long-term SEO and marketing consistency. Company culture indirectly affects brand reputation and external perceptions.
When To Use: Startups undergoing rapid growth or frequent pivots, companies in competitive labor markets.
Execution Steps:

  • Foster clear communication of vision and values regularly.
  • Create rituals or shared experiences that build camaraderie (team activities, philanthropic efforts).
  • Encourage transparency about challenges and strategy to build trust.
  • Recognize and reward employees for alignment and success.
  • Leverage initial employees as anchors to recruit like-minded talent.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Culture takes time; superficial culture-building won’t retain employees. May not directly impact SEO or marketing but supports sustainable growth. Remote settings complicate culture-building.
    Example: Buddy Media emphasized culture early, even spelling “culture” as “cult” to stress unity, which helped them survive multiple pivots and growth phases.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Own Your Local Market and Leverage Travel for Networking
What It Is: Dominate your immediate local market through visibility and relationship-building and proactively travel to other industry hubs to meet prospects and partners in person.
Why It Works: Local reputation opens doors easier in small or emerging markets. Face-to-face meetings build trust and lead to higher conversion rates than cold outreach; word-of-mouth also grows stronger locally.
When To Use: Entrepreneurs in non-major tech hubs or emerging markets; small businesses expanding regionally.
Execution Steps:

  • Identify key local customers, partners, and influencers and focus on engaging them deeply.
  • Attend or host local events for niche dominance.
  • Plan visits to bigger markets or industry conferences to network with a clear agenda and follow-up strategy.
  • Use personal invitations and warm introductions to accelerate relationships.
  • Follow up diligently post-meetings to convert relationships into business outcomes.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Travel requires resources and time; local markets may be limited in size. Remote alternatives (digital meetings) can be less effective.
    Example: The founders’ experience growing out of Chicago demonstrated local dominance helped open doors despite a smaller tech ecosystem, supplemented by trips to other cities.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Consistent Daily Content Creation on Social & Video Platforms
What It Is: Produce and publish multiple pieces of video content daily to build an engaged audience steadily over time by showing up consistently and authentically.
Why It Works: Algorithms on platforms like TikTok and Instagram favor consistent creators; daily posting increases follower growth, visibility, and organic reach. Frequent, authentic content creates familiarity and trust with your audience.
When To Use: Personal brands, entrepreneurs, marketers building thought leadership or community on video/social platforms.
Execution Steps:

  • Commit to a consistent publishing schedule (e.g., 2 videos/day, 6 days/week).
  • Plan and batch content to maintain flow and reduce daily pressure.
  • Focus on authenticity and being yourself rather than perfection.
  • Analyze audience engagement to refine content types and topics.
  • Use platform-native editing tools or simple editors to speed production.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Can lead to burnout or quality dilution if not managed. Early audience growth can be slow, requiring patience. Overproduction can reduce authenticity.
    Example: Mike and Cass publish two videos per day, six days a week, focusing on genuine storytelling and evolving their craft over months.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Leverage Social Video as a Long-Term Channel for Audience Growth and Customer Acquisition
What It Is: Use video-focused social media as a primary marketing channel due to increasing user preference and engagement on this format. Embrace video as a key content type for next 3–5 years.
Why It Works: Algorithms reward video content with higher reach; social video taps into user behavioral trends favoring visual, short-form, easily digestible content, boosting brand awareness and engagement.
When To Use: Brands targeting consumer audiences on platforms like TikTok, Instagram, YouTube Shorts, LinkedIn video, and emerging social networks.
Execution Steps:

  • Develop a video content plan aligned with brand messaging and audience interests.
  • Experiment with formats: tutorials, behind-the-scenes, storytelling, thought leadership.
  • Optimize content for platform-specific preferences (length, captions, hooks).
  • Engage with audience via comments and responses to build community.
  • Track performance and adapt to changing platform features and trends.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Requires creativity and resources; platform shifts can make reinvestment necessary. May not suit B2B with low video engagement; requires ongoing commitment.
    Example: The guests emphasized the importance of adapting to evolving social video trends and are deeply involved with Meta and other platforms advising on content strategies.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name

: Use Persistence and Multi-Touch Negotiation to Secure Premium Marketing Opportunities
What It Is: Rather than passively buying basic access, aggressively negotiate event sponsorships, speaking opportunities, and branding positions by applying multiple negotiation attempts and creative offers.
Why It Works: Persistence increases chances of better deals; bundling valuable assets increases perceived worth for event organizers and advertisers. Creative negotiations can unlock hidden sponsorship value at lower cost.
When To Use: Startups and small businesses maximizing tight marketing budgets, marketers looking for thought leadership visibility.
Execution Steps:

  • Identify key decision-makers and maintain persistent but polite follow-up.
  • Prepare multiple proposals with bundled offers (speaking slot + branding + giveaways).
  • Be flexible to adapt offers to organizer’s needs or constraints.
  • Use creativity to stand out (e.g., branded chocolate bars).
  • Track contacts and conversations to avoid burnout with ineffective leads.
    Pitfalls & Limits: Risk of being seen as pushy; excessive persistence can backfire. Not all event organizers are flexible. Requires strong interpersonal skills.
    Example: Buddy Media secured coffee cup branding, bag drops, speaking slots, and dinners at major conferences with persistent negotiation and creative offers despite small marketing budgets.

This list synthesizes all uniquely actionable SEO and marketing strategies referenced or implied in the transcript portion focused on SEO and digital marketing, omitting generic business/entrepreneur advice and focusing strictly on actionable tactics with SEO relevance.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Viral Meme Marketing for B2B SaaS

What It Is

Creating and sharing humorous, relatable memes tailored to your niche (even if it's "boring," like accounting or sales) on platforms such as Twitter, LinkedIn, and Instagram to attract and engage potential customers.

Why It Works

Memes naturally encourage sharing and engagement due to their humor and relatability. By standing out in traditionally dull B2B markets with entertaining content, you increase top-of-funnel visibility, build brand affinity, and generate inbound leads organically.

When To Use

B2B SaaS marketing, especially in niches considered dry or technical; also effective for startups seeking viral organic reach without big advertising budgets.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify key pain points, stereotypes, or jokes relevant to your industry or audience.
  2. Use a meme marketing tool or create memes using no-code or graphic apps.
  3. Post memes regularly on Twitter, LinkedIn, and Instagram focusing on consistency.
  4. Always include a subtle "plug" or link to your product/newsletter in the comment or thread below (never in the meme itself).
  5. Track engagement and iteratively adjust meme style based on audience reaction.
  6. Optionally, maintain a dedicated memes page on your website for further engagement and brand personality.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Memes can alienate if they miss the mark culturally or aren't well understood by the target audience.
  • Overly promotional memes lose authenticity and can reduce engagement.
  • Some platforms (e.g., Instagram) may require more careful content adaptation than Twitter or LinkedIn.
  • Requires a good product as memes drive interest but won’t convert without value.

Example

  • A YC-backed AI SaaS company used memes on Twitter to book demos.
  • An accounting SaaS attracted Gen Z founders by making accounting memes "fun."
  • A sales SaaS credits 90% of pipeline to meme marketing, posting edgy content across social media.
  • Chris Baky drove $3 million in B2B sales using viral memes with plugs underneath posts.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Plugging Links in Comments Under Viral Posts

What It Is

Instead of placing links directly in the main social media post (which platforms may demote), add your call-to-action or product/newsletter link as a comment after the post starts gaining traction.

Why It Works

Platforms like X (Twitter) demote posts with links in the original content but allow links placed in comments after traction is built, preserving reach while driving traffic.

When To Use

Growing newsletters or products via social media posts, especially on platforms with strict link demotion policies (e.g., X, LinkedIn).

Execution Steps

  1. Post content (memes, tweets, videos) without links initially.
  2. Once the post gains engagement (usually after 1-2 hours), add a comment with the call-to-action link.
  3. On LinkedIn, if possible, edit the post after traction to add a link or add the link in a comment.
  4. Repeat consistently for all content types.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Adding links too early can cause demotion.
  • Requires monitoring posts post-publication, which demands resources.
  • Not as effective on platforms like Instagram, where bio links or stories are preferred.

Example

  • Jason shares marketing hacks in posts then comments with "subscribe to my newsletter" links beneath successful posts, which steadily grows subscribers over years.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Automated LinkedIn Outreach Using PhantomBuster

What It Is

Using PhantomBuster to automatically connect with a targeted LinkedIn audience (e.g., employees/founders associated with a specific VC or incubator) and sending automated follow-up messages with a newsletter or product pitch.

Why It Works

Direct outreach to a highly relevant and filtered audience increases conversion rates. Automation saves time and enables scaling outreach without manual effort. LinkedIn’s acceptance rates are higher when connection requests come without messages, making this approach feel less spammy.

When To Use

B2B lead generation, newsletter growth, and startup marketing targeting investors, founders, or specific professional groups.

Execution Steps

  1. Define your target audience using keywords or affiliations in bios (e.g., "16z", "YC").
  2. Set PhantomBuster to send connection requests (e.g., 20 per day) without a message.
  3. Once connections are accepted, automatically send a short personalized message with a link to your newsletter or product.
  4. Monitor acceptance and engagement for effectiveness.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • LinkedIn has limits and anti-spam policies; overuse may cause account restrictions.
  • Too many unsolicited messages can damage brand reputation if not carefully managed.
  • Messages must be concise and respectful of recipients' time to avoid being ignored or reported.

Example

  • Jason used this to connect and pitch an organic growth newsletter to VC-backed tech founders resulting in new subscribers and potential customers.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Cross-Promotion of Newsletter Through Integrated Product Signup

What It Is

Automatically adding users who sign up for your software or app to your email newsletter, syncing data through tools like Zapier for continuous and seamless audience building.

Why It Works

Combining product onboarding and newsletter subscription reduces friction and maximizes user engagement with ongoing helpful content, increasing retention and conversion opportunities.

When To Use

Software-as-a-Service (SaaS), apps, or tools with user signups tied closely to content marketing strategies.

Execution Steps

  1. Set up your newsletter platform and product signup flow.
  2. Use an automation tool like Zapier to connect product signup forms to your newsletter subscriber list.
  3. Inform users during signup about newsletter benefits to reduce opt-out rates.
  4. Send regular value-packed emails to this combined audience.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Not obtaining explicit consent for marketing emails may violate GDPR or spam laws.
  • Low-quality emails can increase unsubscribes and hurt future deliverability.
  • If product users do not fit your newsletter’s content niche, engagement may drop.

Example

  • Jason’s meme marketing software automatically adds every new user to his marketing newsletter, growing his audience while nurturing product users with helpful marketing tips.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Consistent Daily Content Creation and Iterative Posting

What It Is

Producing and publishing content every day (tweets, videos, blog posts) to accelerate learning, quickly discover what resonates, and compound audience growth through iterative improvement.

Why It Works

Frequent posting allows fast feedback loops, helps algorithms favor active accounts, and builds habitual audience expectations, leading to organic reach and growth.

When To Use

Personal branding, social media growth, small businesses seeking organic scale, and content marketing-driven growth models.

Execution Steps

  1. Block daily time (ideally daily, not weekly) for content creation.
  2. Mix content types: tweets, memes, short videos, blog posts.
  3. Analyze engagement data daily to identify what works.
  4. Modify style, topics, or formats based on feedback and performance.
  5. Use tools to speed editing and posting (e.g., Descript for video editing).

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Risk of burnout if content quality drops or pressure is too high.
  • Inconsistent posting or long gaps break momentum and audience growth.
  • Producing content without strategic focus may scatter efforts.

Example

  • Jason has posted over 3,000 videos since Nov 2022, often making videos within 20 minutes leveraging viral posts from Twitter as inspiration, leading to videos with millions of views.
  • Edward advocates daily video posting over weekly batching for faster iteration.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Leveraging Viral Content from Other Creators and Repurposing It

What It Is

Taking popular viral posts (tweets or videos) from others in your niche and creating new content by reading or reacting to them on other platforms like TikTok or Instagram Reels.

Why It Works

Builds on already proven viral content, reducing content ideation effort while riding the wave of topical interest. Audiences appreciate curation and commentary combined with personal branding.

When To Use

Content creators looking to fast-track reach especially on video platforms like TikTok, Instagram Reels.

Execution Steps

  1. Monitor viral posts from your niche on Twitter or other platforms.
  2. Create quick reaction or reading videos showing your face, adding personality or commentary.
  3. Post these videos on platforms favoring short-form video content.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Repetitive reuse without added value may reduce follower interest.
  • Must give credit or avoid copyright issues on video content.
  • Over-reliance on others’ content without personal original content can stunt brand identity growth.

Example

  • Jason reads and shares viral tweets on TikTok, including the Silicon Valley Bank collapse tweet, which got 15 million views.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Cringe Arbitrage on LinkedIn

What It Is

Posting unconventional, authentic, or humorous content on LinkedIn, a platform known for formal, curated content, to stand out and create viral engagement. This can include memes, family photos, or less polished personal stories.

Why It Works

Because LinkedIn is saturated with similar professional posts, breaking the mold by being genuine or funny captures attention, evokes emotional response, and exploits algorithmic preference for high-engagement content.

When To Use

Personal branding, B2B marketing, enterprise professionals, and CEOs wanting to humanize their presence.

Execution Steps

  1. Share posts that show personality beyond work, such as memes or event photos.
  2. Use humor and vulnerability strategically to connect with the audience.
  3. Observe engagement metrics and iterate content style.
  4. Balance professionalism with authenticity to avoid alienation.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Risk of offending viewers or seeming unprofessional if content is too edgy.
  • May not suit all industries or brand images.
  • Overdoing “cringe” content can harm personal brand credibility.

Example

  • Jason and customers use memes on LinkedIn resulting in substantial engagement and revenue, making tens of thousands monthly despite “cringe” perception.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Parasite SEO via Large Platforms (Reddit, Quora, Medium)

What It Is

Posting relevant content or comments on high-authority third-party platforms to rank for target keywords on Google search, thereby capturing search traffic without owning a website.

Why It Works

Large platforms have strong domain authority, so content posted there can outrank smaller or new sites, driving organic traffic indirectly to products or brands.

When To Use

Sites or new brands without SEO authority; content creators seeking discoverability via question-answer or discussion platforms.

Execution Steps

  1. Identify relevant keywords and questions in your niche.
  2. Create high-quality, helpful posts or comments on Reddit, Quora, Medium related to those keywords.
  3. Avoid direct self-promotion in the content; place brand mentions subtly.
  4. Monitor ranking and organic traffic growth to these posts.
  5. Optionally experiment with affiliate links or indirect calls to action.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Platforms like Reddit are strict about self-promotion and links; poor execution can get you banned.
  • Hard to attribute conversions directly, making ROI measurement difficult.
  • Requires natural and genuine participation in communities to avoid backlash.

Example

  • Jason accidentally ranked for “Twitter marketing tools” on Reddit leading to affiliate sales.
  • Brands outsource posting/commenting via ghost accounts to subtly promote their products without direct links.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Paid Influencer Marketing Post-Viral Organic Success

What It Is

After achieving organic viral content momentum, supplement growth efforts with paid influencer promotions to amplify reach and conversions.

Why It Works

Organic virality validates product-market fit and content appeal. Paid influencer marketing then leverages established trust and audience alignment to scale faster.

When To Use

When a content piece or product gains early organic traction but needs further growth acceleration; for resale or conversion-heavy campaigns.

Execution Steps

  1. Track organic posts that go viral or gain traction.
  2. Identify and engage relevant influencers to promote your product/content.
  3. Design paid campaigns around proven organic content assets.
  4. Measure ROI and scale or adjust accordingly.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Paying for influencer distribution without organic success can waste budget.
  • Poor influencer-product fit reduces campaign effectiveness.
  • Over-reliance on paid can hurt long-term organic growth.

Example

  • Jason plans to start paid influencer marketing after organic viral success with Elon Email but prefers organic methods initially.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Content Automation and Scheduling with Platform-Specific Tactics

What It Is

Utilizing automation tools to schedule and cross-post content across platforms, while adapting posting methods to avoid algorithmic demotion or suppression on sensitive platforms like Instagram and Facebook.

Why It Works

Automation saves time and ensures consistent posting, but platforms have different algorithm sensitivities; manual posting may be required on some to maximize reach.

When To Use

For scaling social media marketing efforts across multiple channels consistently.

Execution Steps

  1. Create content and prepare it for multi-platform use.
  2. Use automation tools to schedule posts on X (Twitter), LinkedIn, etc., where automation doesn’t hurt performance.
  3. Post natively and manually on platforms like Instagram and Facebook where automated posts may be suppressed.
  4. Monitor performance and tweak posting strategies as platforms update policies.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Over-automation on platforms like Instagram can result in lower reach or shadowbanning.
  • Manual posting increases time commitment but is necessary for best results on some platforms.

Example

  • Edward’s published guide “Exact Social Media Posting Strategy” details how to automate on some platforms and manually post on others to avoid suppression.

These 10 strategies represent all specific, actionable SEO and marketing tactics extracted from the transcript. Each is self-contained, actionable, and based on the insights and examples discussed by the speakers.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

High-Volume Consistent Video Production

What It Is

Consistently producing and publishing multiple videos daily (starting from 1 per day and scaling up to 5-6 or even more).

Why It Works

Frequent posting signals activity and freshness to platforms, increases chances of content discovery, and trains the creator to improve rapidly through iteration. Regular engagement builds momentum and audience loyalty.

When To Use

Best for social video platforms (TikTok, Instagram Reels, YouTube Shorts), content creators looking for rapid growth especially in niches with emerging or growing interest. Useful for individuals and small teams scaling content quickly.

Execution Steps

  1. Set a daily posting goal (start with 1 video, increase incrementally).
  2. Prepare scripts or outlines in advance to maintain quality at scale.
  3. Dedicate specific times or locations (studio/workspace) for video recording.
  4. Edit and post promptly, using consistent branding and hooks.
  5. Scale production capacity by outsourcing editing and scriptwriting as volume demands.
  6. Track viewer engagement and iterate on format and delivery.

Pitfalls & Limits

  • Risk of burnout without proper planning or support.
  • Content quality might suffer if scaling too fast without process improvements.
  • Not all niches support extremely high volume; may saturate the audience or platform.
  • Requires infrastructure (editors, scriptwriters) beyond a certain point for consistency.

Example

Creator posted 100 videos in a month, increasing daily output from 1 to 5-6 videos, resulting in significant follower growth and viral content. One video reached over 1.7 million views and was successfully reposted multiple times.

Alternative Implementation:

Strategy Name:

Niche Targeting with Emotional Hooks Based on Audience Identity

What It Is

Creating content that appeals emotionally to a specific niche by praising or positively framing their community or identity rather than the subject matter alone.

Why It Works

People resonate strongly with content that validates their ego or identity, encouraging engagement and sharing. Emotional connection increases watch time, comments, and loyalty.

When To Use
